Have you that I sent you for?	Do you have what I told you to get?
Here’s that, I warrant you, will pay them all.	Yes.
But where’s the money?	But where’s the money?
Why, sir, I gave the money for the rope.	Why, sir, I spent it on this rope.
I’ll serve you, sir, five hundred at the rate.	I can get you five hundred ropes for that price.
To what end did I bid thee hie thee home?	Why did I just send you home?
To a rope’s end, sir, and to that end am I returned.	And here I am, with that piece.
And to that end, sir, I will welcome you.	And I’ll use that piece of rope to welcome you with.
Good sir, be patient.	Good sir, calm down.
Good now, hold thy tongue.	Hold your tongue.
Nay, rather persuade him to hold his hands.	No, you should tell him to hold his hands!
I would I were senseless, sir, that I might not feel your blows.	I wish I were senseless, sir, so that I wouldn’t feel your punches!
Thou art sensible in nothing but blows, and so is an ass.	The only thing you can sense are punches—just like an ass.
I am an ass, indeed; you may prove it by my long ears.—I have served him from the hour of my nativity to this instant, and have nothing at his hands for my service but blows.	I am an ass, indeed: you can tell by my long ears.
Nay, I bear it on my shoulders as a beggar wont her brat, and I think when he hath lamed me, I shall beg with it from door to door.	I figure that once he’s crippled me, I’ll beg by showing off my beatings.
Come, go along.	That’s enough.
My wife is coming yonder.	My wife’s coming.
Mistress,  Wilt thou still talk?	Mistress, think about your end—beware of your death!
How say you now?	EPHESUS Now what do you think?
Is not your husband mad?	Your husband’s mad, isn’t he?
Mark how he trembles in his ecstasy.	He’s trembling in his fit!
I conjure thee by all the saints in heaven.	I demand this in the name of all the saints in heaven.
Peace, doting wizard, peace.	Shut up, you doddering old wizard!
I am not mad.	I’m not possessed!
O, that thou wert not, poor distressèd soul!	Oh, I wish you weren’t, you poor, frightened soul.
You minion, you, are these your customers?	Listen, hussy—is this man one of your customers?
Did this companion with the saffron face Revel and feast it at my house today Whilst upon me the guilty doors were shut And I denied to enter in my house?	Did this fool with the yellow face feast and celebrate in my house today while the guilty doors shut in my face and locked me out of my own house?
Dined at home”?	Ate at home?
Thou villain, what sayest thou?	You there, rogue, what do you have to say about that?
Sir, sooth to say, you did not dine at home.	I swear, sir, you did not eat at home.
Were not my doors locked up and I shut out?	My doors were locked and I was shut out, right?
Perdie, your doors were locked, and you shut out.	By God, your doors were locked and you were shut out.
And did not she herself revile me there?	And she screamed at me, right?
Sans fable, she herself reviled you there.	No lie—she screamed at you.
Did not her kitchen maid rail, taunt, and scorn me?	And her cook yelled, mocked, and teased me, right?
And did not I in rage depart from thence?	And I departed in a rage, right?
In verity you did.—My bones bear witness, That since have felt the vigour of his rage.	You truly did.
It is no shame.	Good idea.
Alas, I sent you money to redeem you By Dromio here, who came in haste for it.	I gave it to Dromio, who rushed in for it.
Money by me!	You gave money to me?
Went’st not thou to her for a purse of ducats?	Didn’t you go to her for a purse full of ducats?
He came to me, and I delivered it.	He did, and I gave it to him.
And I am witness with her that she did.	And I saw her do it.
God and the rope-maker bear me witness That I was sent for nothing but a rope.	I was sent for a rope!
Mistress, both man and master is possessed.	Mistress, both the man and his master are possessed.
I know it by their pale and deadly looks.	I can tell by how pale and deathlike they look.
They must be bound and laid in some dark room.	We must tie them up and leave them in some dark room.
I did not, gentle husband, lock thee forth.	My sweet husband, I did not lock you out.
And, gentle master, I received no gold.	And my sweet master, I received no gold.
But I confess, sir, that we were locked out.	But I agree, sir, that we were locked out.
Let him not come near me.	Keep him away from me!
More company!	We need more help!
The fiend is strong within him.	The devil in him is strong!
What, will you murder me?—Thou jailer, thou, I am thy prisoner.	jailer, i’m your prisoner.
Wilt thou suffer them To make a rescue?	are you going to let them break me out of jail?
Masters, let him go.	Gentlemen, let go of him.
He is my prisoner, and you shall not have him.	He’s my prisoner and you can’t have him.
Go, bind this man, for he is frantic too.	Tie up the servant, for he is mad as well.
He is my prisoner.	He’s my prisoner.
If I let him go, The debt he owes will be required of me.	If I let him go, I’ll have to pay his bail fees myself.
I will discharge thee ere I go from thee.	I’ll pay you.
Bear me forthwith unto his creditor, And, knowing how the debt grows, I will pay it.— Good Master Doctor, see him safe conveyed Home to my house.	Take me to the man my husband is in debt to.
O most unhappy day!	What a horrible day!
O most unhappy strumpet!	What a horrible slut!
Master, I am here entered in bond for you.	Master, I’m all tied up for you.
How idly do they talk!	The poor souls—how strangely they talk!
One Angelo, a goldsmith.	Angelo, the jeweler.
Do you know him?	Do you know him?
I know the man.	I know him.
Two hundred ducats.	Two hundred ducats.
Say, how grows it due?	For what?
Due for a chain your husband had of him.	For a necklace your husband had him make.
He did bespeak a chain for me but had it not.	He said he was going to buy me a necklace, but I never saw it.
I long to know the truth hereof at large.	I need to hear the truth about all this.
God for Thy mercy, they are loose again!	God have mercy on us!
And come with naked swords.	And they’ve got their swords unsheathed!
Let’s call more help To have them bound again.	Let’s call for help and get them tied up again!
Away!	Let’s get out of here!
They’ll kill us.	They’ll kill us!
I see these witches are afraid of swords.	It looks like these witches are scared of swords.
She that would be your wife now ran from you.	The one who claims to be your wife just ran away from you.
I long that we were safe and sound aboard.	I wish we were safely on board our ship already.
Faith, stay here this night.	Look, let’s stay here tonight.
They will surely do us no harm.	Nobody will hurt us.
You saw they speak us fair, give us gold.	You see how kind everyone is to us, how they just hand us gold.
Methinks they are such a gentle nation that, but for the mountain of mad flesh	I think this country is so kind that if it weren’t for
that claims marriage of me, i could find in my heart to stay here still, and turn witch.	that mountain of insanity that wants to marry me, I could find it in my heart to stay here and become a witch myself.
I will not stay tonight for all the town.	I wouldn’t stay here tonight for the entire town.
Therefore away, to get our stuff aboard.	Go and get our stuff onto the ship.
How is the man esteemed here in the city?	What’s this man’s reputation like here in the city?
His word might bear my wealth at any time.	I’d trust him with everything I own.
Speak softly.	You’re right.
Tis so; and that self chain about his neck Which he forswore most monstrously to have.	And that necklace around his neck is the very one he swore he didn’t have!
Good sir, draw near to me.	Good sir, stay close to me.
Therefore give out you are of Epidamnum, Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate.	So, tell people that you’re from Epidamnum–otherwise all your goods will be confiscated.
There is your money that I had to keep.	Here’s the money you asked me to hold.
Go bear it to the Centaur, where we host, And stay there, Dromio, till I come to thee.	Dromio, bring this money to the Centaur Inn, where we’re lodging, and wait there until I come.
Within this hour it will be dinnertime.	It’ll be lunchtime within an hour.
Till that, I’ll view the manners of the town, Peruse the traders, gaze upon the buildings, And then return and sleep within mine inn, For with long travel I am stiff and weary.	Until then, I’ll walk around town, peruse the markets, and gaze upon the buildings, and then I’ll return and sleep at the inn.
Get thee away.	Get going now.
Many a man would take you at your word And go indeed, having so good a mean.	Many men would take you literally and take off with all this money.
A trusty villain, sir, that very oft, When I am dull with care and melancholy, Lightens my humor with his merry jests.	Often, when I’m dulled by worry and melancholy, he lightens my mood with his merry pranks.
What, will you walk with me about the town And then go to my inn and dine with me?	Listen, will you walk with me around the town and then dine with me at the inn?
I think I had.	But if
I never did deny it.	I got it from you—I never said I didn’t.
Yes, that you did, sir, and forswore it too.	Yes, you did, sir.
Who heard me to deny it or forswear it?	Who heard me do that?
These ears of mine, thou know’st did hear thee.	My own ears heard it, and you know it.
Fie on thee, wretch.	To hell with you!
Tis pity that thou liv’st To walk where any honest men resort.	It’s a shame that you walk the streets with all the honest men.
Thou art a villain to impeach me thus.	You’re a villain to say this about me.
I’ll prove mine honor and mine honesty Against thee presently if thou dar’st stand.	I’ll prove that I’m an honest man and a man of honor if you dare defend yourself.
I dare, and do defy thee for a villain.	I do dare, and I say that you are the villain.
Run, master, run.	Run, master, run.
For God’s sake, take a house.	For God’s sake, find a house to duck into.
This is some priory.	This looks like an abbey.
In, or we are spoiled.	Go in, or we’re done for.
Be quiet, people.	Be quiet, people!
Wherefore throng you hither?	Why have you come here in such a mob?
To fetch my poor distracted husband hence.	To get my poor, mad husband out from inside there.
Let us come in, that we may bind him fast And bear him home for his recovery.	Let us in so we can tie him up tight and bring him home to recover.
How long hath this possession held the man?	How long has he been possessed like this?
This week he hath been heavy, sour, sad, And much different from the man he was.	This week he was sad, moody, and depressed and very different from his usual self.
But till this afternoon his passion Ne'er brake into extremity of rage.	But it wasn’t until this afternoon that he broke out into violence.
Hath not else his eye Stray’d his affection in unlawful love, A sin prevailing much in youthful men Who give their eyes the liberty of gazing?	That’s a sin young men often commit because they allow their eyes to wander.
Which of these sorrows is he subject to?	Which of these bad things happened to him?
You should for that have reprehended him.	You should have reprimanded him for that.
Why, so I did.	I did.
Ay, but not rough enough.	Fine, but you weren’t harsh enough.
Haply in private.	You scolded him in private?
And in assemblies too.	And in public too.
Ay, but not enough.	Fine, but not enough.
Alone, it was the subject of my theme; In company I often glancèd it.	He couldn’t eat without me talking about it.
Still did I tell him it was vile and bad.	All I ever did was tell him how hurtful and bad it was.
And thereof came it that the man was mad.	And that’s why he went crazy.
The venom clamors of a jealous woman Poisons more deadly than a mad dog’s tooth.	A jealous woman’s poisonous ranting is worse than the bite of a rabid dog.
Thou sayst his meat was sauced with thy upbraidings.	You seasoned his food with screams.
Thou sayest his sports were hinderd by thy brawls.	Fever, as we know, is a kind of madness.
In food, in sport, and life-preserving rest To be disturbed, would mad or man or beast.	Ruining his meals, his enjoyment, and his sleep would drive any man or beast mad.
The consequence is, then, thy jealous fits Have scared thy husband from the use of wits.	What I’m saying is, your jealousy has pushed your husband away from his sanity.
Good people, enter and lay hold on him.	Gentlemen, go in there and grab him.
Then let your servants bring my husband forth.	Then have your servants bring him out.
It is a branch and parcel of mine oath, A charitable duty of my order.	Healing is part and parcel of my religious vows; it is a charitable duty my order performs.
Therefore depart and leave him here with me.	Therefore, depart, and leave him here with me.
Be quiet and depart.	Be quiet and depart.
Thou shalt not have him.	You’re not going to take him.
Complain unto the Duke of this indignity.	Go lodge a complaint about this with the duke.
Come, go.	Come with me.
I will fall prostrate at his feet And never rise until my tears and prayers Have won his grace to come in person hither And take perforce my husband from the Abbess.	I’ll fall at his feet and lie there until my pleading and crying convinces the duke to come here and force my husband to leave this abbey.
By this, I think, the dial points at five.	It’s almost five o'clock.
To see a reverend Syracusian merchant, Who put unluckily into this bay Against the laws and statutes of this town, Beheaded publicly for his offense.	To see an elderly, unlucky merchant from Syracuse publicly beheaded for breaking the law and coming here to Ephesus.
See where they come.	Here they come.
We will behold his death.	We will watch the execution.
Kneel to the duke before he pass the abbey.	Kneel down to the duke before he passes by the abbey.
Yet once again proclaim it publicly, If any friend will pay the sum for him, He shall not die; so much we tender him.	One more time, we proclaim this publicly: If anyone will pay this man’s bail, he will not be put to death.
Justice, most sacred duke, against the Abbess.	Duke, the abbess has wronged me and I seek justice.
She is a virtuous and a reverend lady.	She’s a virtuous and holy lady.
It cannot be that she hath done thee wrong.	She can’t possibly have done you any wrong.
Therefore, most gracious duke, with thy command Let him be brought forth and borne hence for help.	So please, most gracious duke, order her to bring him out so we can get him some help.
Long since thy husband served me in my wars, And I to thee engaged a prince’s word, When thou didst make him master of thy bed, To do him all the grace and good I could.	And when you married him and made him the master of your bed, I gave you my word that I would do everything I possibly could for him.
Peace, fool.	Shut up, fool!
Thy master and his man are here, And that is false thou dost report to us.	Your master and his servant are here.
Mistress, upon my life I tell you true.	Mistress, I swear on my life that it’s true.
I have not breathed almost since I did see it.	It was just moments ago.
He cries for you, and vows, if he can take you, To scorch your face and to disfigure you.	He’s crying out for you and swears he’ll burn your face and disfigure you if he can get ahold of you.
Ay me, it is my husband.	Oh, my, it’s my husband.
Witness you That he is borne about invisible.	Look, he can become invisible.
Even now we housed him in the abbey here, And now he’s there, past thought of human reason.	Just now we put him in the abbey over here, and now he’s over there.
Even for the blood That then I lost for thee, now grant me justice.	In exchange for the blood I shed for you then, I ask you for justice now.
Beyond imagination is the wrong That she this day hath shameless thrown on me.	The things she has shamelessly hurled on me are beyond imagination.
This day, great duke, she shut the doors upon me While she with harlots feasted in my house.	Today, great duke, she locked me out of my house and feasted there with whores.
A grievous fault.—Say, woman, didst thou so?	That’s terrible!
No, my good lord.	No, my good lord.
Myself, he, and my sister Today did dine together.	I ate with him and my sister.
So befall my soul As this is false he burdens me withal.	Damn my soul if these accusations are true!
Ne'er may I look on day, nor sleep on night But she tells to your Highness simple truth.	If she’s lying, I pray that I never sleep again at night or wake up during the day.
O perjured woman!	Oh, lying woman!
My liege, I am advisèd what I say, Neither disturbed with the effect of wine, Nor heady-rash, provoked with raging ire, Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad.	My lord, I know what I’m saying.
That goldsmith there, were he not packed with her, Could witness it, for he was with me then, Who parted with me to go fetch a chain, Promising to bring it to the Porpentine, Where Balthasar and I did dine together.	He left to fetch a necklace and he promised to bring it to the Porcupine, where I was dining with Balthasar.
Our dinner done and he not coming thither, I went to seek him.	He hadn’t arrived by the time we finished eating, so I went out looking for him.
In the street I met him, And in his company that gentleman.	I met him in the street—he was there with that man.
By th' way we met My wife, her sister, and a rabble more Of vile confederates.	On the way, we came across my wife, her sister, and their gang of vile associates.
Along with them They brought one Pinch, a hungry, lean-faced villain, A mere anatomy, a mountebank, A threadbare juggler, and a fortune-teller, A needy, hollow-eyed, sharp-looking wretch, A living dead man.	One of them was a man named Pinch: a hungry, narrow-faced villain; a skeleton; a fraud; a raggedy magician and fortune-teller; a needy, hollow-eyed, emaciated wretch; a walking corpse.
This pernicious slave, Forsooth, took on him as a conjurer, And, gazing in mine eyes, feeling my pulse,	He pretended to be some kind of sorcerer, and he gazed in my eyes and took my pulse.
But had he such a chain of thee or no?	They left me and my servant there, tied together.
He had, my lord, and when he ran in here, These people saw the chain about his neck.	He did, my lord.
I never saw the chain, so help me heaven, And this is false you burden me withal.	I never saw the necklace, so help me heaven!
Why, what an intricate impeach is this!	Why, what a complicated case this is!
Soon at five o'clock, Please you, I’ll meet with you upon the mart And afterward consort you till bedtime.	it pleases you, I’ll meet you in the marketplace at five and will keep you company until bedtime.
My present business calls me from you now.	Right now, my pressing business calls me away.
Farewell till then.	Farewell till then.
I will go lose myself And wander up and down to view the city.	I will go lose myself, wandering up and down throughout the city.
Sir, I commend you to your own content.	Sir, I leave you to your own contentment.
He that commends me to mine own content Commends me to the thing I cannot get.	He leaves me to my own contentment, but that’s the one thing I cannot find.
I to the world am like a drop of water That in the ocean seeks another drop, Who, falling there to find his fellow forth, Unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself.	Out in the world, I’m like a drop of water, trying to find a drop that matches in the whole wide ocean.
So I, to find a mother and a brother, In quest of them, unhappy, lose myself.	In order to find a mother and a brother, I too have lost myself, unhappily.
How chance thou art returned so soon?	How is it that you’ve come back so soon?
Returned so soon?	Back so soon?
Rather approach’d too late!	Too late is more like it.
The capon burns; the pig falls from the spit; The clock hath strucken twelve upon the bell; My mistress made it one upon my cheek.	The chicken is burning, the pig is overcooked, the clock has already struck twelve, and my mistress has clocked me one on the cheek.
You say he dined at home; the goldsmith here Denies that saying.	ate at home, but the jeweler says he didn’t.
Sir, he dined with her there, at the Porpentine.	Sir, he ate with this woman at the Porcupine.
He did, and from my finger snatched that ring.	He did, and he snatched my ring right off my finger.
Tis true, my liege; this ring I had of her.	That’s true, my lord: I did get this ring from her.
Saw’st thou him enter at the abbey here?	Did you see him enter this abbey?
As sure, my liege, as I do see your Grace.	As clearly as I see you, my lord.
I think you are all mated or stark mad.	I think you’re all either bewildered or stark raving mad.
Most mighty duke, vouchsafe me speak a word.	Mighty duke, please allow me to say something.
Haply I see a friend will save my life And pay the sum that may deliver me.	I think I see a friend who will pay my bail and save my life.
Within this hour I was his bondman sir, But he, I thank him, gnawed in two my cords.	I was bound to him an hour ago, sir, but thankfully he chewed through our ropes.
Now am I Dromio, and his man, unbound.	Now I’m Dromio and no longer attached to him.
I am sure you both of you remember me.	I’m sure you both remember me.
You are not Pinch’s patient, are you, sir?	You’re not one of Pinch’s patients, are you, sir?
Why look you strange on me?	Why are you looking at me so strangely?
you know me well.	You know me well.
I never saw you in my life till now.	I never saw you before in my life.
O, grief hath changed me since you saw me last, And careful hours with time’s deformèd hand Have written strange defeatures in my face.	Oh, grief has transformed me since the last time you saw me.
But tell me yet, dost thou not know my voice?	But tell me this: don’t you know my voice?
Neither.	No.
Dromio, nor thou?	Don’t you, Dromio?
No, trust me, sir, nor I. I am sure thou dost.	No sir, trust me, I do not.
Not know my voice!	You don’t know my voice?
O time’s extremity, Hast thou so crack’d and splitted my poor tongue In seven short years that here my only son Knows not my feeble key of untuned cares?	Have you mangled my tongue so badly in these seven short years that my only son can no longer recognize my weak, sorrow-ravaged voice?
Though now this grainèd face of mine be hid In sap-consuming winter’s drizzled snow, And all the conduits of my blood froze up, Yet hath my night of life some memory, My wasting lamps some fading glimmer left, My dull deaf ears a little use to hear.	But I still have a little memory left, and there’s still some fire in my eyes; my dull, deaf ears can still hear a little.
All these old witnesses—I cannot err— Tell me thou art my son Antipholus.	All these aging faculties tell me—and I cannot be wrong—that you are my son, Antipholus.
I never saw my father in my life.	I never saw my father in my life.
But seven years since, in Syracusa, boy, Thou know’st we parted.	You know that we parted only seven years ago, in Syracuse.
I see thy age and dangers make thee dote.	Your old age and the prospect of death are making you imagine things.
Most mighty duke, behold a man much wronged.	Mighty duke, look here and see a man who’s been treated most terribly!
I see two husbands, or mine eyes deceive me.	Either my eyes deceive me, or I see two husbands.
I, sir, am Dromio.	I, sir, am Dromio.
Command him away.	Command this man to leave.
I, sir, am Dromio.	I, sir, am Dromio.
Please, let me stay.	Pray, let me stay.
O, my old master.—Who hath bound him here?	Oh, my old master!—Who tied him up?
Whoever bound him, I will loose his bonds And gain a husband by his liberty.— Speak, old Egeon, if thou be’st the man That hadst a wife once called Emilia, That bore thee at a burden two fair sons.	Tell us, old Egeon: are you the man who once had a wife named Emilia, who gave birth to two fair sons?
O, if thou be’st the same Egeon, speak, And speak unto the same Emilia.	Oh, if you are the same Egeon, speak now, and speak to that same Emilia!
Why, here begins his morning story right; These two Antipholuses, these two so like, And these two Dromios, one in semblance— Besides her urging of her wreck at sea— These are the parents to these children, Which accidentally are met together.	These two Antipholuses, who look so alike—and these two Dromios, who seem to have the same face—and her story of being shipwrecked—why, these two are the parents of these children and have been reunited by accident.
If I dream not, thou art Emilia.	If I’m not dreaming, you are Emilia.
If thou art she, tell me where is that son That floated with thee on the fatal raft?	If it’s really you, tell me what happened to our son, who floated away with you on that deadly raft.
Corinth first.	Antipholus, aren’t you originally from Corinth?
Stay, stand apart.	Wait, don’t stand next to each other.
I know not which is which.	I can’t tell who’s who.
I came from Corinth, my most gracious lord.	I came from Corinth, Your Highness.
And I with him.	And I came with him.
Brought to this town by that most famous warrior Duke Menaphon, your most renownèd uncle.	Your renowned uncle, Duke Menaphon, the famous soldier, brought me here.
Which of you two did dine with me today?	Which of you two ate lunch with me today?
I, gentle mistress.	I did, kind lady.
And are not you my husband?	And you’re my husband, right?
That is the chain, sir, which you had of me.	That’s the necklace I gave you, sir.
I think it be, sir.	I think it is, sir.
I deny it not.	I don’t deny it.
And you, sir, for this chain arrested me.	And you, sir, had me arrested over that necklace.
I think I did, sir.	I think I did, sir.
I deny it not.	I don’t deny it.
I sent you money, sir, to be your bail By Dromio, but I think he brought it not.	I sent Dromio to you with money for bail, but I don’t think he brought it to you.
No, none by me.	No, he didn’t get any by me.
This purse of ducats I received from you, And Dromio my man did bring them me.	I got this purse full of money from you, and my Dromio brought it to me.
These ducats pawn I for my father here.	I want to use this money to set my father free.
It shall not need.	That’s not necessary.
Thy father hath his life.	I’m going to let him live.
Sir, I must have that diamond from you.	Sir, I must get that diamond ring back from you.
There, take it; and much thanks for my good cheer.	There, take it, and thanks for taking such good care of me.
Renownèd duke, vouchsafe to take the pains To go with us into the abbey here And hear at large discoursed all our fortunes, And all that are assembled in this place That by this sympathizèd one day’s error Have suffered wrong.	Renowned duke, please join us in the abbey, where we will discuss at length all that has happened to us.
Go, keep us company, And we shall make full satisfaction.— Thirty-three years have I but gone in travail Of you, my sons, and till this present hour My heavy burden ne'er deliverèd.— The Duke, my husband, and my children both, And you, the calendars of their nativity, Go to a gossips' feast, and go with me.	Duke Solinus, my husband, and both my children—and you two Dromios, who marked the day of my sons' births with your own—come into the abbey with me for a new christening.
After so long grief, such nativity!	After such a long period of grief, we will have such a celebration!
With all my heart I’ll gossip at this feast.	With all my heart, I’ll join you.
Dromio, what stuff of mine hast thou embarked?	Dromio, what stuff of mine did you put on a ship?
Your goods that lay at host, sir, in the Centaur.	The stuff you had at the Centaur, sir.
He speaks to me.—I am your master, Dromio.	I’m your master, Dromio.
There is a fat friend at your master’s house That kitchened me for you today at dinner.	You have a fat friend at your master’s house: she took care of me in the kitchen today, thinking I was you.
She now shall be my sister, not my wife.	I guess now she’s going to be my sister-in-law and not my wife.
Methinks you are my glass, and not my brother: I see by you I am a sweet-faced youth.	I think you’re my mirror, not my brother.
Will you walk in to see their gossiping?	Do you want to go in and join the party?
Not I, sir.	After you, sir.
You are my elder.	You’re older than me.
That’s a question.	That’s a good point.
How shall we try it?	How can we tell which of us is the oldest?
We’ll draw cuts for the signior.	We’ll draw straws.
Till then, lead thou first.	Meanwhile, after you.
Nay, then, thus: We came into the world like brother and brother, And now let’s go hand in hand, not one before another.	We came into the world as brother and brother, so now let’s enter hand in hand—not one before the other.
Stop in your wind, sir.	Hold on a second.
Tell me this, I pray: Where have you left the money that I gave you?	Answer me this, please: where’s the money I gave you?
O, sixpence, that I had o' Wednesday last To pay the saddler for my mistress' crupper?	Oh, the sixpence you gave me last Wednesday to buy leather goods for my mistress?
The saddler had it, sir; I kept it not.	The saddle maker has it, sir—I didn’t keep it.
I am not in a sportive humor now.	I’m not in a joking mood.
Tell me, and dally not: where is the money?	Tell me right now and stop fooling: where’s the money?
We being strangers here, how dar’st thou trust So great a charge from thine own custody?	We’re strangers here.
I pray you, jest, sir, as you sit at dinner.	Please, sir; crack jokes over lunch.
Methinks your maw, like mine, should be your clock, And strike you home without a messenger.	I should think that your appetite would act like a clock (as mine does) and bring you home on its own, without the need for a messenger.
Come, Dromio, come, these jests are out of season.	That’s enough, Dromio, please.
Reserve them till a merrier hour than this.	This isn’t a good moment for jokes—save them till a happier time.
Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee?	Where’s the gold I gave you?
To me, sir?	Gave me, sir?
Why, you gave no gold to me!	You didn’t give me any gold.
Come on, sir knave, have done your foolishness, And tell me how thou hast disposed thy charge.	Tell me what you’ve done with the money I entrusted to you.
My charge was but to fetch you from the mart Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner.	The only thing that I’ve been entrusted with was getting you from the market and bringing you to your house, the Phoenix, for lunch.
My mistress and her sister stays for you.	My mistress and her sister are waiting for you.
Now, as I am a Christian, answer me In what safe place you have bestowed my money, Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours That stands on tricks when I am undisposed.	Tell me where you’ve stowed away my money, or I swear I’ll break that comical head of yours for goofing when I’m not in the mood.
Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me?	Where are the thousand
Thy mistress' marks?	Your mistress’s marks?
what mistress, slave, hast thou?	What mistress do you have?
What, wilt thou flout me thus unto my face, Being forbid?	What, are you going to mock me to my face when I told you not to?
There, take you that, sir knave.	There, take that, you scoundrel!
What mean you, sir?	What are you doing?
For God’s sake, hold your hands.	Stop, for God’s sake!
Nay, an you will not, sir, I’ll take my heels.	Well, if you don’t, then I’m out of here.
Upon my life, by some device or other The villain is o'erraught of all my money.	I swear, somehow the fool has been cheated out of all my money.
They say this town is full of cozenage, As nimble jugglers that deceive the eye, Dark-working sorcerers that change the mind, Soul-killing witches that deform the body, Disguised cheaters, prating mountebanks, And many suchlike liberties of sin.	They say that this town is full of deception—illusionists that can fool the eye, dark sorcerers who can bewitch your mind, soul-killing witches who can disfigure your body, disguised swindlers, fast-talking fakers, and all kinds of other unchecked sins.
Neither my husband nor the slave returned That in such haste I sent to seek his master?	Neither my husband nor the slave has returned, even though I sent the slave off running.
Sure, Luciana, it is two o'clock.	Surely, Luciana, it’s already two o'clock.
Perhaps some merchant hath invited him, And from the mart he’s somewhere gone to dinner.	Maybe some merchant at the marketplace invited him home for lunch.
Good sister, let us dine and never fret.	Sister, let’s eat and stop worrying.
A man is master of his liberty; Time is their master, and when they see time They’ll go or come.	A man is master of his own freedom: time is his only master, and when the right moment comes along, he’ll come or go as he pleases.
If so, be patient, sister.	If this is so, be patient, sister.
Why should their liberty than ours be more?	Why should men be more free than women?
Because their business still lies out o' door.	Because their business lies outside the home.
Why, headstrong liberty is lashed with woe.	Why, too much freedom leads to woe.
Then let your will attend on their accords.	Therefore, you should obey their wishes.
This servitude makes you to keep unwed.	It’s this servantlike mentality that’s keeping you unmarried.
Not this, but troubles of the marriage bed.	No, that’s not it—it’s because of what happens in the marriage bed.
But, were you wedded, you would bear some sway.	But if you were married, you’d wield some influence.
Ere I learn love, I’ll practice to obey.	Before I learn how to love, I’ll learn how to follow orders.
How if your husband start some otherwhere?	What if your husband strays elsewhere?
Till he come home again, I would forbear.	I’d endure it until he came home again.
Patience unmoved!	Now that’s patience!
No marvel though she pause; They can be meek that have no other cause.	No wonder she’s waiting to get married.
A wretched soul, bruised with adversity We bid be quiet when we hear it cry, But were we burdened with like weight of pain, As much or more we should ourselves complain.	When we’re faced with a wretched person, bruised and crying with hardship, we try to get them to shush up.
So thou, that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee, With urging helpless patience would relieve me; But, if thou live to see like right bereft, This fool-begged patience in thee will be left.	But if you live to see yourself similarly denied your rights, this foolish patience will abandon you.
Well, I will marry one day, but to try.	Well, I’ll get married one day, just to see.
Say, is your tardy master now at hand?	Tell me, is your tardy master close at hand?
Know’st thou his mind?	Do you know his plans?
But say, I prithee, is he coming home?	But please, tell me: is he coming home?
It seems he hath great care to please his wife.	It seems he has taken great care to please his wife.
Why, mistress, sure my master is horn mad.	Why, mistress, my master is as angry as a bull with horns.
Horn mad, thou villain!	You bastard!
I mean not cuckold mad, But sure he is stark mad.	I don’t mean he’s
My mistress, sir,” quoth I.	My mistress,” I said.
Hang up thy mistress!	Damn your mistress!
Quoth my master.	My master said it.
I know,” quoth he, “no house, no wife, no mistress.” So that my errand, due unto my tongue, I thank him, I bare home upon my shoulders, For, in conclusion, he did beat me there.	I don’t know,” he said, “any house, wife, or mistress.” My message, which was supposed to be delivered with my mouth, ended up being carried back home by my shoulders.
Go back again, thou slave, and fetch him home.	Go back again, slave, and bring him home.
Go back again and be new beaten home?	Go back again, to be beaten home again?
For God’s sake, send some other messenger.	For God’s sake, send somebody else.
Back, slave, or I will break thy pate across.	Go back, slave, or I’ll knock you one across the head.
Hence, prating peasant!	Get out of here, you blathering peasant!
Fetch thy master home.	Bring your master home.
You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither.	You kick me out, he kicks me back.
If I last in this service, you must case me in leather.	Look at you!
Fie, how impatience loureth in your face.	You have impatience all over your face.
His company must do his minions grace, Whilst I at home starve for a merry look.	He feels the need to grace all his other tramps with his presence while I sit at home starving for a smile from him.
Hath homely age th' alluring beauty took From my poor cheek?	Has homely old age taken the alluring beauty from my poor cheeks?
Barren my wit?	Have I lost my wit?
My decayèd fair A sunny look of his would soon repair.	One smile from him would repair my decayed beauty.
But, too unruly deer, he breaks the pale And feeds from home.	But like an unruly deer, he’s always trespassing past the park borders and straying away from home to feed in new pastures.
Poor I am but his stale.	I am nothing but a poor, used fool.
Self-harming jealousy, fie, beat it hence.	Drive it out of you.
I know his eye doth homage otherwhere, Or else what lets it but he would be here?	I know his eyes are worshiping some other woman, or why wouldn’t he be here?
Sister, you know he promised me a chain.	Sister, you know he promised to give me a necklace.
Would that alone o' love he would detain, So he would keep fair quarter with his bed.	I would gladly do without that if he would only stay faithful to me.
I see the jewel best enamelèd Will lose his beauty.	Even the best jewel can be tarnished.
Yet the gold bides still That others touch, and often touching will Wear gold; yet no man that hath a name By falsehood and corruption doth it shame.	And no man with a reputation will tarnish that name with lies and bad behavior.
Since that my beauty cannot please his eye, I’ll weep what’s left away, and weeping die.	Since my beauty no longer pleases my husband, I’ll weep away what’s left and then die with weeping.
How many fond fools serve mad jealousy!	How many infatuated people go mad with jealousy!
Proceed, Solinus, to procure my fall, And by the doom of death end woes and all.	Give me the death sentence and end all my troubles.
For, since the mortal and intestine jars 'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us, It hath in solemn synods been decreed Both by the Syracusians and ourselves, To admit no traffic to our adverse towns.	Ever since these deadly conflicts erupted between your violent countrymen and ours, both you Syracusians and we Ephesians have held serious councils and decided not to permit any travel between our two hostile towns.
Nay, more, if any born at Ephesus Be seen at any Syracusian marts and fairs; Again, if any Syracusian born Come to the bay of Ephesus, he dies, His goods confiscate to the Duke’s dispose, Unless a thousand marks be levièd To quit the penalty and to ransom him.	No–the law goes further: if anyone born in Ephesus is seen in Syracuse’s marketplaces or if anyone born in Syracuse comes to Ephesus, that man dies, and his possessions will be confiscated by the Duke, unless he can raise a thousand marks to pay the penalty and ransom himself.
Thy substance, valued at the highest rate, Cannot amount unto a hundred marks; Therefore by law thou art condemned to die.	Therefore, by law, you are condemned to die.
The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up Safe at the Centaur, and the heedful slave Is wandered forth, in care to seek me out.	The gold I gave Dromio is safe and sound at the Centaur, and the inn host says that Dromio has left and is looking for me.
By computation and mine host’s report, I could not speak with Dromio since at first I sent him from the mart.	I haven’t spoken to him since I sent him away from the marketplace earlier.
See, here he comes.	Here he comes.
How now, sir?	So, sir.
is your merry humor altered?	Are you over your ridiculous mood?
You know no Centaur?	You never heard of the Centaur?
You received no gold?	You weren’t given any gold?
Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner?	Your mistress sent for me to come to dinner?
My house was at the Phoenix?	The Phoenix is my house?
Wast thou mad, That thus so madly thou didst answer me?	Were you mad when you spoke to me so madly?
What answer, sir?	Said what, sir?
When spake I such a word?	When did I say all that?
I did not see you since you sent me hence, Home to the Centaur with the gold you gave me.	I haven’t seen you since you sent me to the Centaur with the gold you gave me.
Villain, thou didst deny the gold’s receipt And told’st me of a mistress and a dinner, For which, I hope, thou felt’st I was displeased.	And I hope you realized I wasn’t very happy about it.
I am glad to see you in this merry vein.	I’m glad to see you in such a merry mood.
What means this jest?	But what’s the joke?
I pray you, master, tell me?	Please, master, tell me.
Yea, dost thou jeer and flout me in the teeth?	What, are you mocking me to my face?
Think’st thou I jest?	Here.
Hold, take thou that and that.	Take that, and that!
Hold, sir, for God’s sake!	Stop, sir, for God’s sake!
Now your jest is earnest.	Now this joke has turned serious.
Upon what bargain do you give it me?	Why are you doing this?
Because that I familiarly sometimes Do use you for my fool and chat with you, Your sauciness will jest upon my love And make a common of my serious hours.	Just because I act familiar with you sometimes and let you fool around and joke with me, you try to take advantage of my affection.
Sconce” call you it?	You call it my “ Don’t you know?
Shall I tell you why?	Should I tell you why?
Well, sir, I thank you.	Well, thank you.
Marry, sir, for this something that you gave me for nothing.	Because you gave me something for nothing.
I’ll make you amends next, to give you nothing for something.	Next time I’ll give you nothing for something.
But say, sir, is it dinnertime?	Is it lunchtime?
In good time, sir, what’s that?	What would that be?
Basting.	A basting.
Well, sir, then ’twill be dry.	Well, then it will be dry.
If it be, sir, I pray you, eat none of it.	If it is, I suggest you don’t eat it.
Your reason?	Why not?
Lest it make you choleric and purchase me another dry basting.	Because it will make you angry, and that will get me another beating.
Well, sir, learn to jest in good time.	Well, learn to make jokes at the appropriate time.
There’s a time for all things.	There’s a time for all things.
I durst have denied that before you were so choleric.	Before you got so angry, I never would have thought that.
By what rule, sir?	Why not?
Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the plain bald pate of Father Time himself.	I’ll tell you: it’s because of a law as plain as Father Time’s bald head.
Let’s hear it.	Let’s hear it.
There’s no time for a man to recover his hair that grows bald by nature.	There may be a time for everything, but no man who has gone bald naturally can get his hair back.
Why is Time such a niggard of hair, being, as it is, so plentiful an excrement?	Why is Time so cheap about giving out hair?
Why, but there’s many a man hath more hair than wit.	But a lot of men have more hair than intelligence.
Why, thou didst conclude hairy men plain dealers without wit.	So then, you must think that hairy men are honest and simpleminded.
For what reason?	Two reasons.
For two, and sound ones too.	And good ones, too.
Nay, not sound, I pray you.	Not good ones, please.
Sure ones, then.	Then sure ones.
Nay, not sure, in a thing falsing.	No, not sure ones when we’re talking about something unsure.
Certain ones, then.	Then certain ones.
Name them.	Name them.
The one, to save the money that he spends in tiring; the other, that at dinner they should not drop in his porridge.	One, so they can save the money they spent on hairstyling, and two, so that when their hair falls out it doesn’t land in their dinner.
You would all this time have proved there is no time for all things.	You were supposed to be proving that there isn’t time for everything.
Thus I mend it: Time himself is bald and therefore, to the world’s end, will have bald followers.	Then I’ll change it to this: Father Time himself is bald, so for all time there will be bald men.
The time was once when thou unurged wouldst vow That never words were music to thine ear, That never object pleasing in thine eye, That never touch well welcome to thy hand, That never meat sweet-savored in thy taste, Unless I spake, or looked, or touched, or carved to thee.	There was a time when you’d freely tell me that words were never music to your ear unless I said them, that objects never pleased your eye unless I showed them to you, that touches never pleased your hands unless they were my touches, and that food never tasted sweet to you unless I had prepared it.
How comes it now, my husband, O, how comes it That thou art thus estranged from thyself?	How is it, my husband—oh, how is it—that you have become a stranger to yourself?
Ah, do not tear away thyself from me!	Ah, don’t tear yourself away from me!
I know you not.	I don’t know you.
When were you wont to use my sister thus?	Why are you treating my sister like this?
She sent for you by Dromio home to dinner.	She sent Dromio to bring you home for lunch.
By Dromio?	Dromio?
By thee; and this thou didst return from him: That he did buffet thee and, in his blows, Denied my house for his, me for his wife.	And this is what you told me he said: that he beat you and pretended his house wasn’t his and I wasn’t his wife.
Did you converse, sir, with this gentlewoman?	Did you talk with this woman?
What is the course and drift of your compact?	What kind of scheme do you have going together?
I, sir?	Me, sir?
I never saw her till this time.	I never saw her till now.
Villain, thou liest; for even her very words Didst thou deliver to me on the mart.	You said those exact things to me back in the marketplace.
I never spake with her in all my life.	I never talked with her in my life.
What, was I married to her in my dream?	What, was I married to her in a dream?
Or sleep I now and think I hear all this?	Or am I asleep now and imagining all this?
What error drives our eyes and ears amiss?	What is making our eyes and ears act so strangely?
Until I know this sure uncertainty I’ll entertain the offered fallacy.	Until I know for sure, I’ll humor her.
Dromio, go bid the servants spread for dinner.	Dromio, tell the servants to prepare for lunch.
O, for my beads!	Oh, I wish I had my rosary!
I cross me for a sinner.	I’ll cross myself.
This is the fairy land.	This must be some kind of fairyland.
O spite of spites!	Oh, spite of spites!
We talk with goblins, owls, and sprites: If we obey them not, this will ensue: They’ll suck our breath, or pinch us black and blue.	If we don’t obey them, they’ll suck the life out of us or pinch us black and blue.
Why prat’st thou to thyself and answer’st not?	Why are you mumbling to yourself instead of answering the order I gave you?
Dromio—thou, Dromio—thou snail, thou slug, thou sot.	Dromio, you drone, you snail, you slug, you idiot!
I am transformèd, master, am I not?	I’ve been transformed somehow, haven’t I, master?
I think thou art in mind, and so am I. Nay, master, both in mind and in my shape.	No, master, I’ve been changed in both mind and body.
Tis true.	That’s true.
I am an ass; else it could never be But I should know her as well as she knows me.	I must be as stupid as an ass—that’s why I don’t know her, but she knows me.
Come, come, no longer will I be a fool, To put the finger in the eye and weep Whilst man and master laugh my woes to scorn.	I won’t play the fool anymore and just cry while my husband and his man laugh at me.
Come, sir, to dinner.—Dromio, keep the gate.	Come, husband, let’s go to lunch.
Husband, I’ll dine above with you today, And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks.	Husband, I’ll eat with you in private today and hear your confession about all the pranks you’ve pulled.
Am I in earth, in heaven, or in hell?	Am I on earth, in heaven, or in hell?
Known unto these, and to myself disguised!	know myself!
Master, shall I be porter at the gate?	Master, should I watch the door?
Ay; and let none enter, lest I break your pate.	Yes, and don’t let anyone come in, or else I’ll break your head.
Well, Syracusian, say in brief the cause Why thou dep-artedst from thy native home And for what cause thou camest to Ephesus.	Well, Syracusian, tell us–briefly–why you left your hometown and came to Ephesus.
In Syracusa was I born, and wed Unto a woman happy but for me, And by me, had not our hap been bad.	And yet I would have made her happy had our luck not been so bad.
That very hour, and in the selfsame inn, A meaner woman was deliverèd Of such a burden, male twins, both alike.	In the same hour, and in the same inn, a poor woman also delivered identical twin boys.
Unwilling, I agreed.	Reluctantly, I agreed–alas!
Alas, too soon We came aboard.	Too quickly, we boarded a ship.
Good Signior Angelo, you must excuse us all; My wife is shrewish when I keep not hours.	Signior Angelo, please excuse us.
Say that I lingered with you at your shop To see the making of her carcanet, And that tomorrow you will bring it home.	Here’s the story we’ll tell her: that I was with you at your shop, watching you make her necklace, and that you’re going to deliver it tomorrow.
But here’s a villain that would face me down He met me on the mart, and that I beat him And charged him with a thousand marks in gold, And that I did deny my wife and house.— Thou drunkard, thou, what didst thou mean by this?	But here comes a scoundrel who says he saw me at the marketplace and that I beat on him, told him I’d given him a thousand marks in gold, and then lied about my wife and my house.
Say what you will, sir, but I know what I know.	Say what you want, but I know what I know.
I think thou art an ass.	I think you’re an ass.
You’re sad, Signior Balthasar.	Signior Balthasar, you look upset.
I hold your dainties cheap, sir, and your welcome dear.	Your delicacies aren’t worth as much to me as your welcome is.
Good meat, sir, is common; that every churl affords.	Good food’s not a big deal—everyone can afford that.
And welcome more common, for that’s nothing but words.	And everyone can say “welcome,” which is just a word.
Small cheer and great welcome makes a merry feast.	A little food and a huge welcome makes a joyous feast.
Ay, to a niggardly host and more sparing guest.	Sure, to a cheap host and an even cheaper guest.
But though my cates be mean, take them in good part.	But look, even if my dishes are poor, eat them with my best wishes.
Better cheer may you have, but not with better heart.	You may come across better food, but not a warmer welcome.
But soft!	What’s this?
My door is lock’d.	My door is locked.
Maud, Bridget, Marian, Ciceley, Gillian, Ginn!	Maud, Bridget, Marian, Ciceley, Gillian, Ginn!
My master stays in the street.	My master is standing out in the street!
Who talks within there?	Who’s in there?
Ho, open the door.	Hey, open the door!
Wherefore?	A reason?
For my dinner.	So I can eat lunch.
I have not dined today.	I haven’t eaten today.
What art thou that keep’st me out from the house I owe?	Who do you think you are, keeping me out of my own house?
O villain, thou hast stolen both mine office and my name!	You’ve stolen both my job and my name!
O Lord, I must laugh.	Oh, Lord, this makes me laugh!
Have at you with a proverb: shall I set in my staff?	I’ll come at you with the old proverb: “Should I make myself at home?”
Do you hear, you minion?	Listen up, you slave.
You’ll let us in, I hope?	Are you going to let us in?
So, come, help.	Come, help me bang on the door, master.
Well struck!	Well done!
There was blow for blow.	We answered them, blow for blow.
Thou baggage, let me in.	You good-for-nothing, let me in.
Master, knock the door hard.	Master, knock hard upon the door.
You’ll cry for this, minion, if I beat the door down.	If I break the door down, slave, you’ll be sorry for this.
Are you there, wife?	Is that you, wife?
You might have come before.	You could have come sooner.
If you went in pain, master, this knave would go sore.	If she punishes you, master, she’s sure to punish me.
In debating which was best, we shall part with neither.	We argued about which was best, and now we won’t get either one.
You would say so, master, if your garments were thin.	And if your clothes were as thin as mine, you’d really feel the air.
Your cake there is warm within; you stand here in the cold.	The food inside is warm, but you’re out here freezing.
It would make a man mad as a buck to be so bought and sold.	It would make any man as mad as a bull to be betrayed like this.
Go, fetch me something: I’ll break ope the gate.	Go get me something I can use to break down the door.
Here’s too much “out upon thee!” I pray thee, let me in.	I’ve had enough of this “off with you!” Come on, let me in!
Well, I’ll break in.	Well, I’m going to break in.
Go, borrow me a crow.	Go get me a crow.
A crow without feather?	A crow without feathers?
Master, mean you so?	Master, do you really mean that?
For a fish without a fin, there’s a fowl without a feather.—   Go, get thee gone.	I meant a crowbar.
Fetch me an iron crow.	Get going already.
Have patience, sir.	Be patient, sir!
O, let it not be so.	Don’t do this!
And doubt not, sir, but she will well excuse Why at this time the doors are made against you.	All this suggests that she has a good reason for doing this to you.
Be ruled by me; depart in patience, And let us to the Tiger all to dinner, And about evening come yourself alone To know the reason of this strange restraint.	Let’s assume that she has a reason, which you don’t know yet: have faith that she’ll eventually explain why she shut the doors on you today.
You have prevailed.	You’re right—I’ll go quietly.
I will depart in quiet And, in despite of mirth, mean to be merry.	And even though I’m in a distasteful mood, I’ll work on being happy.
I know a wench of excellent discourse, Pretty and witty, wild and yet, too, gentle.	I know a terrific wench.
There will we dine.	We’ll eat at her place.
That chain will I bestow— Be it for nothing but to spite my wife— Upon mine hostess there.	I swear to her that I haven’t, but it doesn’t change anything.
I’ll meet you at that place some hour hence.	I’ll meet you there in an hour.
Do so.	Do that.
This jest shall cost me some expense.	This little prank of hers is going to cost me.
Shall, Antipholus, Even in the spring of love thy love-springs rot?	Is the building of your love already in ruins?
If you did wed my sister for her wealth, Then for her wealth’s sake use her with more kindness.	If you married my sister for her wealth, then for her wealth’s sake, treat her with more kindness.
What simple thief brags of his own attaint?	What foolish thief brags about his crimes?
Tis double wrong to truant with your bed And let her read it in thy looks at board.	It’s doubly wrong to cheat on your wife and then let her see the offense in your eyes.
Though others have the arm, show us the sleeve; We in your motion turn, and you may move us.	We follow in your orbit, and you have the power to move us.
Then, gentle brother, get you in again.	So, my sweet brother-in-law, go inside.
Sweet mistress—what your name is else I know not, Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine,—	Sweet mistress—I don’t know what other name to give you, or how you’ve figured out mine—you seem as
Less in your knowledge and your grace you show not Than our earth’s wonder, more than earth divine.	wise and graceful as the earth is wonderful and divine.
Teach me, dear creature, how to think and speak.	Teach me how I should think and speak.
Against my soul’s pure truth why labour you To make it wander in an unknown field?	Why would you have me betray the truth of my emotions and make my love wander in some other direction?
Are you a god?	Are you a god?
would you create me new?	Are you trying to remake me?
Transform me, then, and to your power I’ll yield.	Go ahead, I’ll yield to your power.
But if that I am I, then well I know Your weeping sister is no wife of mine, Nor to her bed no homage do I owe.	But if I am myself, then I know for sure that your weeping sister is not my wife.
Far more, far more, to you do I decline.	I don’t owe her any duty—it’s you that I submit to.
O, train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note To drown me in thy sister’s flood of tears.	Oh, sweet mermaid, don’t command me to drown myself in the flood of your sister’s tears.
What, are you mad that you do reason so?	Are you insane, talking like this?
It is a fault that springeth from your eye.	Your eyes are playing tricks on you.
For gazing on your beams, fair sun, being by.	That’s because you are near me, and you’re as dazzling as the sun.
Why call you me “love”?	Why are you calling me “love”?
Call my sister so.	Call my sister that.
Thy sister’s sister.	Your sister’s sister.
That’s my sister.	That’s my sister.
No, It is thyself, mine own self’s better part, Mine eye’s clear eye, my dear heart’s dearer heart, My food, my fortune, and my sweet hope’s aim, My sole earth’s heaven, and my heaven’s claim.	My food, my fortune, my sweetest hope, my heaven on earth, and my entrance to heaven.
All this my sister is, or else should be.	My sister is all those things, or else she should be.
Call thyself “sister,” sweet, for I am thee.	Call yourself your own sister, because I want you.
Give me thy hand.	Give me your hand.
O soft, sir!	Oh, wait, sir.
Hold you still.	Stay here.
I’ll fetch my sister to get her goodwill.	I’ll go get my sister and see what she thinks.
Why, how now, Dromio.	What’s going on, Dromio?

Do you know me, sir?	Do you know me?
Am I Dromio?	Am I Dromio?
Am I your man?	Am I your servant?
Am I myself?	Am I myself?
The children thus disposed, my wife and I, Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fixed, Fastened ourselves at either end the mast And, floating straight, obedient to the stream, Was carried towards Corinth, as we thought.	It carried us toward Corinth–or so we thought.
But ere they came,–O, let me say no more!	But before they reached us–let me say no more!
Thou art Dromio, thou art my man, thou art thyself.	You are Dromio, you are my servant, and you are yourself.
I am an ass, I am a woman’s man, and besides myself.	I’m an ass, I’m a woman’s servant, and I’m beside myself.
What woman’s man?	What woman’s servant?
And how besides thyself?	What do you mean, beside yourself?

What is she?	I don’t mean that she wants me because  What’s she like?
Marry, sir, she’s the kitchen wench, and all grease, and I know not what use to put her to but to make a lamp of her and run from her by her own light.	The only thing I could do with her is to use all that oil as fuel in a lamp and then use that light to run away by.
I warrant her rags and the	Her
If she lives till doomsday, she’ll burn a week longer than the whole world.	Even if she lives till the end of the world, she’d keep burning an additional week.
What complexion is she of?	What’s her skin like?
Swart like my shoe, but her face nothing like so clean kept.	It’s dark, like my shoe.
That’s a fault that water will mend.	Some water will fix that.
No, sir, ’tis in grain; Noah’s flood could not do it.	No, it’s permanent.
What’s her name?	What’s her name?
Then she bears some breadth?	Nell.
She is spherical, like a globe.	She’s round, like a globe.
In what part of her body stands Ireland?	What part of her body is Ireland?
Marry, sir, in her buttocks.	Her bottom.
Faith, I saw it not, but I felt it hot in her breath.	Honestly, I didn’t see it, but I felt it in her hot breath.
Where America, the Indies?	Where’s America and the West Indies?
O, sir, upon her nose, all o'er-embellished with rubies, carbuncles, sapphires, declining their rich aspect to the hot breath of Spain, who sent whole armadas of caracks to be ballast at her nose.	Oh, sir, on her nose, which is covered with pimples, sores, and red welts.
And, I think, if my breast had not been made of faith, and my heart of steel, She had transformed me to a curtal dog and made me turn i' th' wheel.	And I think that if I hadn’t been brave and strong, she would have turned me into a dog and made me her slave.
An if the wind blow any way from shore, I will not harbor in this town tonight.	If there’s enough wind for a ship to sail out tonight, I won’t spend tonight in this town.
If any bark put forth, come to the mart, Where I will walk till thou return to me.	If a ship’s leaving, come to the marketplace.
If every one knows us, and we know none, 'Tis time, I think, to trudge, pack, and be gone.	If everyone here knows us but we don’t know anybody, it’s time, I think, for us to pack our bags and take off.
As from a bear a man would run for life, So fly I from her that would be my wife.	I’ll run from this woman who claims to be my wife as fast as I’d run from a bear.
There’s none but witches do inhabit here, And therefore ’tis high time that I were hence.	That means it’s high time for me to go.
She that doth call me husband, even my soul Doth for a wife abhor.	That woman who claims I am her husband—I loathe her in my soul.
But lest myself be guilty to self wrong, I’ll stop mine ears against the mermaid’s song.	I’d better stop up my ears against this siren’s song.
I know it well, sir.	I know that, sir.

Well, sir, I will.	All right, sir, I will.

Why then, your ambition makes it one.	That must be because you’re so ambitious.

A dream itself is but a shadow.	But a dream itself is just a shadow.
Truly, and I hold ambition of so airy and light a quality that it is but a shadow’s shadow.	In fact, I consider ambition to be so light and airy that it’s only the shadow of a shadow.

How comes it?	Why?

These are now the fashion, and so berattle the common stages—so they call them—that many wearing rapiers are afraid of goose quills and dare scarce come thither.	These child actors are now in fashion, and they’ve so overtaken the public theaters that society types hardly come at all, they’re so afraid of being mocked by the playwrights who write for the boys.
What, are they children?	What, you mean kid actors?
Who maintains 'em?	Who takes care of them?
How are they escoted?	Who pays their way?
Will they pursue the quality no longer than they can sing?	Will they stop working when their voices mature?
Will they not say afterwards, if they should grow themselves to common players (as it is most like if their means are no better), their writers do them wrong to make them exclaim against their own succession?	Aren’t the playwrights hurting them by making them upstage adult actors, which they are going to grow up and become?
Faith, there has been much to do on both sides, and the nation holds it no sin to tar them to controversy.	There’s been a whole debate on the topic.

Is ’t possible?	Are you kidding?

For who would bear the whips and scorns of time, Th' oppressor’s wrong, the proud man’s contumely, The pangs of despised love, the law’s delay, The insolence of office, and the spurns That patient merit of th' unworthy takes, When he himself might his quietus make With a bare bodkin?	After all, who would put up with all life’s humiliations—the abuse from superiors, the insults of arrogant men, the pangs of unrequited love, the inefficiency of the legal system, the rudeness of people in office, and the mistreatment good people have to take from bad—when you could simply take out your knife and call it quits?
Who would fardels bear, To grunt and sweat under a weary life, But that the dread of something after death, The undiscovered country from whose bourn No traveler returns, puzzles the will And makes us rather bear those ills we have Than fly to others that we know not of?	Who would choose to grunt and sweat through an exhausting life, unless they were afraid of something dreadful after death, the undiscovered country from which no visitor returns, which we wonder about without getting any answers from and which makes us stick to the evils we know rather than rush off to seek the ones we don’t?

In the corrupted currents of this world Offense’s gilded hand may shove by justice, And oft ’tis seen the wicked prize itself Buys out the law.	In this wicked world, criminals often take the money they stole and use it to buy off the law, shoving justice aside.
But ’tis not so above.	But not in heaven.
What can it not?	What is there left to do?

The king, sir, hath wagered with him six Barbary horses, against the which he has impawned, as I take it, six French rapiers and poniards with their assigns—as girdle, hangers, and so.	The king has bet six Barbary horses, and he has prepared six French rapiers and daggers with all their accessories.
Three of the carriages, in faith, are very dear to fancy, very responsive to the hilts, most delicate carriages, and of very liberal conceit.	Three of the carriages are very imaginatively designed, and they match the fencing accessories.
What call you the carriages?	What do you mean by “carriages”?
The carriages, sir, are the hangers.	The carriages, sir, are the hangers—where the swords hang.
The phrase would be more germane to the matter if we could carry cannon by our sides.	Carriage” makes it sound like it’s pulling around a cannon.
I would it might be hangers till then.	I prefer to call it a “hanger.” But anyway.
But, on: six Barbary horses against six French swords, their assigns, and three liberal-conceited carriages—that’s the French bet against the Danish.	Six Barbary horses, six French swords with accessories, and three imaginatively designed carriages—sounds like a French bet against the Danish.
Why is this “impawned,” as you call it?	Why has all this been put on the table?

How if I answer “No”?	But what if my answer’s no?

Yours, yours.	Thank you.
He does well to commend it himself.	It’s a good thing he’s here to recommend himself.

He did comply, sir, with his dug before he sucked it.	He used to praise his mother’s nipple before he sucked it.

I am constant to my purpose.	I’ll do whatever the king wants.
They follow the king’s pleasure.	If he’s ready now, so am I.
If his fitness speaks, mine is ready, now or whensoever, provided I be so able as now.	Otherwise, I’ll do it anytime, as long as I’m able.
The king and queen and all are coming down.	The king and queen are coming down with everyone else.
In happy time.	Right on cue.

She well instructs me.	She’s full of good advice.

I do not think so.	I don’t think so.

But it is no matter.	Oh well.
I will forestall their repair hither and say you are not fit.	I’ll say you’re not feeling well.
Not a whit.	You’ll do no such thing.
We defy augury.	I thumb my nose at superstitions.
If it be not to come, it will be now.	What’s important is to be prepared.
Since no man of aught he leaves knows, what is ’t to leave betimes?	Since nobody knows anything about what he leaves behind, then what does it mean to leave early?
Let be.	Let it be.
Come, Hamlet, come, and take this hand from me.	Come shake hands with Laertes, Hamlet.
But in my terms of honor I stand aloof, and will no reconcilement Till by some elder masters, of known honor, I have a voice and precedent of peace To keep my name ungored.	I will accept no apology until experts in matters of honor show me how to make peace with you without staining my own reputation in doing so.
Come, one for me.	Yes, hand me one too.
I’ll be your foil, Laertes.	I’m going to make you look sharp, Laertes.
You mock me, sir.	You’re making fun of me.
No, by this hand.	No, I swear I’m not.
Very well, my lord.	Yes, my lord, quite well.
Your grace hath laid the odds o' th' weaker side.	You’ve bet on the weaker fencer.
I have seen you both.	I’ve seen both of you fence.
But since he is better we have therefore odds.	But since Laertes is better, we’ve given him a handicap.
Ay, my good lord.	Yes, my lord.
Set me the stoups of wine upon that table.	Put the goblets of wine on that table.
If Hamlet give the first or second hit Or quit in answer of the third exchange, Let all the battlements their ordnance fire!	If Hamlet makes the first or second hit, or gets back at Laertes by making the third hit, then let my soldiers give him a military salute.
The king shall drink to Hamlet’s better breath, And in the cup an union shall he throw Richer than that which four successive kings In Denmark’s crown have worn.	I’ll drink to Hamlet’s health, and into his goblet I’ll drop a pearl even more costly than those in the crowns of the last four Danish kings.

In thee there is not half an hour of life.	You don’t have more than half an hour to live.

I can no more.	I can’t speak anymore.

Season your admiration for a while With an attent ear, till I may deliver, Upon the witness of these gentlemen, This marvel to you.	Just listen carefully while I tell you the amazing thing I saw, with these gentlemen as witnesses.
For God’s love, let me hear.	For God’s sake, let me hear it.
Two nights together had these gentlemen, Marcellus and Barnardo, on their watch, In the dead waste and middle of the night, Been thus encountered: a figure like your father, Armed at point exactly, cap-à-pie, Appears before them and with solemn march Goes slow and stately by them.	After midnight, for two nights running, these two guards, Marcellus and Barnardo, saw a figure that looked very much like your father, in full armor from head to toe.
Thrice he walked By their oppressed and fear-surprisèd eyes Within his truncheon’s length, whilst they, distilled Almost to jelly with the act of fear, Stand dumb and speak not to him.	It just appeared before them and marched past them with slow dignity three times, a staff’s distance from their amazed eyes, while they turned, quaking with fear and too shocked to speak.
I knew your father.	I knew your father.

Thou livest.	You’re alive.

What warlike noise is this?	What are these warlike noises?
Young Fortinbras, with conquest come from Poland, To th' ambassadors of England gives This warlike volley.	Young Fortinbras, returning in triumph from Poland, is firing his guns to greet the English ambassadors.
O, I die, Horatio.	Oh, I’m dying, Horatio!

But I do prophesy the election lights On Fortinbras.	But I bet Fortinbras will win the election to the Danish crown.
He has my dying voice.	He’s got my vote as I die.

This quarry cries on havoc.	These corpses suggest mayhem.
O proud death, What feast is toward in thine eternal cell, That thou so many princes at a shot So bloodily hast struck?	Oh, proud Death, what banquet are you preparing that you’ve needed to knock off so many princes at one stroke?
The sight is dismal, And our affairs from England come too late.	This is a horrible sight.
The ears are senseless that should give us hearing, To tell him his commandment is fulfilled, That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead.	We meant to tell the king that his orders have been carried out, and Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead.
Had it th' ability of life to thank you.	Who will thank us now?
For me, with sorrow I embrace my fortune.	As for me, I welcome my good luck with sadness.

And, for his passage, The soldiers' music and the rites of war Speak loudly for him.	Military music and military rites will speak for his heroic qualities.

And in the morn and liquid dew of youth, Contagious blastments are most imminent.	Baby blooms are most susceptible to disease.
Be wary, then.	So be careful.
Best safety lies in fear.	Fear will keep you safe.
Youth to itself rebels, though none else near.	Young people often lose their self-control even without any help from others.

And these few precepts in thy memory Look thou character.	And just try to remember a few rules of life.
Give thy thoughts no tongue, Nor any unproportioned thought his act.	Don’t say what you’re thinking, and don’t be too quick to act on what you think.
Be thou familiar but by no means vulgar.	Be friendly to people but don’t overdo it.
Beware Of entrance to a quarrel, but being in, Bear ’t that th' opposèd may beware of thee.	Don’t be quick to pick a fight, but once you’re in one, hold your own.

Think yourself a baby That you have ta'en these tenders for true pay, Which are not sterling.	Believe that you are a foolish little baby for believing these “offers” are something real.

And hath given countenance to his speech, my lord, With almost all the holy vows of heaven.	And he’s made the holiest vows to me, to back up what he says.
Ay, springes to catch woodcocks.	These vows are just traps for stupid birds.
I do know, When the blood burns, how prodigal the soul Lends the tongue vows.	I know when a man is on fire, he’ll swear anything.
For Lord Hamlet, Believe so much in him that he is young, And with a larger tether may he walk Than may be given you.	Remember that Hamlet is young and has a lot more freedom to fool around than you do.

Say what, is Horatio there?	Is Horatio here too?
A piece of him.	More or less.
What, has this thing appeared again tonight?	So, tell us, did you see that thing again tonight?
I have seen nothing.	I haven’t seen anything.

Therefore I have entreated him along With us to watch the minutes of this night, That if again this apparition come He may approve our eyes and speak to it.	That’s why I’ve begged him to come on our shift tonight, so that if the ghost appears he can see what we see and speak to it.
It is a nipping and an eager air.	Yes, it’s definitely nippy.
What hour now?	What time is it?
I think it lacks of twelve.	A little before twelve, I think.
No, it is struck.	No, it’s just after twelve; I heard the clock strike.
Indeed?	Really?
I heard it not.	I didn’t hear it.
It then draws near the season Wherein the spirit held his wont to walk.	So it’s nearly the time when the ghost likes to appear.
What does this mean, my lord?	What does that mean, sir?
Is it a custom?	Is that a tradition?
Ay, marry, is ’t.	Yes, it is.
But to my mind, though I am native here And to the manner born, it is a custom More honored in the breach than the observance.	But though I was born here and should consider that tradition part of my own heritage, I think it would be better to ignore it than practice it.
This heavy-headed revel east and west Makes us traduced and taxed of other nations.	Other countries criticize us for our loud partying.
They clepe us drunkards and with swinish phrase Soil our addition.	They call us drunks and insult our noble titles.
And indeed it takes From our achievements, though performed at height, The pith and marrow of our attribute.	And our drunkenness does detract from our achievements, as great as they are, and lessens our reputations.
The dram of evil Doth all the noble substance of a doubt To his own scandal.	A tiny spot of evil casts doubt on their good qualities and ruins their reputations.
Look, my lord, it comes!	Look, sir—here it comes!
Angels and ministers of grace defend us!	Oh angels, protect us!
Be thou a spirit of health or goblin damned, Bring with thee airs from heaven or blasts from hell, Be thy intents wicked or charitable, Thou comest in such a questionable shape That I will speak to thee.	Whether you’re a good spirit or a cursed demon, whether you bring heavenly breezes or blasts of hell fire, whether your intentions are good or evil, you look so strange I want to talk to you.

Let me not burst in ignorance, but tell Why thy canonized bones, hearsed in death, Have burst their cerements; why the sepulcher,	Don’t drive me crazy with curiosity, but tell me why your church-buried bones have burst out of their coffin, and why your tomb,
Wherein we saw thee quietly interred, Hath oped his ponderous and marble jaws To cast thee up again.	where we quietly buried you, has opened up its heavy marble jaws to spit you out again.
Wherefore?	Why?
It beckons you to go away with it, As if it some impartment did desire To you alone.	It wants you to go off with it, as if it wants to tell you something alone.
Look, with what courteous action It waves you to a more removèd ground.	Look how politely it’s pointing you to a place that’s farther away.
But do not go with it.	But don’t go.
No, by no means.	Definitely not.
Do not, my lord.	Don’t do it, sir.
Why, what should be the fear?	Why, what’s the danger?
I do not set my life in a pin’s fee, And for my soul—what can it do to that, Being a thing immortal as itself?	And as for my soul, how can the ghost endanger that, since it’s as immortal as the ghost is?
It waves me forth again.	Look, it’s waving me over again.
I’ll follow it.	I’ll follow it.

Speak.	Speak.
I am bound to hear.	I’m ready to hear you.
So art thou to revenge when thou shalt hear.	You must be ready for revenge, too, when you hear me out.
What?	What?
I am thy father’s spirit, Doomed for a certain term to walk the night And for the day confined to fast in fires, Till the foul crimes done in my days of nature Are burnt and purged away.	I’m the ghost of your father, doomed for a certain period of time to walk the earth at night, while during the day I’m trapped in the fires of purgatory until I’ve done penance for my past sins.
But that I am forbid To tell the secrets of my prison house, I could a tale unfold whose lightest word Would harrow up thy soul, freeze thy young blood,	If I weren’t forbidden to tell you the secrets of
Make thy two eyes, like stars, start from their spheres, Thy knotted and combinèd locks to part And each particular hair to stand on end, Like quills upon the fearful porpentine.	make your eyes jump out of their sockets, and your hair stand on end like porcupine quills.
But this eternal blazon must not be To ears of flesh and blood.	But mortals like you aren’t allowed to hear this description of the afterlife.
List, list, O, list!	Listen, listen!
If thou didst ever thy dear father love— O God!	If you ever loved your poor dear father— Oh God!
Revenge his foul and most unnatural murder.	Take revenge for his horrible murder, that crime against nature.
Murder?	Murder?
Murder most foul, as in the best it is.	His most horrible murder.
But this most foul, strange and unnatural.	Murder’s always horrible, but this one was especially horrible, weird, and unnatural.

My uncle?	My uncle?
O Hamlet, what a falling off was there!	Oh, Hamlet, how far she fell!
From me, whose love was of that dignity That it went hand in hand even with the vow I made to her in marriage, and to decline Upon a wretch whose natural gifts were poor To those of mine.	She went from me, who loved her with the dignity and devotion that suits a legitimate marriage, to a wretch whose natural gifts were poor compared to mine.
Brief let me be.	So let me be brief here.
Thus was I, sleeping, by a brother’s hand Of life, of crown, of queen at once dispatched, Cut off even in the blossoms of my sin,	And that’s how my brother robbed me of my life, my crown, and my queen all at once.
Oh, horrible, oh, horrible, most horrible!	Oh, it’s horrible, horrible, so horrible!
If thou hast nature in thee, bear it not.	If you are human, don’t stand for it.

Fare thee well at once.	Now, good-bye.
The glowworm shows the matin to be near, And 'gins to pale his uneffectual fire.	The glowworm’s light is beginning to fade, so morning is near.

Remember me.	Remember me.
O all you host of heaven!	Ah, all you up in heaven!

What else?	What else?

Break we our watch up; and by my advice Let us impart what we have seen tonight Unto young Hamlet; for, upon my life, This spirit, dumb to us, will speak to him.
