So do I, my lord.	I do too, my lord.
They are entirely welcome.	They’re entirely welcome.
And I have reason for it.	That’s true, and with good reason.

Ere I ope his letter, I pray you tell me how my good friend doth.	Before I open this letter, please tell me how my good friend is doing.
Not sick, my lord, unless it be in mind, Nor well, unless in mind.	He’s not sick, my lord, but he’s very upset, and his problems are serious.
His letter there Will show you his estate.	His letter will tell you how he’s doing.
There are some shrewd contents in yond same paper That steals the color from Bassanio’s cheek.	I wish you’d won the  Something bad in that letter is making Bassanio turn pale.
Some dear friend dead, else nothing in the world Could turn so much the constitution Of any constant man.	Some good friend of his must have died, because nothing else in the world could change a man so much.
What, worse and worse?— With leave, Bassanio, I am half yourself, And I must freely have the half of anything That this same paper brings you.	What, does the news only get worse?—Please, Bassanio, I’m half of you, so let me bear half the burden this letter brings you.
O sweet Portia, Here are a few of the unpleasant’st words That ever blotted paper.	Oh Portia, these are some of the worst words that ever stained a piece of paper.
Gentle lady, When I did first impart my love to you, I freely told you, all the wealth I had Ran in my veins.	My darling, when I gave my love to you, I told you that all the wealth I had ran within my veins—that I have noble blood, but no money.
I was a gentleman, And then I told you true.	When I said that, I told you the truth.
When I told you My state was nothing, I should then have told you That I was worse than nothing, for indeed I have engaged myself to a dear friend, Engaged my friend to his mere enemy To feed my means.	But my dear, when I said I was worth nothing, I was actually bragging—I should’ve said that I was worse than nothing.
Have all his ventures failed?	Have all his business ventures failed?
What, not one hit?	Not even one success?
Not one, my lord.	Not one, my lord.
Besides, it should appear that if he had The present money to discharge the Jew, He would not take it.	Anyway, even if he had the money now, the Jew probably wouldn’t take it.
Never did I know A creature that did bear the shape of man So keen and greedy to confound a man.	I’ve never seen a creature with a human shape who was so eager to destroy a man.
He plies the duke at morning and at night, And doth impeach the freedom of the state If they deny him justice.	He’s at the duke’s morning and night, accusing the state of harming free trade if they deny him justice.
When I was with him I have heard him swear To Tubal and to Chus, his countrymen, That he would rather have Antonio’s flesh Than twenty times the value of the sum That he did owe him.	When I was still living with him I heard him swear to Tubal and Cush, his countrymen, that he’d rather have Antonio’s flesh than twenty times the sum Antonio owed.
And I know, my lord, If law, authority, and power deny not, It will go hard with poor Antonio.	And I know that unless the law intervenes, it’ll be bad news for poor Antonio.
Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble?	Is this your good friend who’s in so much trouble?
What sum owes he the Jew?	How much does he owe the Jew?
For me, three thousand ducats.	Three thousand ducats.
What, no more?	What, that’s all?
Pay him six thousand and deface the bond!	Pay him six thousand and cancel the debt.
You shall have gold To pay the petty debt twenty times over.	I’ll give you enough gold to pay back your debt twenty times over.
When it is paid, bring your true friend along.	When it’s paid, bring your friend back.
My maid Nerissa and myself meantime Will live as maids and widows.	Until you get back, Nerissa and I will live like virgins and widows.
Bid your friends welcome, show a merry cheer.	Put on a happy face, and welcome your friends.
But let me hear the letter of your friend.	But let me hear the letter from your friend.
Sweet Bassanio, my ships have all miscarried.	Dear Bassanio, my ships have all been wrecked.
My creditors grow cruel.	My creditors are getting mean.
My estate is very low.	My money’s almost run out.
My bond to the Jew is forfeit.	I couldn’t pay my debt to the Jew on the due date.
Notwithstanding, use your pleasure.	In any case, do what you want.
If your love do not persuade you to come, let not my letter.” O love, dispatch all business and be gone!	If your affection for me doesn’t convince you to come, don’t let my letter do so.” Oh, my darling, make your arrangements and go!
Since I have your good leave to go away, I will make haste.	Since you’re letting me leave, I’ll hurry.
But till I come again, No bed shall e'er be guilty of my stay, No rest be interposer ’twixt us twain.	But I won’t sleep till I get back.
Jailer, look to him.	Jailer, watch out for this one.
This is the fool that lent out money gratis.	This is the fool who lent out money without charging interest.
Jailer, look to him.	Jailer, keep an eye on him.
Hear me yet, good Shylock.	Listen to me, good Shylock.
I pray thee, hear me speak.	I’m going to get my  Please, listen to me.
I’ll have my bond.	I want my bond.
I will not hear thee speak.	I won’t listen to you.
I’ll have my bond, and therefore speak no more.	I want my bond, so stop talking.
I’ll not be made a soft and dull-eyed fool To shake the head, relent and sigh, and yield To Christian intercessors.	I won’t be taken for a fool who sighs and gives in to Christian meddlers.
Follow not.	Don’t follow me.
I’ll have no speaking.	I’m not talking with you.
I will have my bond.	I want my bond.
It is the most impenetrable cur That ever kept with men.	He’s the most stubborn dog that ever lived among humans.
Let him alone.	Leave him alone.
I’ll follow him no more with bootless prayers.	I won’t follow him around with useless pleas anymore.
He seeks my life.	He wants me dead.
His reason well I know.	I know the real reason.
I oft delivered from his forfeitures Many that have at times made moan to me.	I’ve often given money to people who were unable to pay back their loans to him.
Therefore he hates me.	That’s why he hates me.
I am sure the duke Will never grant this forfeiture to hold.	I’m sure the duke will never allow this contract to be enforced.
Therefore go.	So go.
These griefs and losses have so bated me, That I shall hardly spare a pound of flesh Tomorrow to my bloody creditor.— Well, jailer, on.—Pray God Bassanio come To see me pay his debt, and then I care not.	I’ve lost so much weight worrying about my losses have that I’ll hardly have a pound of flesh to spare for my bloody creditor tomorrow.—Well, jailer, let’s go.—I hope to God that Bassanio comes to see me pay his debt.
Lorenzo, I commit into your hands The husbandry and manage of my house Until my lord’s return.	Lorenzo, please take charge of the management of my house until my husband comes back.
Madam, with all my heart.	Madam, with all my heart.
I shall obey you in all fair commands.	I’ll do anything you ask.
My people do already know my mind And will acknowledge you and Jessica In place of Lord Bassanio and myself.	They’ll consider you and Jessica masters of this house in place of Lord Bassanio and myself.
So fare you well till we shall meet again.	So goodbye until we meet again.
Fare you well, Jessica.	Goodbye, Jessica.
Now, Balthazar, As I have ever found thee honest true, So let me find thee still.	Now, Balthazar, you’ve always been honest and faithful to me, and I trust you still are.
Sometimes from her eyes I did receive fair speechless messages.	Sometimes the expression on her face tells me she likes me.
Her name is Portia, nothing undervalued To Cato’s daughter, Brutus' Portia.	Her name is Portia.
I shall be there before thee.	I’ll meet you at the ferry.
Madam, I go with all convenient speed.	I’ll go as fast as I can, madam.
Come on, Nerissa, I have work in hand That you yet know not of.	Come on, Nerissa, I have many things to do that you don’t even know about yet.
We’ll see our husbands Before they think of us.	We’ll see our husbands before they even have a chance to miss us.
Shall they see us?	Will they see us?
They shall, Nerissa, but in such a habit That they shall think we are accomplishèd With that we lack.	They will, Nerissa, but we’ll be disguised as men.
And twenty of these puny lies I’ll tell, That men shall swear I have discontinued school Above a twelvemonth.	I’ll tell twenty lies like that, so men will think I graduated from school at least a year ago.
I have within my mind A thousand raw tricks of these bragging jacks Which I will practice.	I know a thousand immature tricks like that, and I’ll use them all.
Why, shall we turn to men?	Why, are we turning to men?
Fie, what a question’s that If thou wert near a lewd interpreter!	What kind of question is that!
But come, I’ll tell thee all my whole device When I am in my coach, which stays for us At the park gate.	Here, I’ll tell you my whole plan in my carriage, which is waiting for us at the gate.
And therefore haste away, For we must measure twenty miles today.	So hurry up, because we have twenty miles to cover today.
Yes, truly, for look you, the sins of the father are to be laid upon the children.	Yes, look, it’s true that children are punished for the sins of their fathers.
Therefore I promise ye I fear you.	That’s why I’m worried about you.
I was always plain with you, and so now I speak my agitation of the matter.	I’ve always been straightforward with you, so now I’m telling you what I think.
Therefore be o' good cheer, for truly I think you are damned.	Cheer up, because I think you’re going to hell.
There is but one hope in it that can do you any good, and that is but a kind of bastard hope neither.	There’s only one hope for you, and even that’s a kind of illegitimate hope.
And what hope is that, I pray thee?	What hope is that, may I ask?
Marry, you may partly hope that your father got you not, that you are not the Jew’s daughter.	You can hope your father isn’t your real father.
That were a kind of bastard hope indeed.	That really is an illegitimate hope.
So the sins of my mother should be visited upon me.	Then I’d be punished for the sins of my mother.
Truly then I fear you are damned both by father and mother.	In that case I’m afraid you’re damned by both your father and your mother.
Thus when I shun Scylla your father, I fall into Charybdis your mother.	When you avoid one trap, you fall into another.
Well, you are gone both ways.	You’re in trouble either way.
I shall be saved by my husband.	My husband will save me.
He hath made me a Christian.	He’s made me a Christian.
Truly, the more to blame he.	He was wrong to do that.
We were Christians eno' before, e'en as many as could well live one by another.	There were enough Christians before—as many of them as could stand to live near each other.
This making Christians will raise the price of hogs.	All these new Christians will make the price of hogs go up.
If we grow all to be pork-eaters, we shall not shortly have a rasher on the coals for money.	If we’re all pork-eaters, we won’t be able to get our hands on a slice of bacon, even if we’ve got the money for it.
I’ll tell my husband, Launcelot, what you say.	I’ll tell my husband what you’ve said, Launcelot.
Here he comes.	Here he comes.
I shall grow jealous of you shortly, Launcelot, if you thus get my wife into corners.	You’re going to make me jealous, Launcelot, if you keep taking my wife into dark corners like this!
Nay, you need not fear us, Lorenzo.	No, you don’t need to worry about us, Lorenzo.
Launcelot and I are out.	Launcelot and I can’t agree on anything.
He tells me flatly there is no mercy for me in heaven because I am a Jew’s daughter, and he says you are no good member of the commonwealth, for in converting Jews to Christians you raise the price of pork.	He says I won’t get into heaven because I’m a Jew’s daughter, and he says you’re irresponsible because by converting Jews to Christianity you’re raising the price of pork.
I shall answer that better to the commonwealth than you can the getting up of the Negro’s belly.	I can justify that better than you can justify sleeping with Portia’s African servant.
It is much that the Moor should be more than reason.	The  It’s too bad there’s more of the Moor than there ought to be.
I think the best grace of wit will shortly turn into silence, and discourse grow commendable in none only but parrots.	I think the best sign of intelligence will soon be silence, and talking will only be a good thing for parrots to do.
That is done, sir.	That’s already been done, sir.
They have all stomachs.	They’re all ready to eat dinner.
Goodly Lord, what a wit-snapper are you!	Good Lord, what a clown you are!
Wilt thou show the whole wealth of thy wit in an instant?	Are you planning on showing me all your wit at once?
For the table, sir, it shall be served in.	About the table, sir, dinner will be served on it.
For the meat, sir, it shall be covered.	As for the food, it will be served in covered dishes.
For your coming in to dinner, sir, why, let it be as humours and conceits shall govern.	As for your coming in to dinner, just do what you feel is right.
O dear discretion, how his words are suited!	Oh, he’s good at bending words around!
How cheerest thou, Jessica?	Anyway, how are you, Jessica?
How dost thou like the Lord Bassanio’s wife?	And how do you like Lord Bassanio’s wife?
Past all expressing.	I like her more than I can say.
And if on earth he do not merit it, In reason he should never come to heaven.	And if he doesn’t deserve this joy on earth, he’ll never deserve it in heaven.
Why, if two gods should play some heavenly match And on the wager lay two earthly women, And Portia one, there must be something else Pawned with the other, for the poor rude world Hath not her fellow.	The poor rude world doesn’t have her equal.
Even such a husband Hast thou of me as she is for a wife.	As good a wife as she is, that’s how good a husband I am to you.
First let us go to dinner.	First let’s go to dinner.
Nay, let me praise you while I have a stomach.	No, let me say some good things about you while I’m in the mood.
No, pray thee, let it serve for table talk.	No, please, save it for dinner conversation.
What, is Antonio here?	Is Antonio here?
Ready, so please your grace.	Yes, sir, I’m here.
I am sorry for thee.	I feel sorry for you.
Thou art come to answer A stony adversary, an inhuman wretch Uncapable of pity, void and empty From any dram of mercy.	You’ve come to face a ruthless enemy, an inhuman wretch incapable of pity, without any feelings of mercy.
I have heard Your grace hath ta'en great pains to qualify His rigorous course.	They tell me you’ve done everything you can to talk him out of what he’s doing.
But since he stands obdurate And that no lawful means can carry me Out of his envy’s reach, I do oppose My patience to his fury, and am armed To suffer with a quietness of spirit The very tyranny and rage of his.	I’m ready to suffer peacefully whatever he does to me in his cruelty and anger.
Go, one, and call the Jew into the court.	One of you go call the Jew into court here.
He is ready at the door.	He’s standing ready outside the door.
He comes, my lord.	Here he comes, my lord.
We all expect a gentle answer, Jew.	We all expect a nice answer from you, Jew.
I have possessed your grace of what I purpose, And by our holy Sabbath have I sworn To have the due and forfeit of my bond.	I’ve told you what I intend to do, and I’ve sworn by the holy Sabbath to seek the penalty that is due according to our contract.
If you deny it, let the danger light Upon your charter and your city’s freedom.	If you refuse to allow me to do so, your city’s charter and its freedom are endangered.
You’ll ask me why I rather choose to have A weight of carrion flesh than to receive Three thousand ducats.	You’re going to ask me why I’d rather have a pound of decaying flesh than three thousand ducats.
I’ll not answer that But say it is my humour.	I won’t answer that.
Is it answered?	Is that enough of an answer?
What if my house be troubled with a rat And I be pleased to give ten thousand ducats To have it baned?	What if I had a rat in my house, and I felt like paying ten thousand ducats to have it exterminated?
What, are you answered yet?	Do you have your answer yet?
Some men there are love not a gaping pig, Some that are mad if they behold a cat, And others, when the bagpipe sings i' th' nose, Cannot contain their urine.	Some men don’t like roast pig, others go crazy if they see a cat, and others can’t help urinating when they hear bagpipes.
Are you answered?	So, to answer your question.
This is no answer, thou unfeeling man, To excuse the current of thy cruelty.	It doesn’t excuse your cruel behavior.
I am not bound to please thee with my answers.	I don’t have to give you answers that you like.
Do all men kill the things they do not love?	Does everyone kill what they don’t love?
What, wouldst thou have a serpent sting thee twice?	What, would you let a snake bite you twice?
You may as well do anything most hard, As seek to soften that—than which what’s harder?— His Jewish heart.	You might as well do the impossible rather than try to soften his Jewish heart.
I would have my bond.	I would choose to take my penalty.
How shalt thou hope for mercy, rendering none?	How can you ever hope for mercy for yourself, when you don’t give any now?
What judgment shall I dread, doing no wrong?	Why should I be afraid of your judgment when I haven’t done anything wrong?
You have among you many a purchased slave, Which—like your asses and your dogs and mules— You use in abject and in slavish parts Because you bought them.	Many of you own slaves, which—like your donkeys and dogs and mules—you use to perform awful jobs just because you bought them.
Shall I say to you, “Let them be free!	Should I say to you, “Set them free!
Marry them to your heirs!	Let them marry your children!
Why sweat they under burdens?	Why are you making them work so hard?
Let their beds Be made as soft as yours and let their palates Be seasoned with such viands”?	Let their beds be as soft as yours, and let them eat the same food as you”?
You will answer, “The slaves are ours.” So do I answer you.	No, you’d answer, “The slaves are ours.” And that’s just how I’m answering you.
The pound of flesh which I demand of him Is dearly bought.	The pound of flesh that I want from him was very expensive.
Tis mine and I will have it.	It’s mine and I’m going to get it.
If you deny me, fie upon your law— There is no force in the decrees of Venice.	If you refuse me, the laws of Venice have no validity.
I stand for judgment.	I await justice.
By my troth, Nerissa, my little body is aweary of this great world.	Oh Nerissa, my poor little body is tired of this great big world.
And yet for aught I see, they are as sick that surfeit with too much as they that starve with nothing.	But as far as I can tell, people with too much suffer as much as people with nothing.
It is no mean happiness, therefore, to be seated in the mean.	The best way to be happy is to be in between.
Good sentences, and well pronounced.	Good point, and well said.
They would be better if well followed.	It would be better if you actually applied it to your life.
It is a good divine that follows his own instructions.	It takes a good priest to practice what he preaches.
But this reasoning is not in the fashion to choose me a husband.	But thinking like this won’t help me choose a husband.
Is it not hard, Nerissa, that I cannot choose one nor refuse none?	Isn’t it a pain that I can’t choose or refuse anyone, Nerissa?
Upon my power I may dismiss this court, Unless Bellario, a learnèd doctor, Whom I have sent for to determine this, Come here today.	I have the authority to dismiss this court, unless Bellario comes today.
Bring us the letter.	Bring us the letters.
Call the messenger.	Call the messenger in.
Good cheer, Antonio!	Cheer up, Antonio!
What, man, courage yet!	Keep up your courage, man!
The Jew shall have my flesh, blood, bones and all, Ere thou shalt lose for me one drop of blood.	I’ll give the Jew my flesh, blood, bones, and everything before you lose one drop of blood for me.
I am a tainted wether of the flock, Meetest for death.	I’m like the one sick sheep in the flock, the one who deserves to die.
The weakest kind of fruit Drops earliest to the ground, and so let me.	The weakest fruit drops to the ground first, so let me drop.
You cannot better be employed, Bassanio, Than to live still and write mine epitaph.	Bassanio, the best thing you can do is to keep living and write an epitaph for my gravestone.
Came you from Padua, from Bellario?	Have you come from Bellario’s office in Padua?
From both, my lord.	Yes, my lord.
Bellario greets your grace.	Bellario sends his greetings.
To cut the forfeiture from that bankrupt there.	To cut my penalty from that bankrupt man over there.
Not on thy sole, but on thy soul, harsh Jew, Thou makest thy knife keen.	You’re sharpening that knife not on your sole but on your soul, you cruel Jew.
But no metal can— No, not the hangman’s axe—bear half the keenness Of thy sharp envy.	No metal—not even the executioner’s axe—could ever be half as sharp as your hatred.
Can no prayers pierce thee?	Can’t any prayers reach your heart?
No, none that thou hast wit enough to make.	No, none that you’re smart enough to make.
Thou almost makest me waver in my faith To hold opinion with Pythagoras That souls of animals infuse themselves Into the trunks of men.	You make me want to agree with the philosopher Pythagoras that animal souls are reincarnated in human bodies.
Thy currish spirit Governed a wolf who, hanged for human slaughter, Even from the gallows did his fell soul fleet, And whilst thou layest in thy unhallowed dam Infused itself in thee, for thy desires Are wolvish, bloody, starved, and ravenous.	That’s why your desires are wolfish, bloody, and ravenous.
Till thou canst rail the seal from off my bond, Thou but offend’st thy lungs to speak so loud.	Unless your taunts can undo the signature on my contract, you’re just wearing out your lungs by speaking so loud.
Repair thy wit, good youth, or it will fall To cureless ruin.	Be quiet, boy, or you’ll lose your mind.
I stand here for law.	I stand here with the law on my side.
This letter from Bellario doth commend A young and learnèd doctor to our court.	This letter from Bellario introduces us to a young and well-educated legal expert.
Where is he?	Where is he?
He attendeth here hard by To know your answer whether you’ll admit him.	He’s waiting nearby to find out if you’ll invite him in.
With all my heart.—Some three or four of you Go give him courteous conduct to this place.— Meantime the court shall hear Bellario’s letter.	With all my heart.—Three or four of you go welcome him.—In the meantime, I’ll read Bellario’s letter out loud.
His name is Balthazar.	His name is Balthazar.
I leave him to your gracious acceptance, whose trial shall better publish his commendation.” You hear the learned Bellario, what he writes.	I leave him to you.
Come you from old Bellario?	Did old Bellario send you here?
I did, my lord.	Yes, my lord.
You are welcome.	Welcome.
Take your place.	Please have a seat.
Are you acquainted with the difference That holds this present question in the court?	Are you familiar with the case currently before the court?
I am informèd thoroughly of the cause.	Yes, thoroughly.
Antonio and old Shylock, both stand forth.	Antonio and Shylock, both of you come forward.
Is your name Shylock?	Is your name Shylock?
Shylock is my name.	Shylock is my name.
Of a strange nature is the suit you follow, Yet in such rule that the Venetian law Cannot impugn you as you do proceed.—   Ay, so he says.	Your case is most unusual, though the Venetian law can’t stop you from proceeding.— Yes, so he says.
Do you confess the bond?	Do you acknowledge the contract?
I do.	Yes, I do.
Then must the Jew be merciful.	Then the Jew must show you mercy.
On what compulsion must I?	Why do I have to do that?
Tell me that.	Tell me.
The quality of mercy is not strained.	No one shows mercy because he has to.
It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven Upon the place beneath.	It just happens, the way gentle rain drops on the ground.
It is twice blessed: It blesseth him that gives and him that takes.	It blesses the one who gives it and the one who receives it.
Tis mightiest in the mightiest.	It’s strongest in the strongest people.
It becomes The thronèd monarch better than his crown.	It looks better in a king than his own crown looks on him.
And earthly power doth then show likest God’s When mercy seasons justice.	Kingly power seems most like God’s power when the king mixes mercy with justice.
I have spoke thus much To mitigate the justice of thy plea, Which if thou follow, this strict court of Venice Must needs give sentence 'gainst the merchant there.	If you pursue it, this strict court of Venice will need to carry out the sentence against the merchant there.
My deeds upon my head.	I take all responsibility for my decisions.
I crave the law, The penalty, and forfeit of my bond.	I want the law, the penalty, and the fulfillment of my contract.
Is he not able to discharge the money?	Can’t he pay back the money?
If that will not suffice, I will be bound to pay it ten times o'er, On forfeit of my hands, my head, my heart.	If that’s not enough, I’ll sign a contract to pay ten times that much, and I’ll give you my hands, my head, and my heart as security.
There is no power in Venice Can alter a decree establishèd.	There’s no power in Venice that can change an established decree.
Twill be recorded for a precedent, And many an error by the same example Will rush into the state.	The change will be recorded as a precedent, and many bad legal decisions will result.
It cannot be.	That can’t happen.
I pray you, let me look upon the bond.	Please, let me review the contract.
Shylock, there’s thrice thy money offered thee.	Shylock, they’re offering you three times the money you lent.
An oath, an oath, I have an oath in heaven.	But I made an oath, an oath, an oath in heaven.
Shall I lay perjury upon my soul?	Should I perjure my soul by disobeying it?
No, not for Venice.	No, not for all of Venice.
And lawfully by this the Jew may claim A pound of flesh to be by him cut off Nearest the merchant’s heart.—Be merciful.	And so the Jew may lawfully claim a pound of flesh nearest the merchant’s heart, to be cut off by him.—But please have mercy.
Take thrice thy money.	Take three times your money.
Bid me tear the bond.	Tell me to tear up this contract.
When it is paid according to the tenor.	I’ll tear it up when it’s paid.
It doth appear you are a worthy judge.	You seem like a good judge.
You know the law.	You know the law.
I charge you by the law, Whereof you are a well-deserving pillar, Proceed to judgment.	I urge you to deliver your verdict.
By my soul I swear There is no power in the tongue of man To alter me.	I swear that nothing anyone can say will change my mind.
I stay here on my bond.	I’m sticking to the contract.

Why then, thus it is: You must prepare your bosom for his knife.	Well, then, here it is: you must prepare yourself for his knife.
O noble judge!	Oh, good judge!
O excellent young man!	Oh, you excellent young man!
For the intent and purpose of the law Hath full relation to the penalty, Which here appeareth due upon the bond.	The law fully authorizes the penalty, which you have to pay according to the contract.
Tis very true.	Very true.
O wise and upright judge!	Oh wise judge!
How much more elder art thou than thy looks!	You’re so much older than you look!
Ay, his breast.	Yes, his chest!
Nearest his heart”—those are the very words.	Nearest his heart.”—Those are the very words.
It is so.	Yes.

I have them ready.	I have it ready.
Have by some surgeon, Shylock, on your charge, To stop his wounds lest he do bleed to death.	Pay a surgeon to stand by and bind his wounds, Shylock, so he doesn’t bleed to death.

It is not so expressed, but what of that?	Not explicitly, but so what?

But little.	Not much.

Fare you well.	Goodbye.
Grieve not that I am fall'n to this for you, For herein Fortune shows herself more kind Than is her custom.	Don’t be sad that this happened because of you, because Lady Luck’s been nicer to me than usual.
Repent but you that you shall lose your friend, And he repents not that he pays your debt.	Be sad only at the fact that you’ll lose your friend—your friend doesn’t regret that he paid your debt.
For if the Jew do cut but deep enough, I’ll pay it presently with all my heart.	If the Jew cuts deep enough, I’ll pay it instantly with all my heart.
Antonio, I am married to a wife Which is as dear to me as life itself.	Antonio, I married a woman as dear to me as life itself.
But life itself, my wife, and all the world Are not with me esteemed above thy life.	But life itself, my wife, and the whole world aren’t more valuable to me than your life is.
I would lose all—ay, sacrifice them all Here to this devil—to deliver you.	I’d give it all up—yes, I’d sacrifice them all to this devil here—to save you.
Your wife would give you little thanks for that If she were by to hear you make the offer.	Your wife wouldn’t like it if she were here to hear you make that offer.
I have a wife, whom I protest I love.	I have a wife I love.
I would she were in heaven, so she could Entreat some power to change this currish Jew.	I wish she were in heaven so she could appeal to some power to make this dog Jew change his mind.
Tis well you offer it behind her back.	It’s nice you’re offering to sacrifice her behind her back.
These be the Christian husbands.	That’s what you get for marrying Christian husbands.
I have a daughter.	I have a daughter.
The court awards it, and the law doth give it.	The court awards it and the law authorizes it.
Most rightful judge!	What a righteous judge!
And you must cut this flesh from off his breast.	And you have to cut this flesh from his chest.
The law allows it, and the court awards it.	The law allows it, and the court awards it.
Most learnèd judge, a sentence!	What a wise judge!
Come, prepare.	Come on, get ready.
Tarry a little.	But wait a moment.
There is something else.	There’s something else.
This bond doth give thee here no jot of blood.	This contract doesn’t give you any blood at all.
The words expressly are “a pound of flesh.” Take then thy bond, take thou thy pound of flesh, But in the cutting it if thou dost shed One drop of Christian blood, thy lands and goods Are by the laws of Venice confiscate Unto the state of Venice.	The words expressly specify “a pound of flesh.” So take your penalty of a pound of flesh, but if you shed one drop of Christian blood when you cut it, the state of Venice will confiscate your land and property under Venetian law.
Is that the law?	Is that the law?
Thyself shalt see the act.	You can see for yourself.
For as thou urgest justice, be assured Thou shalt have justice more than thou desirest.	You asked for justice, so rest assured you’ll get more justice than you bargained for.
I take this offer then: pay the bond thrice And let the Christian go.	Pay me three times the amount of the loan and let the Christian go.
Here is the money.	Here is the money.
Soft!	Wait!
The Jew shall have all justice.	The Jew will have justice.
Soft, no haste.	Wait, don’t rush!
He shall have nothing but the penalty.	He’s not getting anything except the penalty.
Therefore prepare thee to cut off the flesh.	So get ready to cut off the flesh.
Shed thou no blood, nor cut thou less nor more But just a pound of flesh.	Don’t shed any blood, or cut less or more than exactly a pound of flesh.
If thou takest more Or less than a just pound, be it but so much As makes it light or heavy in the substance Or the division of the twentieth part Of one poor scruple—nay, if the scale do turn But in the estimation of a hair, Thou diest and all thy goods are confiscate.	If you take more or less than exactly a pound, even if it’s just the tiniest fraction of an ounce—if the scale changes by even so much as a hair, you die, and all your property will be confiscated.
A second Daniel!—A Daniel, Jew!	A second Daniel!—A Daniel, Jew!

I have it ready for thee.	I have it ready for you.
Here it is.	Here it is.
Your father was ever virtuous, and holy men at their death have good inspirations.	Your father was an extremely moral man, and religious people get odd ideas on their deathbeds.
I pray thee, overname them.	But tell me.
First, there is the Neapolitan prince.	Well, first there was the prince from Naples.
I am much afeard my lady his mother played false with a smith.	I’m afraid his mother may have had an affair with a blacksmith.
Then there is the County Palatine.	Then there’s the Count Palatine.
He doth nothing but frown, as who should say, “An you will not have me, choose.” He hears merry tales and smiles not.	He does nothing but frown, as if he wants to say, “If you don’t want me, I don’t care.” He doesn’t even smile when he hears funny stories.
I fear he will prove the weeping philosopher when he grows old, being so full of unmannerly sadness in his youth.	If he’s so sad and solemn when he’s young, I can only imagine how much he’ll cry as an old man.
I had rather be married to a death’s-head with a bone in his mouth than to either of these.	No, I’d rather be married to a skull with a bone in its mouth than to either of those men.
God defend me from these two!	God protect me from these two!
How say you by the French lord, Monsieur le Bon?	What did you think about that French lord, Monsieur le Bon?
He hath refused it in the open court.	No, he refused it publicly, in open court.
He shall have merely justice and his bond.	He will have only justice and his penalty.
Thou shalt have nothing but the forfeiture To be so taken at thy peril, Jew.	You can’t have anything but the penalty, to be taken at your peril, Jew.
Why then, the devil give him good of it!	Well, then, I hope he chokes on it!
I’ll stay no longer question.	I’m not staying here to argue anymore.
Tarry, Jew.	Wait a minute, Jew.
The law hath yet another hold on you.	The law has another hold on you.
It is enacted in the laws of Venice, If it be proved against an alien That by direct or indirect attempts He seek the life of any citizen, The party 'gainst the which he doth contrive Shall seize one half his goods.	The laws of Venice state that if a foreign resident directly or indirectly attempts to kill any citizen, the person he tried to kill will receive one half of the foreigner’s goods.
The other half Comes to the privy coffer of the state, And the offender’s life lies in the mercy Of the Duke only 'gainst all other voice.	The other half goes to the state.
Down, therefore, and beg mercy of the Duke.	So get down on your knees and beg mercy from the duke.
Therefore thou must be hanged at the state’s charge.	So you’ll be hanged at the state’s expense.
That thou shalt see the difference of our spirit, I pardon thee thy life before thou ask it.	I want you to see the difference between us, so I pardon you even before you ask for a pardon.
For half thy wealth, it is Antonio’s.	Half of your wealth goes to Antonio.
The other half comes to the general state, Which humbleness may drive unto a fine.	The other half goes to the state.
Ay, for the state, not for Antonio.	Yes, the state’s half can be reduced, but not Antonio’s.
Nay, take my life and all.	No, go ahead and take my life.
Pardon not that.	Don’t pardon that.
You take my house when you do take the prop That doth sustain my house.	You take my house away when you take the money I need for upkeep.
You take my life When you do take the means whereby I live.	You take my life when you take away my means of making a living.
What mercy can you render him, Antonio?	What mercy can you show him, Antonio?
A halter gratis, nothing else, for God’s sake.	Nothing else, for God’s sake!
So please my lord the duke and all the court, To quit the fine for one half of his goods I am content, so he will let me have The other half in use to render it Upon his death unto the gentleman That lately stole his daughter.	If the duke and his court agree to set aside the fine for one half of his property, I’m happy, as long as he lets me have the other half in trust, to give it to the gentleman who recently stole his daughter.
Two things provided more: that for this favor He presently become a Christian; The other, that he do record a gift Here in the court, of all he dies possessed, Unto his son Lorenzo and his daughter.	Second, he must make a will here in this court that leaves all his property to his son-in-law Lorenzo and his daughter when he dies.
He shall do this, or else I do recant The pardon that I late pronouncèd here.	He must do this, or I’ll recant the pardon I just delivered.
Art thou contented, Jew?	Are you satisfied, Jew?
What dost thou say?	What do you say?
I am content.	I’m satisfied.
I pray you, give me leave to go from hence.	Please let me go.
I am not well.	I’m not well.
Send the deed after me, And I will sign it.	Send the deed after me and I’ll sign it.
Get thee gone, but do it.	Go, but sign the deed.
I must away this night toward Padua, And it is meet I presently set forth.	I should really leave right away.
I am sorry that your leisure serves you not.— Antonio, gratify this gentleman, For in my mind you are much bound to him.	I’m sorry you don’t have time.—Antonio, give this gentleman a reward.
And stand indebted, over and above, In love and service to you evermore.	We owe you love and service forever.
He is well paid that is well satisfied.	Being satisfied with a job well done is payment enough.
And I, delivering you, am satisfied, And therein do account myself well paid.	In saving you I consider myself well paid.
My mind was never yet more mercenary.	My thoughts were never on money.
I pray you, know me when we meet again.	I hope you’ll recognize me when we meet again.
I wish you well, and so I take my leave.	I wish you well.
Take some remembrance of us as a tribute, Not as a fee.	Take some memento from us as a token of our gratitude, not as a fee.
This ring, good sir—alas, it is a trifle.	This ring, sir—oh no, it’s nothing.
I will not shame myself to give you this.	I’d be ashamed to give you this.
I will have nothing else but only this.	I don’t want anything but that.
And now methinks I have a mind to it.	Now that I think about it, I really want it.
There’s more depends on this than on the value.	There’s more to this ring than its cash value.
The dearest ring in Venice will I give you, And find it out by proclamation.	I’ll give you the most expensive ring in Venice, and I’ll make a public announcement to help me find it.
Only for this, I pray you, pardon me.	But as for this ring, please excuse me.
I see, sir, you are liberal in offers.	I see you like to make big offers, sir.
You taught me first to beg, and now methinks You teach me how a beggar should be answered.	First you taught me how to beg, and now I think you’re teaching me how a beggar should be answered.
Good sir, this ring was given me by my wife.	Good sir, this ring was given to me by my wife.
And when she put it on, she made me vow That I should neither sell nor give nor lose it.	When she put it on my finger, she made me swear never to sell it, give it away, or lose it.
That ’scuse serves many men to save their gifts.	Many men use that excuse to avoid giving gifts.
An if your wife be not a madwoman, And know how well I have deserved the ring, She would not hold out enemy forever For giving it to me.	If your wife’s not a madwoman, and you tell her how much I deserve this ring, she won’t stay angry at you forever if you give it to me.
Well, peace be with you.	Well, anyway, goodbye.
My Lord Bassanio, let him have the ring.	Bassanio, let him have the ring.
Come, you and I will thither presently.	Come on, you and I will go soon.
And in the morning early will we both Fly toward Belmont.	Early in the morning we’ll both rush to Belmont.
Come, Antonio.	Come on, Antonio.
Inquire the Jew’s house out.	Find out where the Jew’s house is.
Give him this deed, And let him sign it.	Give him this deed and have him sign it.
We’ll away tonight, And be a day before our husbands home.	We’ll leave tonight and be home a day before our husbands get back.
This deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo.	Lorenzo will be happy with what we’ve done.
Furthermore, I pray you show my youth old Shylock’s house.	And could you please take my servant to old Shylock’s house?
That will I do.	I’ll do that.
Away, make haste.	Go, hurry.
Thou know’st where I will tarry.	You know where I’ll be waiting.
The moon shines bright.	The moon’s bright tonight.
In such a night as this, When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees And they did make no noise, in such a night Troilus methinks mounted the Trojan walls And sighed his soul toward the Grecian tents Where Cressid lay that night.	I think that on a night like this, when the wind blew the trees so gently that they didn’t make a sound,  On a night like this,  On a night like this,  On a night like this,
In such a night Did young Lorenzo swear he loved her well, Stealing her soul with many vows of faith, And ne'er a true one.	On a night like this, young Lorenzo swore he loved her very much, stealing her heart with vows of love, but not one vow was true.
In such a night Did pretty Jessica, like a little shrew, Slander her love, and he forgave it her.	On a night like this, pretty Jessica, in a bad mood, said outrageously wrong things about her lover, and he forgave her.
But, hark, I hear the footing of a man.	I hear his footsteps.
Who comes so fast in silence of the night?	Who are you, coming so fast in this quiet night?
A friend.	A friend.
A friend?	A friend?
What friend?	What friend?
Your name, I pray you, friend?	What’s your name, please, friend?
Stephano is my name, and I bring word My mistress will before the break of day Be here at Belmont.	My name’s Stephano, and I’ve come to tell you my mistress will arrive here at Belmont before sunrise.
She doth stray about By holy crosses, where she kneels and prays For happy wedlock hours.	She’s still at the monastery, kneeling and praying for a happy marriage.
Who comes with her?	Who’s coming with her?
None but a holy hermit and her maid.	No one except her maid and a holy hermit.

Here.	Here.
Tell him there’s a post come from my master with his horn full of good news.	Tell him a messenger has arrived from my master with good news.

Sweet soul, let’s in, and there expect their coming.	My dear, let’s go inside and wait for them to arrive.
And yet no matter.	But I guess it doesn’t matter.
God made him and therefore let him pass for a man.	We might as well call him a man, since God created him.
In truth, I know it is a sin to be a mocker, but he!—why, he hath a horse better than the Neapolitan’s, a better bad habit of frowning than the Count Palatine.	His horse is better than the Neapolitan’s and he frowns more than the Count Palatine.
What say you then to Falconbridge, the young baron of England?	What about Falconbridge, that young English baron?
You know I say nothing to him, for he understands not me, nor I him.	I have no opinion about him.
He hath neither Latin, French, nor Italian, and you will come into the court and swear that I have a poor pennyworth in the English.	He doesn’t speak Latin, French, or Italian, and you know how little English I speak.
He is a proper man’s picture, but alas, who can converse with a dumb show?	He’s great-looking, but how can you talk to someone who doesn’t speak your language?
How oddly he is suited!	He was dressed so oddly too!
I think he bought his doublet in Italy, his round hose in France, his bonnet in Germany, and his behavior everywhere.	I think he got his jacket in Italy, his tights in France, his hat in Germany, and his behavior everywhere.
What think you of the Scottish lord, his neighbor?	What do you think of his neighbor, the Scottish lord?
How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank!	How beautiful the moonlight’s shining on this bank!
Here will we sit and let the sounds of music Creep in our ears.	Let’s sit here and let the music fill our ears.
Soft stillness and the night Become the touches of sweet harmony.	Stillness and nighttime are perfect for beautiful music.
Sit, Jessica.	Sit down, Jessica.
Look how the floor of heaven Is thick inlaid with patens of bright gold.	Look at the stars, see how the floor of heaven is inlaid with small disks of bright gold.
Come ho, and wake Diana with a hymn!	Wake up the moon goddess with a hymn!
With sweetest touches pierce your mistress' ear, And draw her home with music.	Get her attention and draw her home with music.
I am never merry when I hear sweet music.	I’m never in the mood to laugh when I hear sweet music.
The motions of his spirit are dull as night, And his affections dark as Erebus.	His soul is as dull as night and dark as the underworld.
Let no such man be trusted.	Nobody like that should be trusted.
Mark the music.	Pay attention to the music.
That light we see is burning in my hall.	That light we see is coming from my hall.
How far that little candle throws his beams!	Look how far that little candle sends its light!
So shines a good deed in a naughty world.	That’s the way a good deed shines in a naughty world.
When the moon shone we did not see the candle.	While the moon was shining we didn’t even notice the candle.
So doth the greater glory dim the less.	Well, brighter lights always dim the smaller ones.
A substitute shines brightly as a king Until a king be by, and then his state Empties itself, as doth an inland brook Into the main of waters.	A governor shines as brightly as a king until a king is near by, and the governor suddenly looks like a nobody.
Music, hark.	Music, listen!
It is your music, madam, of the house.	It’s your music, madam, from your house.
Nothing is good, I see, without respect.	Now I see that you can’t call anything good except in right context.
How many things by season seasoned are To their right praise and true perfection!	How many things in life seem good to us because of when they happen!
Peace!	Quiet now!
How the moon sleeps with Endymion And would not be awaked.	Look how the moon seems to be sleeping with its lover and can’t be awoken!
That is the voice, Or I am much deceived, of Portia.	If I’m not mistaken, that’s Portia’s voice.
He knows me as the blind man knows the cuckoo— By the bad voice.	He recognizes me like a blind man recognizes a cuckoo—by its bad voice.
Dear lady, welcome home.	Dear lady, welcome home.
We have been praying for our husbands' welfare, Which speed, we hope, the better for our words.	We’ve been praying for our husbands' welfare.

This night methinks is but the daylight sick.	I think this night is just like sick daylight.

It must appear in other ways than words, Therefore I scant this breathing courtesy.	But action speaks louder than words, so I’ll cut short these polite words.
A quarrel, ho, already?	What, an argument already?

About a hoop of gold, a paltry ring That she did give me, whose posy was For all the world like cutler’s poetry Upon a knife, “Love me and leave me not.” What talk you of the posy or the value?	It said, “Love me and don’t leave me.” How can you talk about the quality of the poem or the value of the ring?

He will, an if he live to be a man.	He will if he lives long enough to become a man.
Ay, if a woman live to be a man.	Yes, if a woman grows up to be a man.
I could not for my heart deny it him.	I didn’t have the heart to say no to him.

I gave my love a ring and made him swear Never to part with it.	I gave my lover a ring and made him swear never to lose it or give it away.
And here he stands.	And here he is.
I dare be sworn for him he would not leave it Nor pluck it from his finger for the wealth That the world masters.	I’d swear he wouldn’t leave it behind, or even take it off his finger, for all the money in the world.

An ’twere to me, I should be mad at it.	If it were me, I’d be very upset too.
My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away Unto the judge that begged it and indeed Deserved it too.	Bassanio gave his ring to the judge who asked for it, and deserved it too.
And then the boy, his clerk, That took some pains in writing, he begged mine.	And then his clerk, who went to a lot of trouble with the writing, begged for mine.

What ring gave you my lord?	Which ring did you give away, my lord?
Not that, I hope, which you received of me.	Not the one I gave you, I hope.
If I could add a lie unto a fault I would deny it.	If I could make things better by lying, I’d deny it.
but you see my finger Hath not the ring upon it.	But you see my finger doesn’t have the ring on it.
It is gone.	It’s gone.
Sweet Portia, If you did know to whom I gave the ring, If you did know for whom I gave the ring, And would conceive for what I gave the ring, And how unwillingly I left the ring When naught would be accepted but the ring, You would abate the strength of your displeasure.	My dear Portia, if you knew who I gave the ring to, for whose sake I gave the ring to him, why I gave it to him, and how unwilling I was to leave it when he wouldn’t accept anything but the ring, you wouldn’t be so angry.
If you had known the virtue of the ring, Or half her worthiness that gave the ring, Or your own honor to contain the ring, You would not then have parted with the ring.	If you’d known how much that ring meant, how much the woman who gave it to you is worth, or how much your honor depended on your keeping the ring, you wouldn’t have let it go.
Nerissa teaches me what to believe.	Nerissa’s got the right idea.

I was enforced to send it after him.	I had to send it to him.

Watch me like Argus.	Watch me like a hawk.

I am th' unhappy subject of these quarrels.	All these quarrels are about me.

In both my eyes he doubly sees himself— In each eye, one.	He sees himself in my two eyes, so there’s two of him.
Swear by your double self, And there’s an oath of credit!	He should swear by his two-faced self, and that’s an oath I’ll believe!
Nay, but hear me.	No, just listen to me.

You come to me and you say, “Shylock, we would have moneys.” You say so!— You, that did void your rheum upon my beard And foot me as you spurn a stranger cur Over your threshold! If thou wilt lend this money, lend it not As to thy friends, for when did friendship take A breed for barren metal of his friend?	If you’re going to lend us this money, don’t lend it to us as if we were your friends.
But lend it rather to thine enemy, Who, if he break, thou mayst with better face Exact the penalty.	Instead, lend it to me as your enemy.
Why, look you how you storm!	Look at you getting all riled up!
I would be friends with you and have your love, Forget the shames that you have stained me with, Supply your present wants and take no doit Of usance for my moneys—and you’ll not hear me!	I want to be friends with you, and forget all the times you’ve embarrassed and humiliated me.
This is kind I offer.	I’m making a kind offer—zero percent financing.

Go with me to a notary, seal me there Your single bond, and—in a merry sport— If you repay me not on such a day, In such a place, such sum or sums as are Expressed in the condition, let the forfeit Be nominated for an equal pound Of your fair flesh, to be cut off and taken In what part of your body pleaseth me.	If you don’t repay me on the day we agree on, in the place we name, for the sum of money fixed in our contract, your penalty will be a pound of your pretty flesh, to be cut off and taken out of whatever part of your body I like.
Content, in faith.	It’s a deal.
I’ll seal to such a bond, And say there is much kindness in the Jew.	I’ll agree to those terms and even say that Jews are nice.
You shall not seal to such a bond for me!	No, you can’t sign a contract like that for me!
I’ll rather dwell in my necessity.	I’d rather go without the money.
Within these two months—that’s a month before This bond expires—I do expect return Of thrice three times the value of this bond.	In two months—a month before this loan is due—I expect to earn more than three times that much from my investments.
A pound of man’s flesh taken from a man Is not so estimable, profitable neither, As flesh of muttons, beefs, or goats.	A pound of human flesh taken isn’t even as valuable as a pound of mutton or beef.
If he will take it, so.	If he agrees, great.
If not, adieu.	If not, goodbye.
And for my love I pray you wrong me not.	And I hope you won’t think badly of me.
Yes, Shylock, I will seal unto this bond.	Yes, Shylock, I’ll sign the contract and agree to its terms.
Then meet me forthwith at the notary’s.	Then meet me right away at the notary’s.
Give him direction for this merry bond, And I will go and purse the ducats straight, See to my house left in the fearful guard Of an unthrifty knave, and presently I will be with you.	Give him the instructions for our amusing little contract, and I’ll go get the money for you right away.
Hie thee, gentle Jew.	Hurry up, my Jewish friend.
My ships come home a month before the day.	My ships will come home a month before the money is due.
I would not change this hue Except to steal your thoughts, my gentle queen.	I wouldn’t change it except to make you think of me, my darling queen.
Even for that I thank you.	Thank you for saying that.
Therefore I pray you lead me to the caskets To try my fortune.	Show me the caskets and let me try my luck.
By this scimitar That slew the Sophy and a Persian prince That won three fields of Sultan Solyman, I would o'erstare the sternest eyes that look, Outbrave the heart most daring on the earth, Pluck the young sucking cubs from the she-bear, Yea, mock the lion when he roars for prey, To win the lady.	I swear by my sword, which killed the Shah of Persia and a Persian prince and defeated the Sultan Suleiman three times, that I would face the meanest-looking warriors on earth.
But, alas the while!	But this is bad!
Nor will not.	Think about it carefully.
Come, bring me unto my chance.	Let me take my chances.
First, forward to the temple.	Let’s go to the temple first.
After dinner Your hazard shall be made.	You can take your chances after dinner.
Certainly my conscience will serve me to run from this Jew, my master.	I’m sure I’ll feel guilty if I run away from this Jew, my master.
For the heavens, rouse up a brave mind,” says the fiend, “and run.” Well, my conscience, hanging about the neck of my heart, says very wisely to me, “My honest friend Launcelot, being an honest man’s son”—or rather an honest woman’s son, for indeed my father did something smack, something grow to.	Be tough,” says the devil, “and run!” But then my conscience, hanging around my heart, says very wisely to me, “My good friend Launcelot, you’re a good boy, the son of an honest man,” really, that should be the son of an honest woman, since my father cheated on my mother.
He had a kind of taste.—Well, my conscience says, “Launcelot, budge not.” “Budge!” says the fiend.	Anyway, my conscience says, “Stay put.” “Go,” the devil says.
Budge not,” says my conscience.	Don’t go,” says my conscience.
Conscience,” say I, “you counsel well.” “Fiend,” say I, “you counsel well.” To be ruled by my conscience I should stay with the Jew my master, who, God bless the mark, is a kind of devil.	Conscience,” I say, “you give good advice.” “Devil,” I say, “you give good advice.” If I listened to my conscience, I’d stay with the Jew my master, who’s a devil.
And to run away from the Jew I should be ruled by the fiend, who, saving your reverence, is the devil himself.	But if I ran away from the Jew, I’d be following the advice of the devil, who’s the very devil himself.
The fiend gives the more friendly counsel.	The devil’s advice is nicer.
I will run, fiend.	I’ll run, devil.
I will run.	Tell me to run, and I’ll run.
Master young man, you, I pray you, which is the way to Master Jew’s?	Excuse me, young man, how do I get to the Jew’s residence?
Master young gentleman, I pray you, which is the way to Master Jew’s?	Young man, excuse me, how do I get to the Jew’s?
Turn up on your right hand at the next turning, but at the next turning of all on your left.	Turn right at the next turn, but at the following turn, turn left.
Marry, at the very next turning turn of no hand, but turn down indirectly to the Jew’s house.	Oh, and then at the very next turn, don’t turn left or right, but turn down and around to the Jew’s house.
By God’s sonties, ’twill be a hard way to hit.	Good heavens, those are difficult directions.
Can you tell me whether one Launcelot that dwells with him, dwell with him or no?	Can you tell me if a man named Launcelot, who lives with him, is still there?
Talk you of young Master Launcelot?	Are you talking about young Master Launcelot?
No “master,” sir, but a poor man’s son.	He’s not a “master,” sir, he’s just a poor man’s son.
His father, though I say ’t, is an honest exceeding poor man and, God be thanked, well to live.	His father, if I do say so myself, is an honest but very poor man, and, thank God, likely to live a long time.
Your worship’s friend and Launcelot, sir.	He’s just Launcelot.
Shall I have the thought To think on this, and shall I lack the thought That such a thing bechanced would make me sad?	Who wouldn’t get sad thinking about things like that?
But tell not me.	It’s obvious.
Believe me, no.	No, that’s not it, trust me.
Therefore my merchandise makes me not sad.	So it’s not my business that’s making me sad.
Why then, you are in love.	Well then, you must be in love.
Not in love neither?	You’re not in love either?
But I pray you, ergo, old man, ergo, I beseech you, talk you of young Master Launcelot?	But excuse me,  Yes, I’m talking about Launcelot, sir.
Ergo, Master Launcelot.	Oh, no.
Marry, God forbid!	God forbid!
The boy was the very staff of my age, my very prop.	The boy was going to support me in my old age!
Do I look like a cudgel or a hovel-post, a staff or a prop?	What am I, a cane?
Do you know me, Father?	Don’t you recognize me, father?
Alack the day, I know you not, young gentleman.	Heaven help me, I don’t know you, sir.
But I pray you, tell me, is my boy, God rest his soul, alive or dead?	But please tell me, is my boy—God rest his soul—alive or dead?
Do you not know me, Father?	You really don’t recognize me, father?
Alack, sir, I am sand-blind.	Sir, I’m half-blind.
I know you not.	I don’t know you.
Nay, indeed if you had your eyes, you might fail of the knowing me.	Even if you had your eyes, you still might not recognize me.
It is a wise father that knows his own child.	It takes a wise father to know his own child.
Well, old man, I will tell you news of your son.	Well, old man, I’ll tell you news of your son.
Give me your blessing.	Give me your blessing.
Pray you, sir, stand up.	Please stand up!
I am sure you are not Launcelot, my boy.	I’m sure you aren’t Launcelot, my boy.
Pray you, let’s have no more fooling about it, but give me your blessing.	Give me your blessing.
I am Launcelot, your boy that was, your son that is, your child that shall be.	I’m Launcelot, who was your boy, is your son, and will be your child.
I cannot think you are my son.	I can’t believe you’re my son.
Her name is Margery, indeed.	Yes, you’re right, her name is Margery.
I’ll be sworn, if thou be Launcelot, thou art mine own flesh and blood.	If you’re Launcelot, then you’re my own flesh and blood.
It should seem then that Dobbin’s tail grows backward.	Then Dobbin’s tail must be growing backward.
I am sure he had more hair of his tail than I have of my face when I last saw him.	I’m sure he had more hair on his tail than I have on my face when I last saw him.
Lord, how art thou changed!	Lord, how you’ve changed!
How dost thou and thy master agree?	How are you and your master getting along?
I have brought him a present.	I’ve brought him a present.
How 'gree you now?	How are you?
My master’s a very Jew.	My master’s a total Jew.
Give him a present.	You’re giving him a present?
Give him a halter.	Give him a noose to hang himself.
I am famished in his service.	He’s starving me to death.
You may tell every finger I have with my ribs.	You can see my ribs so well you can count them.
Father, I am glad you are come.	I’m glad you’ve come, father.
Give me your present to one Master Bassanio, who indeed gives rare new liveries.	Give me your present to give to Master Bassanio.
Gramercy!	Thank you.
Wouldst thou aught with me?	What do you want with me?
What would you?	What do you want?
Serve you, sir.	To work for you, sir.
That is the very defect of the matter, sir.	That’s what we’re trying to say, sir.
I know thee well.	I know who you are.
Thou hast obtained thy suit.	You can have what you want.
Father, in.	Father, go ahead.
My best endeavours shall be done herein.	BASSANIO Please, Leonardo, think about this  I’ll do my best.
Yonder, sir, he walks.	He’s walking over there, sir.
Signor Bassanio!	Signor Bassanio!
Gratiano!	Gratiano!
I have a suit to you.	I have a favor to ask.
You have obtained it.	Anything.
You must not deny me.	Don’t say no.
I must go with you to Belmont.	Let me go with you to Belmont.
Why, then you must.	Well, if you have to go, you have to go.
But hear thee, Gratiano.	But listen to me, Gratiano.
Thou art too wild, too rude and bold of voice— Parts that become thee happily enough And in such eyes as ours appear not faults.	Sometimes you get a bit too wild, and you let your voice get a bit loud and rude.
Pray thee, take pain To allay with some cold drops of modesty Thy skipping spirit, lest through thy wild behavior I be misconst’red in the place I go to, And lose my hopes.	Please, try to act a little more serious, or the people in Belmont will get the wrong impression about me, and your wildness will make me blow my chance with Portia.
Signor Bassanio, hear me.	Listen, Signor Bassanio, there’s nothing to worry about.
If I do not put on a sober habit, Talk with respect and swear but now and then, Wear prayer books in my pocket, look demurely— Nay more.	I’ll carry prayer books in my pocket and look sweet—even more.
While grace is saying, hood mine eyes Thus with my hat, and sigh and say, “Amen”— Use all the observance of civility Like one well studied in a sad ostent To please his grandam, never trust me more.	If I don’t do all this, never trust me again.
Well, we shall see your bearing.	Well, we’ll see how you act.
Nay, but I bar tonight.	Okay, but tonight doesn’t count.
You shall not gauge me By what we do tonight.	You can’t judge me based on what I do tonight.
I would entreat you rather to put on Your boldest suit of mirth, for we have friends That purpose merriment.	I’d rather see you having fun, because we have friends coming who want to have fun.
But fare you well.	Anyway, I have to say goodbye to you now.
I have some business.	I’ve got some business to take care of.
I am sorry thou wilt leave my father so.	I’m sorry you’re leaving my father like this.
Our house is hell, and thou, a merry devil, Didst rob it of some taste of tediousness.	It’s hell in our house, and you helped cheer it up, like a funny devil.
And Launcelot, soon at supper shalt thou see Lorenzo, who is thy new master’s guest.	You’ll soon be meeting Lorenzo at supper; he’ll be a guest of your new master.
Give him this letter.	Give him this letter.
Adieu!	Goodbye.
If a Christian do not play the knave and get thee, I am much deceived.	I’m sure some Christian will resort to trickery to get you.
But adieu.	But goodbye.
These foolish drops do something drown my manly spirit.	It’s not manly to cry.
Adieu.	Goodbye.
Farewell, good Launcelot.	Goodbye, Launcelot.
Alack, what heinous sin is it in me To be ashamed to be my father’s child!	Oh God, what a heinous sinner I am, being ashamed to be my father’s child!
But though I am a daughter to his blood, I am not to his manners.	But I need to remember I’m related to him by blood, not behavior.
O Lorenzo, If thou keep promise, I shall end this strife, Become a Christian and thy loving wife.	Oh Lorenzo, if you keep your promise to me, I’ll end this agony by becoming a Christian and marrying you.
Nay, we will slink away in supper time, Disguise us at my lodging, and return, All in an hour.	No, we’ll sneak away at supper time, disguise ourselves with masks at my house, and come back in an hour.
We have not made good preparation.	But we haven’t made any preparations.
We have not spoke us yet of torchbearers.	We haven’t even talked about who’ll be our torchbearers.
Tis vile, unless it may be quaintly ordered, And better in my mind not undertook.	I think it’s better to call it off.
Tis now but four o'clock.	It’s only four o'clock now.
We have two hours To furnish us.	We have two hours to get ready.
Friend Launcelot, what’s the news?	Launcelot, what’s going on?
I know the hand.	I recognize the handwriting.
Love news, in faith?	I bet it’s a love letter!
Whither goest thou?	Where are you going?
Marry, sir, to bid my old master the Jew to sup tonight with my new master the Christian.	To invite my former boss, the Jew, to dine tonight with my new master, the Christian.
And so will I.	Me too.
Meet me and Gratiano At Gratiano’s lodging some hour hence.	Meet me and Gratiano at his house in about an hour.
Tis good we do so.	It’s good we’re doing this.
Was not that letter from fair Jessica?	Wasn’t that letter from Jessica?
Some that will evermore peep through their eyes And laugh like parrots at a bagpiper, And other of such vinegar aspect That they’ll not show their teeth in way of smile Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable.	Some people will laugh at anything, and others are so grouchy they won’t even crack a smile when they hear something hysterically funny.
Fare ye well.	Goodbye, then.
Your worth is very dear in my regard.	You’re both very precious to me.
I take it your own business calls on you And you embrace th' occasion to depart.	You need to leave to take care of your own business.
Good signors both, when shall we laugh?	We’re available.
My Lord Bassanio, since you have found Antonio, We two will leave you.	Bassanio, we’ll say goodbye for now, since you’ve found Antonio.
I will not fail you.	Don’t worry, I’ll be there.
I must needs tell thee all.	I have to tell you everything.
Who bids thee call?	Who asked you to call her?
I do not bid thee call.	I’m not asking you to call her.
Your worship was wont to tell me that I could do nothing without bidding.	You always loved to tell me I couldn’t do anything without being told.
Call you?	Did you call me?
What is your will?	Do you need something?
I am bid forth to supper, Jessica.	I’ve been invited to supper, Jessica.
There are my keys.—But wherefore should I go?	Here are my keys.—But why should I go?
I am not bid for love.	I wasn’t invited because they like me.
They flatter me.	They’re just flattering me.
But yet I’ll go in hate to feed upon The prodigal Christian.—Jessica, my girl, Look to my house.	But I’ll go out of spite, to feed off the wasteful Christian.—Jessica, my girl, watch the house.
I am right loath to go.	I don’t feel like going.
There is some ill a-brewing towards my rest, For I did dream of money bags tonight.	I know because I dreamed of money bags last night.
I beseech you, sir, go.	Please go, sir.
My young master doth expect your reproach.	My new master is expecting your approach.
So do I his.	And I’m expecting his reproach.
And they have conspired together.	And they’ve been plotting things together.
I will not say you shall see a masque, but if you do then it was not for nothing that my nose fell a-bleeding on Black Monday last at six o'clock i' th' morning falling out that year on Ash Wednesday was four year in th' afternoon.	I knew there would be a masquerade when I got that bad omen of a bloody nose last Easter Monday, at six in the morning, four years after I got the same kind of bloody nose on Ash Wednesday, in the afternoon.
What, are there masques?	What, there’s going to be a masquerade?
But stop my house’s ears—I mean my casements— Let not the sound of shallow foppery enter My sober house.	Don’t stick your head out into the public street to stare at the Christian fools with painted faces.
By Jacob’s staff, I swear, I have no mind of feasting forth tonight.	Block up my house’s ears—I mean the windows.
I will go before, sir.— Mistress, look out at window, for all this.	I’ll go ahead of you, sir.
What says that fool of Hagar’s offspring, ha?	What did that gentile fool say to you, hmmm?
His words were, “Farewell, mistress.” Nothing else.	He said “Goodbye, madam,” and nothing else.
The patch is kind enough, but a huge feeder, Snail-slow in profit, and he sleeps by day More than the wildcat.	The fool’s nice enough, but he’s such a huge eater, and slow as a snail when he works.
Drones hive not with me.	He sleeps all day like a cat.
Well, Jessica, go in.	Anyway, Jessica, go inside.
Perhaps I will return immediately.	I might come back soon.
Do as I bid you.	Do as I told you.
Shut doors after you.	Shut the doors after you.
Fast bind, fast find.	Goodbye.
Farewell, and if my fortune be not crost, I have a father, you a daughter, lost.	If luck’s with me, I’ll lose a father, and you’ll lose a daughter.
This is the penthouse under which Lorenzo Desired us to make stand.	This is the roof under which Lorenzo said to meet him.
His hour is almost past.	He’s late.
And it is marvel he outdwells his hour, For lovers ever run before the clock.	Yes, and that’s surprising, because lovers are usually early.
Oh, ten times faster Venus' pigeons fly To seal love’s bonds new made than they are wont To keep obligèd faith unforfeited.	Yes, for new lovers time passes ten times faster than for couples who’ve been married forever.
That ever holds.	That’s always true.
Who riseth from a feast With that keen appetite that he sits down?	Who gets up from a meal with the same appetite he had when he sat down?
Where is the horse that doth untread again His tedious measures with the unbated fire That he did pace them first?	Can any horse retrace his footsteps with the same energy he had when he walked them the first time?
All things that are, Are with more spirit chasèd than enjoyed.	We chase everything in life more excitedly than we actually enjoy it when we get it.
Here comes Lorenzo.	Here comes Lorenzo.
More of this hereafter.	We’ll talk about this later.
Sweet friends, your patience for my long abode.	My dear friends, thanks for your patience.
Not I but my affairs have made you wait.	I had business that made me late.
When you shall please to play the thieves for wives, I’ll watch as long for you then.	When you have to steal your own wives some day, I’ll wait for you just as long.
Approach.	Come over here.
Who’s within?	Who’s in there?
Who are you?	Who are you?
Tell me for more certainty, Albeit I’ll swear that I do know your tongue.	Tell me so I can be sure, though I swear I recognize your voice.
Lorenzo, and thy love.	I’m Lorenzo, your love.
Lorenzo certain, and my love indeed— For who love I so much?	Lorenzo, that’s for sure, and I’m also sure you’re my love—who else do I love so much?
And now who knows But you, Lorenzo, whether I am yours?	And now who but you knows whether I’m yours?
Heaven and thy thoughts are witness that thou art.	As God is my witness, you know you’re mine.
Here, catch this casket.	Here, catch this box.
It is worth the pains.	It’ll be worth your while.
Descend, for you must be my torchbearer.	You have to be my torchbearer for the masquerade.
What, must I hold a candle to my shames?	What, I have to hold a candle up so people can see what I’m doing?
I will make fast the doors and gild myself With some more ducats, and be with you straight.	I’ll lock up the doors, grab some more ducats, and be with you right away.
Now, by my hood, a gentle and no Jew.	My God, she can’t be a Jew, she’s too nice!
Beshrew me but I love her heartily.	God, I’m crazy about her.
For she is wise, if I can judge of her.	She’s wise, if I’m judging her right.
And fair she is, if that mine eyes be true.	She’s beautiful, if my eyes can see.
And true she is, as she hath proved herself.	And she’s loyal, as she has proven.
And therefore, like herself—wise, fair and true— Shall she be placèd in my constant soul.	And as long as she’s herself—wise, beautiful, and faithful—she’ll always have a place in my heart.
What, art thou come?—On, gentlemen, away!	Ah, you’re here?—Come on, gentlemen, let’s go!
Our masquing mates by this time for us stay.	Our masquerade mates are waiting for us.
Who’s there?	Who’s there?
Signor Antonio?	Signor Antonio?
Tis nine o'clock.	It’s nine o'clock!
Our friends all stay for you.	Our friends are all waiting for you.
No masque tonight.	There’s no masquerade tonight.
I have sent twenty out to seek for you.	I’ve sent twenty people to look for you.
I am glad on ’t.	I’m glad.
I desire no more delight Than to be under sail and gone tonight.	I want to head out tonight.
The one of them contains my picture, Prince.	One of them contains my picture.
If you choose that, then I am yours withal.	If you choose that one, I’m yours, along with the picture.
Some god direct my judgment!	I wish some god could help me choose!
Let me see.	Let me see.
I will survey th' inscriptions back again.	I’ll look over the inscriptions again.
What says this leaden casket?	What does the lead box say?
Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.” Must give—for what?	He who chooses me must give and risk all he has.” Must give everything—for what?
For lead?	For lead?
Hazard for lead?	Risk everything for lead?
This casket threatens.	This box is too threatening.
Men that hazard all Do it in hope of fair advantages.	Men who risk everything hope to make profits.
A golden mind stoops not to shows of dross.	A golden mind doesn’t bend down to choose something worthless.
I’ll then nor give nor hazard aught for lead.	So I won’t give or risk anything for lead.
What says the silver with her virgin hue?	What does the silver one say?
Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.” “As much as he deserves!”—pause there, Morocco, And weigh thy value with an even hand.	He who chooses me will get as much as he deserves.” As much as he deserves—wait a minute there, Morocco, and consider your own value with a level head.
What if I strayed no further, but chose here?	What if I went no further and chose this one?
Let’s see once more this saying graved in gold, “Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.” Why, that’s the lady.	But let’s see once more what the gold one says: “He who chooses me will get what many men want.” That’s Portia!
All the world desires her.	The whole world wants her.
From the four corners of the earth they come To kiss this shrine, this mortal breathing saint.	They come from the four corners of the earth to kiss this shrine and see this living, breathing saint.
The Hyrcanian deserts and the vasty wilds Of wide Arabia are as thoroughfares now For princes to come view fair Portia.	Princes travel across deserts and the vast wilderness of Arabia to come see the beautiful Portia.
The watery kingdom, whose ambitious head Spits in the face of heaven, is no bar To stop the foreign spirits, but they come As o'er a brook to see fair Portia.	The wide ocean doesn’t prevent them from coming to see her—they travel across it as if it were a little stream.
One of these three contains her heavenly picture.	One of these three boxes contains her lovely picture.
Is ’t like that lead contains her?	Could the lead one contain it?
Twere damnation To think so base a thought.	No, it’d be a sin to think such a low thought.
It were too gross To rib her cerecloth in the obscure grave.	Lead’s too crass to hold her.
Or shall I think in silver she’s immured, Being ten times undervalued to tried gold?	Is she enclosed in silver, which is ten times less valuable than gold?
O sinful thought!	Oh, what a sinful thought!
Never so rich a gem Was set in worse than gold.	Nobody ever set a gem like her in a worse setting than gold.
They have in England A coin that bears the figure of an angel Stamped in gold, but that’s insculped upon.	They have a coin in England stamped with the figure of an angel, but that’s just engraved on the surface.
You look not well, Signor Antonio.	You don’t look well, Antonio.
You have too much respect upon the world.	People with too much invested in the world always get hurt.
And let my liver rather heat with wine Than my heart cool with mortifying groans.	I’d rather overload my liver with wine than starve my heart by denying myself fun.
I’ll tell thee more of this another time.	I’ll talk to you more about this some other time.
But fish not with this melancholy bait For this fool gudgeon, this opinion.— Come, good Lorenzo.—Fare ye well awhile.	I’m a fool.—Let’s go, Lorenzo.—Goodbye for now.
I’ll end my exhortation after dinner.	I’ll finish my lecture after dinner.
Lies all within.—Deliver me the key.	Here an angel’s lying in a golden bed.—Give me the key.
Here do I choose, and thrive I as I may!	I will choose this one and try my chances.
There, take it, Prince.	Damn it!
O hell, what have we here?	What’s this?
A carrion death, within whose empty eye There is a written scroll.	It’s a skull with a scroll in its empty eye socket.
I’ll read the writing.	I’ll read it aloud.
All that glisters is not gold— Often have you heard that told.	All that glitters is not gold— You’ve often heard that said.
Many a man his life hath sold But my outside to behold.	Many men have sold their souls Just to view my shiny surface.
Gilded tombs do worms enfold.	But gilded tombs contain worms.
Had you been as wise as bold, Young in limbs, in judgment old, Your answer had not been inscrolled.	If you’d been as wise as you were bold, With an old man’s mature judgment, You wouldn’t have had to read this scroll.
Portia, adieu.	Portia, goodbye to you.
I have too grieved a heart To take a tedious leave.	My heart’s too sad for long goodbyes.
Thus losers part.	Losers always leave quickly.
A gentle riddance.—Draw the curtains, go.— Let all of his complexion choose me so.	Good riddance!—Close the curtains and leave.—I hope everyone who looks like him will make the same choice.
Why, man, I saw Bassanio under sail.	I saw Bassanio sail away, and Gratiano went with him.
With him is Gratiano gone along.	I’m sure Lorenzo isn’t on their ship.
And in their ship I am sure Lorenzo is not.	That wicked Jew got the duke to listen to his complaints.
The villain Jew with outcries raised the Duke, Who went with him to search Bassanio’s ship.	The duke went with him to search Bassanio’s ship.
He came too late.	He got there too late.
The ship was under sail.	The ship was already sailing.
But there the Duke was given to understand That in a gondola were seen together Lorenzo and his amorous Jessica.	But once he got there, the duke learned that Lorenzo and his lover Jessica were together in a gondola.
Besides, Antonio certified the Duke They were not with Bassanio in his ship.	In any case, Antonio assured the duke they weren’t with Bassanio on his ship.
I never heard a passion so confused, So strange, outrageous, and so variable, As the dog Jew did utter in the streets.	I’ve never heard such confused emotions as what that Jew dog was shouting in the streets.
O my daughter, Fled with a Christian!	Ran off with a Christian!
