O mischief, thou art swift To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!	O mischief, you are quick To enter into the thoughts of desperate men!
I do remember an apothecary, And hereabouts he dwells, which late I noted In tatt'red weeds, with overwhelming brows, Culling of simples.	I do remember a pharmacist, And lives near here, who I noticed was dressed in In tattered weeds, with overwhelming eyebrows, Choosing the simple life.
Meagre were his looks, Sharp misery had worn him to the bones; And in his needy shop a tortoise hung, An alligator stuff'd, and other skins Of ill-shaped fishes; and about his shelves A beggarly account of empty boxes, Green earthen pots, bladders, and musty seeds, Remnants of packthread, and old cakes of roses Were thinly scattered, to make up a show.	He looked very thin, As if sharp misery had worn him down to the bones; And in his poor shop a turtle was hanging, And a stuffed alligator, and other skins Of ill-shaped fishes, and on his shelves he had A poverty-stricken collection of empty boxes, and Green earthen pots, animal bladders, and musty smelling seeds, Remnants of leftover twine, and old cakes of roses, Were thinly scattered around, to make up a display.
Noting this penury, to myself I said, ‘An if a man did need a poison now Whose sale is present death in Mantua, Here lives a caitiff wretch would sell it him.’ O, this same thought did but forerun my need, And this same needy man must sell it me.	Noting this poverty, I said to myself, ”If a man did need a poison now, ”The sale of which is punished by death in Mantua, ”Here lives a poor wretch would sell it to him.” O, this same thought only predicted my need, And this same needy man must sell it to me.
As I remember, this should be the house.	As I remember, this should be the house.
Being holiday, the beggar's shop is shut.	Being a holiday, the beggar's shop is closed.
What, ho!	What, hello!
apothecary!	Pharmacist!
Who calls so loud?	Who is calling so loudly?
Come hither, man.	Come here, man.
Let me have A dram of poison, such soon-speeding gear As will disperse itself through all the veins That the life-weary taker may fall dead, And that the trunk may be discharg'd of breath As violently as hasty powder fir'd Doth hurry from the fatal cannon's womb.	Let me have A small vial of poison, such quickly acting medicine That it will disperse itself throughout all the veins In order that the life-weary taker may fall dead, And that the body may suffocate As violently as speedy gunpowder Hurries a bullet from a gun barrel.
Such mortal drugs I have; but Mantua's law Is death to any he that utters them.	I have such deadly drugs, but Mantua's law Gives the death penalty to anybody who sells them.
Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness And fearest to die?	You are so naked and full of misery And you’re afraid to die?
My poverty but not my will consents.	My poverty agrees to take it, but not my will.
I pay thy poverty and not thy will.	I pay your poverty, and not your will.
Put this in any liquid thing you will And drink it off, and if you had the strength Of twenty men, it would dispatch you straight.	Put this poison into any liquid you want, And drink it all; and, if you had the strength Of twenty men, it would kill you right away.
I sell thee poison; thou hast sold me none.	I sell you poison; you haven’t sold me any.

This same should be the voice of Friar John.	This is the voice of Friar John.
Welcome from Mantua.	Welcome from Mantua.
What says Romeo?	What does Romeo say?
Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.	Or, if he wrote his mind, give me his letter.
Going to find a barefoot brother out, One of our order, to associate me Here in this city visiting the sick, And finding him, the searchers of the town, Suspecting that we both were in a house Where the infectious pestilence did reign, Seal'd up the doors, and would not let us forth, So that my speed to Mantua there was stay'd.	Going to find a fellow brother, One of our order, to help me Visit the sick here in this city, And finding him, the searchers of the town, Suspecting that we both were in a house Where the infectious plague was, Sealed up the doors, and wouldn’t let us leave; So that my speed to Mantua was delayed by that.
Who bare my letter, then, to Romeo?	The, who took my letter to Romeo?
I could not send it—here it is again— Nor get a messenger to bring it thee, So fearful were they of infection.	I couldn’t deliver it, so here it is again, I couldn’t even get a messenger to bring it back to you, They were so afraid of getting infected with the plague.
Unhappy fortune!	Very bad luck!
By my brotherhood, The letter was not nice, but full of charge, Of dear import; and the neglecting it May do much danger.	By my brotherhood, The letter was not a social one, but a message Of great importance, and failing to deliver it May do a lot of damage.
Brother, I'll go and bring it thee.	Brother, I'll go and bring it to you.
She will beshrew me much that Romeo Hath had no notice of these accidents; But I will write again to Mantua, And keep her at my cell till Romeo come— Poor living corse, clos'd in a dead man's tomb!	She will really curse me that Romeo Has had no news of these events; But I will write to him again in Mantua, And keep her at my cell until Romeo comes to get her; Poor living corpse, closed in a dead man's tomb!
Give me thy torch, boy.	Give me your torch, boy.

Do as I bid thee, go.	Go, do what I have told you.
I am almost afraid to stand alone Here in the churchyard; yet I will adventure.	I am almost afraid to stand alone Here in the churchyard, but I will stay.
The obsequies that I for thee will keep Nightly shall be to strew thy grave and weep.	I will keep saying the funeral prayers for you, and I will come Every night to put flowers on your grave and weep.
The boy gives warning something doth approach.	The boy gives the warning something is approaching.
What cursed foot wanders this way to-night To cross my obsequies and true love's rite?	What cursed foot wanders this way tonight, To disturb my funeral prayers and the rites of true love?

Muffle me, night, a while.	Night, hide me awhile.

Early in the morning See thou deliver it to my lord and father.	First thing in the morning, See that you deliver it to my lord and father.
Why I descend into this bed of death Is partly to behold my lady's face, But chiefly to take thence from her dead finger A precious ring—a ring that I must use In dear employment.	Why I’m going down into this tomb Is partly to see my lady's face, But mostly to take a precious ring from her dead finger, a ring that I must use In a very special errand.
But if thou, jealous, dost return to pry In what I further shall intend to do, By heaven, I will tear thee joint by joint And strew this hungry churchyard with thy limbs.	But if you return, jealous, and try to find out What I intend to do, By heaven, I will tear you limb from limb, And scatter your limbs all over this hungry churchyard!
The time and my intents are savage-wild, More fierce and more inexorable far Than empty tigers or the roaring sea.	The time and my intents are savage and wild, So much ore fierce and more determined Than hungry tigers or the roaring sea.
I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.	I’ll go, sir, and not trouble you.

Take thou that.	You take that.

His looks I fear, and his intents I doubt.	I fear his looks, and I doubt his reasons.
Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death, Gorg'd with the dearest morsel of the earth, Thus I enforce thy rotten jaws to open, And in despite I'll cram thee with more food.	You hateful belly, you womb of death, Stuffed full with the dearest morsel of the earth, I will force your rotten jaws to open, And, in spite, I'll cram you fuller with more food!
This is that banish'd haughty Montague That murdered my love's cousin—with which grief It is supposed the fair creature died— And here is come to do some villanous shame To the dead bodies.	This man is that banished, arrogant Montague That murdered my love's cousin, by which grief, It is supposed, the beautiful creature died, And he’s come here to desecrate The dead bodies.

Stop thy unhallowed toil, vile Montague!	Stop your unholy work, vile Montague!

By heaven, I love thee better than myself, For I come hither arm'd against myself.	By heaven, I love you better than I love myself, Because I came here only armed against myself.

or did I dream it so?	Or did I dream it?

which their keepers call A lightning before death.	Which their keepers call A lightening before death.

my wife!	My wife!

Beauty's ensign yet Is crimson in thy lips and in thy cheeks, And death's pale flag is not advanced there.	Beauty's officer Is still red on your lips and in your cheeks, And death's pale flag is not yet planted there.

this sight of death is as a bell That warns my old age to a sepulchre.	this sight of death is as a bell That warns my old age to a tomb.

what manners is in this, To press before thy father to a grave?	What kind of manners is it To go to a grave before your father?

Meantime forbear, And let mischance be slave to patience.	In the meantime, do nothing, And let the investigation be do patiently.
Bring forth the parties of suspicion.	Bring out the suspects.
I am the greatest, able to do least, Yet most suspected, as the time and place Doth make against me, of this direful murder; And here I stand, both to impeach and purge Myself condemned and myself excus'd.	I am the greatest, able to do least, Yet most suspected, as the time and place Cast suspicion on me as guilty of this sad murder; And here I stand, both to accuse and free Myself, condemned and myself excused.
Then say at once what thou dost know in this.	Then tell what you know about all of this.
I will be brief, for my short date of breath Is not so long as is a tedious tale.	I will be brief, for I don’t have enough breath to This tedious tale.
Romeo, there dead, was husband to that Juliet; And she, there dead, that Romeo's faithful wife.	Romeo, there dead, was husband to that Juliet; And she, there dead, was Romeo's faithful wife.
I married them; and their stol'n marriage day Was Tybalt's doomsday, whose untimely death Banish'd the new-made bridegroom from this city; For whom, and not for Tybalt, Juliet pin'd.	I married them; and their secret wedding day Was Tybalt's doomsday, whose untimely death Banished the new-made bridegroom from this city, For whom Juliet pined, and not for Tybalt.
You, to remove that siege of grief from her, Betroth'd and would have married her perforce To County Paris.	You, to remove that siege of grief from her, Engaged and would have married her against her will, To Count Paris.
Then comes she to me And with wild looks bid me devise some mean To rid her from this second marriage, Or in my cell there would she kill herself.	Then she comes to me, And with wild looks, asks me to devise some means To get her of this second marriage, Or right there, in my cell, she would kill herself.
Then gave I her (so tutored by my art) A sleeping potion; which so took effect As I intended, for it wrought on her The form of death.	Then gave I her, according to my craft with herbs, A sleeping potion; which took effect As I intended, for it made her Seem dead.
Meantime I writ to Romeo That he should hither come as this dire night To help to take her from her borrowed grave, Being the time the potion's force should cease.	In the meantime, I wrote to Romeo That he should come home, this bad night, To help to take her from her borrowed grave, At the time that the potion would wear off.
But he which bore my letter, Friar John, Was stay'd by accident, and yesternight Return'd my letter back.	But the man who carried my letter, Friar John, Was delayed by accident, and last night Returned my letter to me.
Then all alone At the prefixed hour of her waking Came I to take her from her kindred's vault; Meaning to keep her closely at my cell Till I conveniently could send to Romeo.	Then all alone At the prearranged hour of her waking up, I came to take her from her relative's tomb, Intending to keep her close at my cell Until I could easily send for Romeo.
But when I came, some minute ere the time Of her awaking, here untimely lay The noble Paris and true Romeo dead.	But when I got here, some minutes before the time Of her waking up, here the noble Paris Lay and true Romeo, both untimely dead.

And I, for winking at you, discords too, Have lost a brace of kinsmen.	And I, for disregarding your feud too, Have lost a number of relatives.
All are punish'd.	We are all are punished.

Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here!	Holy Saint Francis, this is a drastic change!
Is Rosaline, whom thou didst love so dear, So soon forsaken?	Have you given up so quickly on Rosaline, whom you loved so much?
Young men’s love then lies Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.	Then young men love with their eyes, not with their hearts.
The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears, Thy old groans ring yet in my ancient ears.	The groans you used to make are still ringing in my old ears.
Lo, here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit Of an old tear that is not washed off yet.	There’s still a stain on your cheek from an old tear that hasn’t been washed off yet.

And is it not well served into a sweet goose?	Then isn’t it just the right dish for a sweet goose?
Oh, here’s a wit of cheveril, that stretches from an inch narrow to an ell broad!	Oh, that’s a joke made out of leather that spreads itself thin, from the width of an inch to as fat as a yard.
I stretch it out for that word “broad,” which, added to the goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.	I stretch my joke for that word “fat.” If you add that word to the word “goose,” it shows that you are a fat goose.

And what to?	And what about that?
Nay, an there were two such, we should have none shortly, for one would kill the other.	If there were two men like you, pretty soon there’d be none because the two of you would kill each other.
Thou, why, thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more or a hair less in his beard than thou hast.	You would fight with a man if he had one more whisker or one less whisker in his beard than you have in your beard.
Thou wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts, having no other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes.	You’ll fight with a man who’s cracking nuts just because you have hazelnut-colored eyes.
What eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel?	Only you would look for a fight like that.
Thy head is as full of quarrels as an egg is full of meat, and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as an egg for quarreling.	Your head is as full of fights as an egg is full of yolk, but your head has been beaten like scrambled eggs from so much fighting.
Thou hast quarreled with a man for coughing in the street because he hath wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun.	You started a fight with a man who coughed in the street because he woke up a dog that was sleeping in the sun.
Didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter?	Didn’t you argue it out with your tailor for wearing one of his new suits before the right season?
With another, for tying his new shoes with old ribbon?	And with another for tying the new shoes he made with old laces?
And yet thou wilt tutor me from quarreling!	And yet you’re the one who wants to teach me about restraint!
An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man should buy the fee simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.	If I were in the habit of fighting the way you are, my life insurance rates would be sky high.
The fee simple?	Your life insurance?
O simple!	That’s foolish.
By my head, here comes the Capulets.	Oh great, here come the Capulets.
By my heel, I care not.	Well, well, I don’t care.
Couple it with something.	Put it together with something else.
Make it a word and a blow.	Make it a word and a blow.
You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you will give me occasion.	You’ll find me ready enough to do that, sir, if you give me a reason.
Could you not take some occasion without giving?	Can’t you find a reason without my giving you one?
Mercutio, thou consort’st with Romeo.	Mercutio, you hang out with Romeo.
What, dost thou make us minstrels?	Hang out?” Who do you think we are, musicians in a band?
An thou make minstrels of us, look to hear nothing but discords.	If we look like musicians to you, you can expect to hear nothing but noise.
We talk here in the public haunt of men.	We’re talking here in a public place.
Either withdraw unto some private place, And reason coldly of your grievances, Or else depart.	Either go someplace private, or talk it over rationally, or else just go away.
Here all eyes gaze on us.	Out here everybody can see us.
Men’s eyes were made to look and let them gaze.	Men’s eyes were made to see things, so let them watch.
I will not budge for no man’s pleasure, I.	I won’t move to please anybody.
Well, peace be with you, sir.	Well, may peace be with you.
Here comes my man.	Here comes my man, the man I’m looking for.
But I’ll be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery.	He’s not your man.
Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee Doth much excuse the appertaining rage To such a greeting.	Tybalt, I have a reason to love you that lets me put aside the rage I should feel and excuse that insult.
Villain am I none.	I am no villain.
Therefore, farewell.	So, goodbye.
I see thou know’st me not.	I can tell that you don’t know who I am.
Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries That thou hast done me.	Boy, your words can’t excuse the harm you’ve done to me.
Therefore turn and draw.	So now turn and draw your sword.
And so, good Capulet—which name I tender As dearly as my own—be satisfied.	And so, good Capulet—which is a name I love like my own name—you should be satisfied with what I say.
O calm dishonourable, vile submission!	This calm submission is dishonorable and vile.
What wouldst thou have with me?	What do you want from me?
Will you pluck your sword out of his pilcher by the ears?	Will you pull your sword out of its sheath?
Make haste, lest mine be about your ears ere it be out.	Hurry up, or I’ll smack you on the ears with my sword before you have yours drawn.
I am for you.	I’ll fight you.
Gentle Mercutio, put thy rapier up.	Noble Mercutio, put your sword away.
Away, Tybalt.	Let’s get away, Tybalt.
I am hurt.	I’ve been hurt.
A plague o' both your houses!	May a plague curse both your families.
I am sped.	I’m finished.
Is he gone and hath nothing?	Did he get away clean?
What, art thou hurt?	What, are you hurt?
Marry, ’tis enough.	But it’s enough.
Where is my page?—Go, villain, fetch a surgeon.	Where is my page?
Courage, man.	Have courage, man.
The hurt cannot be much.	The wound can’t be that bad.
No, ’tis not so deep as a well nor so wide as a church-door, but ’tis enough, ’twill serve.	No, it’s not as deep as a well, or as wide as a church door, but it’s enough.
Ask for me tomorrow, and you shall find me a grave man.	Ask for me tomorrow, and you’ll find me in a grave.
I am peppered, I warrant, for this world.	I’m done for in this world, I believe.
A plague o' both your houses!	May a plague strike both your houses.
Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a cat to scratch a man to death!	I can’t believe that dog, that rat, that mouse, that cat could scratch me to death!
A braggart, a rogue, a villain that fights by the book of arithmetic!	That braggart, punk villain who fights like he learned swordsmanship from a manual!
Why the devil came you between us?	Why the hell did you come in between us?
I was hurt under your arm.	He struck me from under your arm.
I thought all for the best.	I thought it was the right thing to do.
Help me into some house, Benvolio, Or I shall faint.	Take me inside some house, Benvolio, or I’ll pass out.
A plague o' both your houses!	May a plague strike both your families!
They have made worms' meat of me.	They’ve turned me into food for worms.
I have it, And soundly too.	I’m done for.
Your houses!	Curse your families!
O Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead!	Oh Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead!
Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.	Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.
Alive in triumph—and Mercutio slain!	He’s alive and victorious, and Mercutio’s dead?
Either thou or I, or both, must go with him.	Either you, or I, or both of us have to go with him.
Thou, wretched boy, that didst consort him here Shalt with him hence.	Wretched boy, you hung out with him here, and you’re going to go to heaven with him.
This shall determine that.	This fight will decide who dies.
Romeo, away, be gone!	Romeo, get out of here.
The citizens are up, and Tybalt slain.	The citizens are around, and Tybalt is dead.
Stand not amazed.	Don’t stand there shocked.
The Prince will doom thee death If thou art taken.	The Prince will give you the death penalty if you get caught.
Hence, be gone, away!	So get out of here!
Why dost thou stay?	Why are you waiting?
Which way ran he that killed Mercutio?	The man who killed Mercutio, which way did he go?
Tybalt, that murderer, which way ran he?	Tybalt, that murderer, which way did he run?
There lies that Tybalt.	Tybalt is lying over there.
Speak, nephew.	Speak, nephew.
Were you by when it began?	Were you here when it started?
Where are the vile beginners of this fray?	Where are the evil men who started this fight?
O noble prince, I can discover all The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl.	Oh, noble prince, I can tell you everything about the unfortunate circumstances of this deadly fight.
There lies the man, slain by young Romeo, That slew thy kinsman, brave Mercutio.	He killed your relative, brave Mercutio, and then young Romeo killed him.
Tybalt, my cousin!	Tybalt was my nephew!
O my brother’s child!	He was my brother’s son!
O cousin, cousin!	Oh cousin, cousin!
Benvolio, who began this bloody fray?	Benvolio, who started this fight?
Romeo, he cries aloud, “Hold, friends!	Romeo cried out, “Stop, my friends.
Friends, part!” and, swifter than his tongue, His agile arm beats down their fatal points, And ’twixt them rushes—underneath whose arm An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled.	Break it up.” Then he jumped in between them and forced them to put their swords down.
But by and by comes back to Romeo, Who had but newly entertained revenge, And to ’t they go like lightning, for ere I Could draw to part them was stout Tybalt slain.	Before I could break up the fight, Tybalt was killed.
And, as he fell, did Romeo turn and fly.	Romeo ran away when Tybalt fell dead.
This is the truth, or let Benvolio die.	Benvolio is part of the Montague family.
He speaks not true.	He’s not telling the truth.
Some twenty of them fought in this black strife, And all those twenty could but kill one life.	There were twenty Montagues fighting in this awful riot, and together those twenty could only kill one man.
I beg for justice, which thou, Prince, must give.	You, Prince, are the man who can give me justice.
Romeo slew Tybalt.	Romeo killed Tybalt.
Romeo must not live.	Romeo must die.
Romeo slew him; he slew Mercutio.	Romeo killed Tybalt.
Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?	Who should now pay the price for Mercutio’s life?
His fault concludes but what the law should end, The life of Tybalt.	His crime did justice’s job by taking Tybalt’s life.
I have an interest in your hearts' proceeding.	I’m involved in your rivalry.
But I’ll amerce you with so strong a fine That you shall all repent the loss of mine.	I’ll punish you so harshly that you’ll regret causing me this loss.
I will be deaf to pleading and excuses.	I won’t listen to your pleas or excuses.
Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses, Therefore use none.	You can’t get out of trouble by praying or crying, so don’t bother.
Bear hence this body and attend our will.	Take away this body, and do what I say.
Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.	Showing mercy by pardoning killers only causes more murders.
Lovers can see to do their amorous rites By their own beauties, or, if love be blind, It best agrees with night.	Or else love is blind, and its best time is the night.
Come, civil night, Thou sober-suited matron, all in black, And learn me how to lose a winning match Played for a pair of stainless maidenhoods.	I wish night would come, like a widow dressed in black, so I can learn how to submit to my husband and lose my virginity.
Hood my unmanned blood bating in my cheeks, With thy black mantle, till strange love, grow bold, Think true love acted simple modesty.	Let the blood rushing to my cheeks be calmed.
Come, night.	Come, night.
Come, Romeo.	Come, Romeo.
Come, thou day in night, For thou wilt lie upon the wings of night Whiter than new snow upon a raven’s back.	You’re whiter than snow on the black wings of a raven.
And when I shall die, Take him and cut him out in little stars, And he will make the face of heaven so fine That all the world will be in love with night And pay no worship to the garish sun.	His face will make the heavens so beautiful that the world will fall in love with the night and forget about the garish sun.
The cords That Romeo bid thee fetch?	Is that the rope ladder Romeo told you to pick up?
Ay, ay, the cords.	Yes, yes, this is the rope ladder.
Ay me, what news?	Oh my, what’s the news?
Why dost thou wring thy hands?	Why do you look so upset?
Ah, welladay!	He’s dead.
We are undone, lady, we are undone!	We’re ruined, lady, we’re ruined!
Alack the day!	What an awful day!
Can heaven be so envious?	Can God be so jealous and hateful?
Romeo can, Though heaven cannot.	Romeo is hateful, even though God isn’t.
What devil art thou that dost torment me thus?	What kind of devil are you to torture me like this?
This torture should be roared in dismal hell.	This is as bad as the tortures of hell.
Hath Romeo slain himself?	Has Romeo killed himself?
Say thou but “ay,” And that bare vowel  Than the death-darting eye of cockatrice.	Just say “Yes” and I will turn more poisonous than the snake with the evil eye.
I am not I if there be such an  Or those eyes shut that makes thee answer “ay.” If he be slain, say “ay,” or if not, “no.” Brief sounds determine of my weal or woe.	If he’s been killed, say “Yes.” If not, say “No.” These short words will determine my joy or my pain.
To prison, eyes, ne'er look on liberty.	I’ll send my eyes to prison, and they’ll never be free to look at anything again.
Vile earth, to earth resign.	I’ll give my vile body back to the earth.
O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I had!	Oh, Tybalt, Tybalt, he was the best friend I had.
That ever I should live to see thee dead.	I wish I had not lived long enough to see him die.
Is Romeo slaughtered, and is Tybalt dead?	Has Romeo been killed, and is Tybalt dead too?
My dearest cousin and my dearer lord?	Tybalt was my dearest cousin.
Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banishèd.	Tybalt is dead, and Romeo has been banished.
O God, did Romeo’s hand shed Tybalt’s blood?	Oh God, did Romeo’s hand shed Tybalt’s blood?
It did, it did.	It did, it did.
Alas the day, it did.	Curse the day this happened, but it did.
O serpent heart hid with a flowering face!	Oh, he’s like a snake disguised as a flower.
Did ever dragon keep so fair a cave?	Did a dragon ever hide in such a beautiful cave?
Dove-feathered raven, wolvish-ravening lamb!	He’s a raven with the feathers of the dove.
O nature, what hadst thou to do in hell When thou didst bower the spirit of a fiend In moral paradise of such sweet flesh?	Oh nature, what were you doing in hell?
Was ever book containing such vile matter So fairly bound?	Was there ever such an evil book with such a beautiful cover?
Ah, where’s my man?—Give me some aqua vitae.— These griefs, these woes, these sorrows make me old.	Ah, where’s my servant?—Give me some brandy.—These griefs, these pains, these sorrows make me old.
Shame come to Romeo!	Shame on Romeo!
Blistered be thy tongue For such a wish!	I hope sores cover your tongue for a wish like that!
He was not born to shame.	He was not born to be shameful.
Upon his brow shame is ashamed to sit, For ’tis a throne where honor may be crowned.	He deserves only honor, complete honor.
Sole monarch of the universal earth, Oh, what a beast was I to chide at him!	Oh, I was such a beast to be angry at him.
Will you speak well of him that killed your cousin?	Are you going to say good things about the man who killed your cousin?
But wherefore, villain, didst thou kill my cousin?	But why, you villain, did you kill my cousin?
That villain cousin would have killed my husband.	Probably because my cousin the villain would have killed my husband.
All this is comfort.	All this is comforting news.
Wherefore weep I then?	Why, then, should I cry?
I would forget it fain, But oh, it presses to my memory, Like damnèd guilty deeds to sinners' minds.	I would be glad to forget about it, but it weighs on my memory like sins linger in guilty minds.
Tybalt is dead, and Romeo banishèd.”	Tybalt is dead, and Romeo has been banished.”
That “banishèd,” that one word “banishèd” Hath slain ten thousand Tybalts.	That banishment is worse than the murder of ten thousand Tybalts.
Tybalt’s death Was woe enough, if it had ended there.	Tybalt’s death would be bad enough if that was all.
Or, if sour woe delights in fellowship And needly will be ranked with other griefs, Why followed not, when she said “Tybalt’s dead,” “Thy father” or “thy mother,” nay, or both, Which modern lamentations might have moved?	It would have been better if, after she said, “Tybalt’s dead,” she told me my mother or my father, or both, were gone.
But with a rearward following Tybalt’s death, “Romeo is banishèd.” To speak that word, Is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet, All slain, all dead.	But to say that Tybalt’s dead and then say, “Romeo has been banished.” To say that is like saying that my father, my mother, Tybalt, Romeo, and Juliet have all been killed, they’re all dead.
Romeo is banishèd.” There is no end, no limit, measure, bound, In that word’s death.	Romeo has been banished.” That news brings infinite death.
No words can that woe sound.	No words can express the pain.
Where is my father and my mother, Nurse?	Where are my father and my mother, Nurse?
Weeping and wailing over Tybalt’s corse.	They are crying and moaning over Tybalt’s corpse.
Will you go to them?	Are you going to join them?
I will bring you thither.	I’ll bring you there.
Wash they his wounds with tears?	Are they washing out his wounds with their tears?
Mine shall be spent When theirs are dry, for Romeo’s banishment.	I’ll cry my tears for Romeo’s banishment when their tears are dry.
Take up those cords.—Poor ropes, you are beguiled, Both you and I, for Romeo is exiled.	Pick up this rope ladder.
He made you for a highway to my bed, But I, a maid, die maiden-widowèd.	He made this rope ladder to be a highway to my bed, but I am a virgin, and I will die a virgin and a widow.
And death, not Romeo, take my maidenhead!	And death, not Romeo, can take my virginity!
Hie to your chamber.	Go to your bedroom.
I’ll find Romeo To comfort you.	I’ll find Romeo to comfort you.
I wot well where he is.	I know where he is.
Hark ye, your Romeo will be here at night.	Listen, your Romeo will be here tonight.
I’ll to him.	I’ll go to him.
He is hid at Lawrence' cell.	He’s hiding out in Friar Lawrence’s cell.
Romeo, come forth.	Romeo, come out.
Come forth, thou fearful man.	Come out, you frightened man.
Father, what news?	Father, what’s the news?
Too familiar Is my dear son with such sour company.	You know too much about suffering.
I bring thee tidings of the Prince’s doom.	I have news for you about the Prince’s punishment.
What less than doomsday is the Prince’s doom?	Is the Prince’s punishment any less awful than doomsday?
Ha, banishment!	Ha, banishment?
Be merciful, say “death,” For exile hath more terror in his look, Much more than death.	Be merciful and say “death.” Exile is much worse than death.
Do not say “banishment.” Hence from Verona art thou banishèd.	Don’t say “banishment.” From now on, you are banished from Verona.
Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.	You should be able to endure this because the world is broad and wide.
There is no world without Verona walls But purgatory, torture, hell itself.	There is no world for me outside the walls of Verona, except purgatory, torture, and hell itself.
Hence “banishèd” is banished from the world, And world’s exile is death.	So to be banished from Verona is like being banished from the world, and being banished from the world is death.
Calling death “banishment,” Thou cutt’st my head off with a golden ax And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.	Calling death banishment is like cutting off my head with a golden ax and smiling while I’m being murdered.
O deadly sin!	Oh, deadly sin!
O rude unthankfulness!	Oh, rude and unthankful boy!
Tis torture and not mercy.	It’s torture, not mercy.
More validity, More honorable state, more courtship lives In carrion flies than Romeo.	Flies are healthier and more honorable and better suited for romance than Romeo.
Flies may do this, but I from this must fly.	Flies can kiss her, but I must flee the city.
They are free men, but I am banishèd.	Flies are like free men, but I have been banished.
And sayst thou yet that exile is not death?	And yet you say that exile is not death?
Hadst thou no poison mixed, no sharp-ground knife, No sudden mean of death, though ne'er so mean, But “banishèd” to kill me?—“Banishèd”!	Did you have no poison, no sharp knife, no weapon you could use to kill me quickly, nothing so disgraceful, except banishment?
O Friar, the damnèd use that word in hell.	Oh Friar, damned souls use the word banishment to describe hell.
Howling attends it.	They howl about banishment.
How hast thou the heart, Being a divine, a ghostly confessor, A sin-absolver, and my friend professed, To mangle me with that word “banishèd”?	If you’re a member of a divine spiritual order of men who forgive sins, and you say you’re my friend, how do you have the heart to mangle me with the word banishment?
Thou fond mad man, hear me a little speak.	You foolish madman, listen to me for a moment.
Here were the servants of your adversary, And yours, close fighting ere I did approach.	Your servants were fighting your enemy’s servants before I got here.
I drew to part them.	I drew my sword to part them.
While we were interchanging thrusts and blows, Came more and more and fought on part and part, Till the Prince came, who parted either part.	As we were trading blows, more and more people showed up to join the fight, until the Prince came and broke everyone up.
Oh, where is Romeo?	Oh, where’s Romeo?
Saw you him today?	Have you seen him today?
Right glad I am he was not at this fray.	I’m glad he wasn’t here for this fight.
Towards him I made, but he was 'ware of me And stole into the covert of the wood.	I headed toward him, but he saw me coming and hid in the woods.
Many a morning hath he there been seen, With tears augmenting the fresh morning’s dew, Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs.	He’s been seen there many mornings, crying tears that add drops to the morning dew and making a cloudy day cloudier with his sighs.
But all so soon as the all-cheering sun Should in the farthest east begin to draw The shady curtains from Aurora’s bed, Away from light steals home my heavy son,	But as soon as the sun rises in the east, my sad son comes home to escape the light.
Oh, thou wilt speak again of banishment.	Oh, you’re just going to talk about banishment again.
Talk no more.	Don’t say anything else.
Oh, then I see that madmen have no ears.	Oh, so madmen like you are also deaf.
How should they, when that wise men have no eyes?	How should madmen hear, if wise men can’t even see?
Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.	Let me talk to you about your situation.
Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not feel.	You can’t talk about something that you don’t feel.
Wert thou as young as I, Juliet thy love, An hour but married, Tybalt murderèd, Doting like me, and like me banishèd, Then mightst thou speak, then mightst thou tear thy hair And fall upon the ground, as I do now, Taking the measure of an unmade grave.	If you were as young as I am, if you were in love with Juliet, if you had just married her an hour ago, if then you murdered Tybalt, if you were lovesick like me, and if you were banished, then you might talk about it.
Arise.	Get up.
One knocks.	Somebody’s knocking.
Good Romeo, hide thyself.	Hide yourself, good Romeo.
Not I, unless the breath of heartsick groans, Mistlike, infold me from the search of eyes.	I won’t hide unless all the mist from my heartsick groans envelopes me like fog and conceals me from people’s searching eyes.
Who knocks so hard?	Why are you knocking so hard?
Whence come you?	Where do you come from?
What’s your will?	What do you want?
O holy Friar, O, tell me, holy Friar, Where is my lady’s lord?	Oh, holy Friar, Oh, tell me, holy Friar, where is my lady’s husband?
Where’s Romeo?	Where’s Romeo?
Oh, he is even in my mistress' case, Just in her case.	Oh, he’s acting just like Juliet, just like her.
O woeful sympathy, Piteous predicament!	Oh painful sympathy!
Even so lies she, Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering.	She’s lying on the ground just like him, blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering.
Stand, an you be a man.	Stand up if you’re really a man.
For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand.	For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand up.
Why should you fall into so deep an O?	Why should you fall into so deep a moan?
Nurse!	Nurse!
Ah sir, ah sir.	Ah sir, ah sir.
Death’s the end of all.	Well, death is the end for everybody.
Spakest thou of Juliet?	Were you talking about Juliet?
How is it with her?	How is she?
Where is she?	Where is she?
And how doth she?	How is she doing?
And what says My concealed lady to our canceled love?	What does my hidden wife say about our ruined love?
As if that name, Shot from the deadly level of a gun, Did murder her, as that name’s cursed hand Murdered her kinsman.	She’s calling out my name as if I were a bullet murdering her, just like I murdered her relative.
O, tell me, Friar, tell me, In what vile part of this anatomy Doth my name lodge?	Tell me, Friar, in what part of my body is my name embedded?
Tell me, that I may sack The hateful mansion.	Tell me, so I can cut it out of myself.
Art thou a man?	Are you a man?
Thy wild acts denote The unreasonable fury of a beast.	Your wild actions resemble the irrational fury of a beast.
Thou hast amazed me.	You have amazed me.
By my holy order, I thought thy disposition better tempered.	I swear by my holy order, I thought you were smarter and more rational than this.
Hast thou slain Tybalt?	Have you killed Tybalt?
Why rail’st thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth?	Why do you complain about your birth, the heavens, and the earth?
Fie, fie, thou shamest thy shape, thy love, thy wit, Which, like a usurer, abound’st in all And usest none in that true use indeed Which should bedeck thy shape, thy love, thy wit.	You have so much natural talent, but like someone who hoards money, you use none of your talent for the right purpose—not your body, not your love, not your mind.
What, rouse thee, man!	Get up, man!
Thy Juliet is alive, For whose dear sake thou wast but lately dead— There art thou happy.	Your Juliet is alive.
Tybalt would kill thee, But thou slew’st Tybalt—there art thou happy.	Tybalt wanted to kill you, but you killed Tybalt.
The law that threatened death becomes thy friend And turns it to exile—there art thou happy.	Be happy that you’re alive.
A pack of blessings light upon thy back, Happiness courts thee in her best array,	You have the best sorts of happiness to enjoy.
But, like a misbehaved and sullen wench, Thou pout’st upon thy fortune and thy love.	But like a misbehaved, sullen girl, you’re whining about your bad luck and your love.
Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed.	Go be with your love, as it was decided at your wedding.
Ascend her chamber, hence, and comfort her.	Climb up to her bedroom and comfort her.
Commend me to thy lady, And bid her hasten all the house to bed, Which heavy sorrow makes them apt unto.	Give my regards to your lady, and tell her to hurry everybody in the house to bed.
Romeo is coming.	Romeo is coming.
O Lord, I could have stayed here all the night To hear good counsel.	O Lord, I could stay here all night listening to such good advice.
Oh, what learning is!	Educated men are so impressive!
Do so, and bid my sweet prepare to chide.	Do so, and tell my sweet to be ready to scold me.
Here, sir, a ring she bid me give you, sir.	Here, sir, this is a ring she asked me to give you.
Hie you, make haste, for it grows very late.	Hurry up, it’s getting late.
How well my comfort is revived by this!	This makes me feel so much better!
Go hence.	Now get out of here.
Good night.	Good night.
And here stands all your state: Either be gone before the watch be set, Or by the break of day disguised from hence.	Everything depends on this: either be out of here before the night watchmen take their positions, or leave in disguise after daybreak.
Sojourn in Mantua.	Take a little vacation in Mantua.
I’ll find out your man, And he shall signify from time to time Every good hap to you that chances here.	I’ll find your servant, and he’ll update you now and then on your case as it stands here.
Give me thy hand.	Give me your hand.
Tis late.	It’s late.
Farewell.	Farewell.
Things have fall'n out, sir, so unluckily, That we have had no time to move our daughter.	Things have turned out so unluckily, sir, that we haven’t had time to convince our daughter to marry you.
Look you, she loved her kinsman Tybalt dearly, And so did I.	Listen, she loved her cousin Tybalt dearly, and so did I.
Well, we were born to die.	Well, we were all born to die.
These times of woe afford no time to woo.	These times of pain are bad times for romance.
Madam, good night.	Madam, good night.
Commend me to your daughter.	Give my regards to your daughter.
I will, and know her mind early tomorrow.	I will.
Tonight she is mewed up to her heaviness.	Tonight she is shut up in her room, alone with her sadness.
Sir Paris, I will make a desperate tender Of my child’s love.	Sir Paris, I’ll make a desperate argument for my child’s love.
Acquaint her here of my son Paris' love, And bid her, mark you me, on Wednesday next— But, soft!	Tell her about my son Paris’s love for her.
What day is this?	And tell her, listen to me, on Wednesday—Wait—What day is today?
Monday, my lord.	Monday, my lord.
Monday!	Monday!
Ha, ha.	Ha, ha!
Do you like this haste?	Do you think it’s a good idea to rush?
We’ll keep no great ado, a friend or two.	We shouldn’t have too big a celebration—we can invite a friend or two.
For, hark you, Tybalt being slain so late, It may be thought we held him carelessly, Being our kinsman, if we revel much.	Listen, because Tybalt was just killed, people might think that we don’t care about his memory as our relative if we have too grand a party.
Therefore we’ll have some half a dozen friends, And there an end.	Therefore we’ll have about half a dozen friends to the wedding, and that’s it.
But what say you to Thursday?	What do you think about Thursday?
My lord, I would that Thursday were tomorrow.	My lord, I wish Thursday were tomorrow.
Well get you gone.	Well go on home.
O' Thursday be it, then.— Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed.	Thursday it is, then.
Wilt thou be gone?	Are you going?
It is not yet near day.	It’s still a long time until daybreak.
It was the nightingale, and not the lark, That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear.	That sound you heard was the  It was the lark, the bird that sings at dawn, not the nightingale.
Look, love, what envious streaks Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east.	Look, my love, what are those streaks of light in the clouds parting in the east?
Night’s candles are burnt out, and jocund day Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops.	Night is over, and day is coming.
Yon light is not daylight, I know it, I.	That light is not daylight, I know it.
It is some meteor that the sun exhales To be to thee this night a torchbearer, And light thee on thy way to Mantua.	It’s some meteor coming out of the sun to light your way to Mantua.
Therefore stay yet.	So stay for a while.
Thou need’st not to be gone.	You don’t have to go yet.
Let me be ta'en.	Let me be captured.
Let me be put to death.	Let me be put to death.
I am content, so thou wilt have it so.	I am content, if that’s the way you want it.
I have more care to stay than will to go.	I want to stay more than I want to go.
Come, death, and welcome!	Come, death, and welcome!
Let’s talk.	Let’s talk.
It is not day.	It’s not daylight.
It is, it is.	It is, it is.
It is the lark that sings so out of tune, Straining harsh discords and unpleasing sharps.	It’s the lark that sings so out of tune, making such harsh noise.
Some say the lark makes sweet division.	Some say the lark makes a sweet division between day and night.
This doth not so, for she divideth us.	It’s not true because she separates us.
More light and light it grows.	More and more light.
More light and light, more dark and dark our woes!	More and more pain for us.
Madam.	Madam.
Nurse?	Nurse?
Your lady mother is coming to your chamber.	Your mother is coming to your bedroom.
The day is broke.	Day has broken.
Then, window, let day in and let life out.	Then the window lets day in, and life goes out the window.
Farewell, farewell.	Farewell, farewell!
One kiss, and I’ll descend.	Give me one kiss, and I’ll go down.
And private in his chamber pens himself, Shuts up his windows, locks fair daylight out, And makes himself an artificial night.	He locks himself up alone in his bedroom, shuts his windows to keep out the beautiful daylight, and makes himself an artificial night.
My noble uncle, do you know the cause?	My noble uncle, do you know why he acts this way?
I neither know it nor can learn of him.	I don’t know, and he won’t tell me.
Have you importuned him by any means?	Have you done everything you could to make him tell you the reason?
I would thou wert so happy by thy stay To hear true shrift.—Come, madam, let’s away.	I hope you’re lucky enough to hear the true story by sticking around.
Art thou gone so, love, lord?	Are you gone like that, my love, my lord?
Oh, by this count I shall be much in years Ere I again behold my Romeo.	Oh, by this count I’ll be many years older before I see my Romeo again.
Farewell!	Farewell!
I will omit no opportunity That may convey my greetings, love, to thee.	I won’t miss any chance to send my love to you.
Oh, think’st thou we shall ever meet again?	Oh, do you think we’ll ever meet again?
O God, I have an ill-divining soul.	Oh God, I have a soul that predicts evil things!
Methinks I see thee now, thou art so low As one dead in the bottom of a tomb.	Now that you are down there, you look like someone dead in the bottom of a tomb.
Either my eyesight fails, or thou look’st pale.	Either my eyesight is failing me, or you look pale.
And trust me, love, in my eye so do you.	And trust me, love, you look pale to me too.
Dry sorrow drinks our blood.	Sadness takes away our color.
Adieu, adieu!	Goodbye, Goodbye!
O fortune, fortune!	Oh luck, luck.
All men call thee fickle.	Everyone says you can’t make up your mind.
Be fickle, fortune, For then, I hope, thou wilt not keep him long, But send him back.	I hope maybe then you’ll send him back home soon.
Who is ’t that calls?	Who’s that calling?
Is it my lady mother?	Is it my mother?
What unaccustomed cause procures her hither?	What strange reason could she have for coming here?
Why, how now, Juliet?	What’s going on, Juliet?
Madam, I am not well.	Madam, I am not well.
Evermore weeping for your cousin’s death?	Will you cry about your cousin’s death forever?
What, wilt thou wash him from his grave with tears?	Are you trying to wash him out of his grave with tears?
An if thou couldst, thou couldst not make him live.	If you could, you couldn’t bring him back to life.
Therefore, have done.	So stop crying.
Some grief shows much of love, But much of grief shows still some want of wit.	A little bit of grief shows a lot of love.
Yet let me weep for such a feeling loss.	Let me keep weeping for such a great loss.
So shall you feel the loss, but not the friend Which you weep for.	You will feel the loss, but the man you weep for will feel nothing.
Feeling so the loss, Cannot choose but ever weep the friend.	Feeling the loss like this, I can’t help but weep for him forever.
Well, girl, thou weep’st not so much for his death, As that the villain lives which slaughtered him.	Well, girl, you’re weeping not for his death as much as for the fact that the villain who killed him is still alive.
What villain, madam?	What villain, madam?
That same villain, Romeo.	That villain, Romeo.
That is because the traitor murderer lives.	That’s because the murderer is alive.
Ay, madam, from the reach of these my hands.	Yes, madam, he lies beyond my reach.
Would none but I might venge my cousin’s death!	I wish that no one could avenge my cousin’s death except me!
Then weep no more.	Stop crying.
I’ll send to one in Mantua, Where that same banished runagate doth live, Shall give him such an unaccustomed dram That he shall soon keep Tybalt company.	I’ll send a man to Mantua, where that exiled rogue is living.
And then, I hope, thou wilt be satisfied.	And then, I hope, you’ll be satisfied.
Indeed, I never shall be satisfied With Romeo, till I behold him—dead— Is my poor heart for a kinsman vexed.	I’ll never be satisfied with Romeo until I see him .
Madam, if you could find out but a man To bear a poison, I would temper it, That Romeo should, upon receipt thereof, Soon sleep in quiet.	Madam, if you can find a man to deliver the poison, I’ll mix it myself so that Romeo will sleep quietly soon after he drinks it.
To wreak the love I bore my cousin Upon his body that slaughtered him!	I want to take the love I had for my cousin and take it out on the body of the man who killed him.
Find thou the means, and I’ll find such a man.	Find out the way, and I’ll find the right man.
But now I’ll tell thee joyful tidings, girl.	But now I have joyful news for you, girl.
And joy comes well in such a needy time.	And it’s good to have joy in such a joyless time.
What are they, beseech your ladyship?	Please tell me.
Well, well, thou hast a careful father, child.	Well, well, you have a careful father, child.
Madam, in happy time, what day is that?	Madam, tell me quickly, what day is that?
Marry, my child, early next Thursday morn, The gallant, young, and noble gentleman, The County Paris, at Saint Peter’s Church, Shall happily make thee there a joyful bride.	Indeed, my child, at Saint Peter’s Church early Thursday morning, the gallant, young, and noble gentleman Count Paris will happily make you a joyful bride.
Now, by Saint Peter’s Church and Peter too, He shall not make me there a joyful bride.	Now, I swear by Saint Peter’s Church and Peter too, he will not make me a joyful bride there.
I wonder at this haste, that I must wed Ere he, that should be husband, comes to woo.	How can I marry him, this husband, before he comes to court me?
I pray you, tell my lord and father, madam, I will not marry yet.	Please, tell my father, madam, I won’t marry yet.
And when I do, I swear It shall be Romeo, whom you know I hate, Rather than Paris.	And, when I do marry, I swear, it will be Romeo, whom you know I hate, rather than Paris.
These are news indeed!	That’s really news!
Here comes your father.	Here comes your father.
Tell him so yourself, And see how he will take it at your hands.	Tell him so yourself, and see how he takes the news.
How now?	What are you, girl?
A conduit, girl?	Some kind of fountain?
What, still in tears, Evermore showering?	Why are you still crying?

I would the fool were married to her grave!	I wish the fool were dead and married to her grave!
How, will she none?	How can this be?
Is she not proud?	Isn’t she proud of such a match?

How, how, how, how?	What is this?

Proud,” and “I thank you,” and “I thank you not,” And yet “not proud”?	I hear you say “proud” and “I thank you,” and then “no thank you” and “not proud,” you spoiled little girl.

God in heaven bless her!	God in heaven bless her!

Smatter with your gossips, go.	Go blabber with your gossiping friends.
I speak no treason.	I’ve said nothing wrong.
Oh, God 'i' good e'en.	Oh, for God’s sake.

You are too hot.	You’re getting too angry.
God’s bread!	Goddammit!
It makes me mad.	It makes me mad.
Day, night, hour, tide, time, work, play, Alone, in company, still my care hath been To have her matched.	Day and night, hour after hour, all the time, at work, at play, alone, in company, my top priority has always been to find her a husband.

Beshrew my very heart, I think you are happy in this second match, For it excels your first.	Curse my very heart, but I think you should be happy in this second marriage, because it’s better than your first.

Ay, forsooth.	Yes, that’s true.

Alack the day.	Curse the day!
She’s dead, she’s dead, she’s dead!	She’s dead, she’s dead, she’s dead!
Ha?	No!
Let me see her.	Let me see her.
Out, alas!	Oh no!
She’s cold.	She’s cold.
Her blood is settled, and her joints are stiff.	Her blood has stopped, and her joints are stiff.
Life and these lips have long been separated.	She’s been dead for some time.
Death lies on her like an untimely frost Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.	She’s dead, like a beautiful flower, killed by an unseasonable frost.
O lamentable day!	Oh, sad day!
O woeful time.	Oh, this is a painful time!
Death, that hath ta'en her hence to make me wail, Ties up my tongue and will not let me speak.	Death, which has taken her away to make me cry, now ties up my tongue and won’t let me speak.
Come, is the bride ready to go to church?	Come, is the bride ready to go to church?
Ready to go, but never to return.	She’s ready to go, but she’ll never return.
Death is my son-in-law.	Death is my son-in-law.
Death is my heir.	Death is my heir.
My daughter he hath wedded.	My daughter married death.
I will die, And leave him all.	I will die and leave Death everything.
Life, living, all is Death’s.	Life, wealth, everything belongs to Death.
Have I thought long to see this morning’s face, And doth it give me such a sight as this?	Have I waited so long to see this morning, only to see this?
Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day!	Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day!
Most miserable hour that e'er time saw In lasting labor of his pilgrimage.	This is the most miserable hour of all time!
But one, poor one, one poor and loving child, But one thing to rejoice and solace in, And cruel death hath catched it from my sight!	I had only one child, one poor child, one poor and loving child, the one thing I had to rejoice and comfort myself, and cruel Death has stolen it from me!
O woe!	Oh pain!
O woeful, woeful, woeful day!	Oh painful, painful, painful day!
Never was seen so black a day as this.	There has never been so black a day as today.
O woeful day, O woeful day!	Oh painful day, Oh painful day!
Beguiled, divorcèd, wrongèd, spited, slain!	She was tricked, divorced, wronged, spited, killed!
Most detestable Death, by thee beguiled, By cruel, cruel thee quite overthrown!	Cruel, cruel Death killed her.
O love!	Oh love!
O life!	Oh life!
Not life, but love in death.	There is no life, but my love is dead!
Despised, distressèd, hated, martyred, killed!	Despised, distressed, hated, martyred, killed!
Uncomfortable time, why camest thou now To murder, murder our solemnity?	Why did this have to happen now?
My soul, and not my child!	My soul and not my child!
Dead art thou!	You are dead!
Peace, ho, for shame!	Be quiet, for shame!
Confusion’s cure lives not In these confusions.	The cure for confusion is not yelling and screaming.
Heaven and yourself Had part in this fair maid.	You had this child with the help of heaven.
Now heaven hath all,	Now heaven has her.
And all the better is it for the maid.	She is in a better place.
Your part in her you could not keep from death, But heaven keeps his part in eternal life.	You could not prevent her from dying someday, but heaven will give her eternal life.
The most you sought was her promotion, For ’twas your heaven she should be advanced.	The most you hope for was for her to marry wealthy and rise up the social ladder—that was your idea of heaven.
And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?	And now you cry, even though she has risen up above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?
Oh, in this love, you love your child so ill That you run mad, seeing that she is well.	Oh, in this love, you love your child so badly, that you go mad, even though she is in heaven.
She’s not well married that lives married long, But she’s best married that dies married young.	It is best to marry well and die young, better than to be married for a long time.
Our instruments to melancholy bells, Our wedding cheer to a sad burial feast.	Our wedding banquet will become a sad burial feast.
Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change, Our bridal flowers serve for a buried corse, And all things change them to the contrary.	Our celebratory hymns will change to sad funeral marches.
Every one prepare To follow this fair corse unto her grave.	Everyone prepare to take this beautiful corpse to her grave.
The heavens do lour upon you for some ill. Move them no more by crossing their high will.	Don’t disturb the heavens any more by trying to go against heaven’s will.
Faith, we may put up our pipes and be gone.	Well, we can put away our pipes and go home.
Ay, by my troth, the case may be amended.	Yes, well, things could get better.
Not a dump, we.	No, not a sad song.
Tis no time to play now.	It’s not the right time to play.
You will not then?	You won’t, then?
No.	No.
I will then give it you soundly.	Then I’ll really give it to you.
What will you give us?	What will you give us?
No money, on my faith, but the gleek.	No money, I swear.
I will give you the minstrel.	I’ll call you a minstrel.
Then I will give you the serving creature.	Then I’ll call you a serving-creature.
Then will I lay the serving creature’s dagger on your pate.	Then I’ll smack you on the head with the serving-creature’s knife.
I will carry no crotchets.	I’ll make you sing.
Then have at you with my wit.	Do you hear me?
Answer me like men.	Answer me like men.
Marry, sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.	Well, sir, because silver has a sweet sound.
Prates too.—What say you, James Soundpost?	Another studpid answer!
Faith, I know not what to say.	What do you say, James  Well, I don’t know what to say.
I will say for you.	I’ll answer for you.
It is “music with her silver sound” because musicians have no gold for sounding.	It is “music with her silver sound,” because musicians have no gold to use to make sounds.
What a pestilent knave is this same!	What an annoying man, this guy is!
Hang him, Jack!	Forget about him, Jack!
If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep, My dreams presage some joyful news at hand.	If I can trust my dreams, then some joyful news is coming soon.
Ah me!	Oh my!
How sweet is love itself possessed When but love’s shadows are so rich in joy!	How sweet it would be to actually have the woman I love, when merely thinking about love makes me so happy.
News from Verona!—How now, Balthasar?	Do you have news from Verona!—What is it, Balthasar?
Dost thou not bring me letters from the friar?	Do you bring me a letter from the friar?
How doth my lady?	How is my wife?
Is my father well?	Is my father well?
How fares my Juliet?	How is my Juliet?
That I ask again, For nothing can be ill if she be well.	I ask that again because nothing can be wrong if she is well.
Then she is well, and nothing can be ill.	Then she is well, and nothing is wrong.
Her body sleeps in Capels' monument, And her immortal part with angels lives.	Her body sleeps in the Capulet tomb, and her immortal soul lives with the angels in heaven.
I saw her laid low in her kindred’s vault And presently took post to tell it you.	I saw her buried in her family’s tomb, and then I came here to tell you the news.
O, pardon me for bringing these ill news, Since you did leave it for my office, sir.	Oh, pardon me for bringing this bad news, but you told me it was my job, sir.
A sick man in sadness makes his will, A word ill urged to one that is so ill.	You wouldn’t tell a sick man he “seriously” has to make his will—it would just make him worse.
In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.	Seriously, cousin, I love a woman.
A right good markman!	Then you were right on target.
And she’s fair I love.	The woman I love is beautiful.
A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.	A beautiful target is the one that gets hit the fastest.
Well, in that hit you miss.	Well, you’re not on target there.
She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste, For beauty, starved with her severity, Cuts beauty off from all posterity.	Yes she has, and by keeping celibate, she wastes her beauty.
She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair, To merit bliss by making me despair.	She’s too beautiful and too wise to deserve heaven’s blessing by making me despair.
Be ruled by me.	Take my advice.
Forget to think of her.	Don’t think about her.
O, teach me how I should forget to think!	Teach me to forget to think!
Is it e'en so?	Is it really true?
Then I defy you, stars!	Then I rebel against you, stars!
Thou know’st my lodging.	You know where I live.
Get me ink and paper, And hire post horses.	Get me some ink and paper, and hire some horses to ride.
I will hence tonight.	I will leave here for Verona tonight.
I do beseech you, sir, have patience.	Please, sir, have patience.
Your looks are pale and wild, and do import Some misadventure.	You look pale and wild as if you’re going to hurt yourself.
Tush, thou art deceived.	Tsk, you’re wrong.
Leave me and do the thing I bid thee do.	Leave me and do what I told you to do.
Hast thou no letters to me from the friar?	Don’t you have a letter for me from the friar?
No, my good lord.	No, my good lord.
No matter.	No matter.
Get thee gone, And hire those horses.	Get on your way and hire those horses.
I’ll be with thee straight.	I’ll be with you right away.
Well, Juliet, I will lie with thee tonight.	Well, Juliet, I’ll lie with you tonight.
Let’s see for means.	Let’s see how.
O mischief, thou art swift To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!	Destructive thoughts come quickly to the minds of desperate men!
As I remember, this should be the house.	As I remember, this should be the house.
Being holiday, the beggar’s shop is shut.	Today’s a holiday, so the beggar’s shop is shut.
What, ho!	Hey!
Apothecary!	Pharmacist!
Who calls so loud?	Who’s that calling so loud?
Come hither, man.	Come here, man.
I see that thou art poor.	I see that you are poor.
Hold, there is forty ducats.	Here are forty ducats.
Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness, And fear’st to die?	You’re this poor and wretched and still afraid to die?
Famine is in thy cheeks.	Your cheeks are thin because of hunger.
Need and oppression starveth in thine eyes.	I can see in your eyes that you’re starving.
The world is not thy friend nor the world’s law.	The world is not your friend, and neither is the law.
The world affords no law to make thee rich.	The world doesn’t make laws to make you rich.
Buy food, and get thyself in flesh.— Come, cordial and not poison, go with me To Juliet’s grave, for there must I use thee.	I pay you because you’re poor, not because you want me to buy this.
Holy Franciscan Friar!	Holy Franciscan Friar!
Brother, ho!	Brother, hey!
This same should be the voice of Friar John.	That sounds like the voice of Friar John.
Welcome from Mantua.	Welcome back from Mantua.
What says Romeo?	What does Romeo say?
Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.	Or, if he wrote down his thoughts, give me his letter.
So that my speed to Mantua there was stayed.	I couldn’t go to Mantua because I was stuck there.
Who bare my letter, then, to Romeo?	Then who took my letter to Romeo?
Unhappy fortune!	Unhappy fortune!
Brother, I’ll go and bring it thee.	Brother, I’ll go and bring it to you.
Now must I to the monument alone.	Now I must go to the tomb alone.
Within this three hours will fair Juliet wake.	Within three hours Juliet will wake up.
But I will write again to Mantua, And keep her at my cell till Romeo come.	But I’ll write again to Mantua, and I’ll keep her in my cell until Romeo comes.
Poor living corse, closed in a dead man’s tomb!	She’s shut inside a dead man’s tomb!
Give me thy torch, boy.	Give me your torch, boy.
Hence, and stand aloof.	Go away and stay apart from me.
Yet put it out, for I would not be seen.	Put the torch out, so I can’t be seen.
Give me those flowers.	Give me those flowers.
Do as I bid thee, go.	Do as I tell you.
Yet I will adventure.	Go.
The boy gives warning something doth approach.	The boy is warning me that someone approaches.
What cursèd foot wanders this way tonight To cross my obsequies and true love’s rite?	Who’s ruining my rituals of true love?
What with a torch!	It’s someone with a torch!
Muffle me, night, awhile.	I must hide in the darkness for awhile.
Give me that mattock and the wrenching iron.	Give me that pickax and the crowbar.
I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.	I’ll go, sir, and I won’t bother you.
So shalt thou show me friendship.	That’s the way to show me friendship.
Take thou that.	Take this.
Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man.	Good and noble young man, don’t mess with someone who’s desperate.
Fly hence and leave me.	Get away from here and leave me.
Think upon these gone.	Think about the ones who have died.
Let them affright thee.	Let them put fear in your heart.
I beseech thee, youth, Put not another sin upon my head By urging me to fury.	Please, young man, don’t make me angry.
O, be gone!	Oh, go away!
Stay not, be gone.	Don’t stay here, go away.
Live, and hereafter say A madman’s mercy bid thee run away.	Live, and from now on, say a madman mercifully told you to run away.
I do defy thy commination And apprehend thee for a felon here.	I’m arresting you as a criminal.
Wilt thou provoke me?	Are you going to provoke me?
Then have at thee, boy!	Alright, let’s fight, boy!
O Lord, they fight!	Oh Lord, they’re fighting!
I will go call the watch.	I’ll go call the watch.
Open the tomb.	Alright, I will.
Mercutio’s kinsman, noble County Paris.	It’s Mercutio’s relative, noble Count Paris!
What said my man, when my betossèd soul Did not attend him as we rode?	What did my man say?
I think He told me Paris should have married Juliet.	I think he told me Paris was about to marry Juliet.
Said he not so?	Isn’t that what he said?
Or did I dream it so?	Or was I dreaming?
I’ll bury thee in a triumphant grave.	I’ll bury you in a magnificent grave.
A grave?	A grave?
Oh, no.	Oh no!
A lantern, slaughtered youth, For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes This vault a feasting presence full of light.	Juliet lies here, and her beauty fills this tomb with light.
Death, that hath sucked the honey of thy breath, Hath had no power yet upon thy beauty.	Death has sucked the honey from your breath, but it has not yet ruined your beauty.
Thou art not conquered.	You haven’t been conquered.
O, what more favor can I do to thee, Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain To sunder his that was thine enemy?	Oh, what better favor can I do for you than to kill the man who killed you with the same hand that made you die young.
Shall I believe That unsubstantial death is amorous, And that the lean abhorrèd monster keeps Thee here in dark to be his paramour?	Should I believe that death is in love with you, and that the awful monster keeps you here to be his mistress?
Here, here will I remain With worms that are thy chamber maids.	Here, here I’ll remain with worms that are your chamber-maids.
Oh, here Will I set up my everlasting rest, And shake the yoke of inauspicious stars From this world-wearied flesh.	Oh, I’ll rest here forever.
Eyes, look your last.	Eyes, look out for the last time!
Arms, take your last embrace.	Arms, make your last embrace!
Thy drugs are quick.	His drugs work quickly.
Thus with a kiss I die.	So I die with a kiss.
These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows, Being black, puts us in mind they hide the fair.	Look at other beautiful girls.
Saint Francis be my speed!	Saint Francis, help me!
How oft tonight Have my old feet stumbled at graves!—Who’s there?	How often tonight have my old feet stumbled on gravestones!
Here’s one, a friend, and one that knows you well.	I’m a friend, a friend who knows you well.
Bliss be upon you!	God bless you!

As I discern, It burneth in the Capels' monument.	It looks to me like it’s burning in the Capulet tomb.
Who is it?	Who is it?
Romeo.	Romeo.
How long hath he been there?	How long has he been there?
Full half an hour.	For a full half hour.
Go with me to the vault.	Go with me to the tomb.
I dare not, sir.	I don’t dare, sir.
Stay, then.	Stay, then.
I’ll go alone.	I’ll go alone.
Fear comes upon me.	I’m suddenly afraid.
Oh, much I fear some ill unthrifty thing.	Oh, I’m very scared something awful has happened.

O comfortable Friar!	Oh friendly friar!
Where is my lord?	Where is my husband?
I do remember well where I should be, And there I am.	I remember very well where I should be, and here I am.
Where is my Romeo?	Where is my Romeo?
I hear some noise.	I hear some noise.
Lady, come from that nest Of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep.	Lady, come out of the tomb.
A greater power than we can contradict Hath thwarted our intents.	A greater power than we can fight has ruined our plan.
Come, come away.	Come, come away.
Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead, And Paris too.	Your husband lies dead there, and Paris too.

A cup, closed in my true love’s hand?	It’s a cup, closed in my true love’s hand?
Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end.— O churl, drunk all, and left no friendly drop To help me after?	Poison, I see, has been the cause of his death.
I will kiss thy lips.	I will kiss your lips.
Haply some poison yet doth hang on them, To make me die with a restorative.	Perhaps there’s still some poison on them, to make me die with a medicinal kiss.
Yea, noise?	Oh, noise?
Then I’ll be brief.	Then I’ll be quick.
O happy dagger, This is thy sheath.	Oh, good, a knife!
There rust and let me die.	Rust inside my body and let me die.
This is the place.	This is the place.
There, where the torch doth burn.	There, where the torch is burning.
The ground is bloody.—Search about the churchyard.	The ground is bloody.
Pitiful sight!	This is a pitiful sight!
Here lies the county slain, And Juliet bleeding, warm and newly dead, Who here hath lain these two days buried.— Go, tell the Prince.	Go, tell the Prince.

Raise up the Montagues.	Wake up the Montagues.
Some others search.	Have some others search.
Here’s Romeo’s man.	Here’s Romeo’s man.
We found him in the churchyard.	We found him in the churchyard.
Hold him in safety till the Prince come hither.	Hold him in custody until the Prince gets here.

A great suspicion.	Very suspicious.
Stay the friar too.	Hold the friar too.
What misadventure is so early up That calls our person from our morning rest?	What crimes happen so early in the morning that I have to wake up before the usual time?
What should it be that is so shrieked abroad?	What’s the problem, that they cry out so loud?
Oh, the people in the street cry “Romeo,” Some “Juliet,” and some “Paris,” and all run With open outcry toward our monument.	Some people in the street are crying “Romeo.” Some are crying “Juliet,” and some are crying “Paris.” They’re all running in an open riot toward our tomb.
Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.	Investigate how this foul murder came about.
O heavens!	Oh heavens!
O wife, look how our daughter bleeds!	Oh wife, look at how our daughter bleeds!
This dagger hath mista'en—for, lo, his house Is empty on the back of Montague, And it mis-sheathèd in my daughter’s bosom.	That knife should be in its sheath on that Montague’s back, but instead it’s mis-sheathed in my daughter’s breast.
O me!	Oh my!
This sight of death is as a bell, That warns my old age to a sepulcher.	This sight of death is like a bell that warns me I’m old and I’ll die soon.
Alas, my liege, my wife is dead tonight.	Oh, my liege, my wife died tonight.
Grief of my son’s exile hath stopped her breath.	Sadness over my son’s exile stopped her breath.
What further woe conspires against mine age?	What further pain must I endure in my old age?
Look, and thou shalt see.	Look, and you’ll see.
Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while, Till we can clear these ambiguities And know their spring, their head, their true descent, And then will I be general of your woes, And lead you even to death.	And then I’ll be the leader of pain, and maybe I’ll lead you as far as death.
Meantime forbear, And let mischance be slave to patience.— Bring forth the parties of suspicion.	In the meantime, hold on, and be patient.
I am the greatest, able to do least, Yet most suspected, as the time and place Doth make against me, of this direful murder.	I am the greatest, but I was able to do the least.
And here I stand, both to impeach and purge, Myself condemnèd and myself excused.	I have already condemned and excused myself.
Then say at once what thou dost know in this.	Tell us what you know about this affair.
I will be brief, for my short date of breath Is not so long as is a tedious tale.	I will be brief because I’m not going to live long enough to tell a boring story.
Meantime I writ to Romeo, That he should hither come as this dire night, To help to take her from her borrowed grave, Being the time the potion’s force should cease.	In the meantime I wrote to Romeo and told him to come here on this awful night to help remove her from her temporary grave when the sleeping potion wore off.
What can he say in this?	I know all of this.
Their course of love, the tidings of her death.	I brought my master news of Juliet’s death.
Montague!	Give me the letter.
O brother Montague, give me thy hand.	Oh, brother Montague, give me your hand.
But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?	But what do you say to my request?
But saying o'er what I have said before.	I can only repeat what I’ve said before.
My child is yet a stranger in the world.	My daughter is still very young.
She hath not seen the change of fourteen years.	She’s not even fourteen years old.
Younger than she are happy mothers made.	Girls younger than she often marry and become happy mothers.
And too soon marred are those so early made.	Girls who marry so young grow up too soon.
But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart.	But go ahead and charm her, gentle Paris; make her love you.
This night I hold an old accustomed feast, Whereto I have invited many a guest Such as I love.	Tonight I’m having a feast that we’ve celebrated for many years.
From forth the fatal loins of these two foes A pair of star-crossed lovers take their life, Whose misadventured piteous overthrows Doth with their death bury their parents' strife.	At my humble house tonight, you can expect to see dazzling stars that walk on the ground and light the sky from below.
The fearful passage of their death-marked love And the continuance of their parents' rage, Which, but their children’s end, naught could remove, Is now the two hours' traffic of our stage— The which, if you with patient ears attend, What here shall miss, our toil shall strive to mend.	In the beautiful city of Verona, where our story takes place, a long-standing hatred between two families erupts into new violence, and citizens stain their hands with the blood of their fellow citizens.
Such comfort as do lusty young men feel When well-appareled April on the heel Of limping winter treads.	Two unlucky children of these enemy families become lovers and commit suicide.
Even such delight Among fresh fennel buds shall you this night Inherit at my house.	Their unfortunate deaths put an end to their parents' feud.
Go, sirrah, trudge about Through fair Verona.	Come along with me.
Find them out whose names are written here?	Find the people whose names are on this list?
It is written, that the shoemaker should meddle with his yard and the tailor with his last, the fisher with his pencil and the painter with his nets.	It is written that shoemakers and tailors should play with each others' tools, that fisherman should play with paints, and painters should play with with fishing nets.
But I am sent to find those persons whose names are here writ, and can never find what names the writing person hath here writ.	But I’ve been sent to find the people whose names are written on this list, and I can’t read!
Take thou some new infection to thy eye, And the rank poison of the old will die.	But here come some people, right in the nick of time.
Your plantain leaf is excellent for that.	For when you cut your shin.
For what, I pray thee?	What?
Why Romeo, art thou mad?	Romeo, are you crazy?
Not mad, but bound more than a madman is, Shut up in prison, kept without my food, Whipped and tormented and—Good e'en, good fellow.	I’m locked up in a prison and deprived of food.
God 'i' good e'en.	I’m whipped and tortured— May God give you a good evening.
I pray, sir, can you read?	Excuse me, sir, do you know how to read?
Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.	I can read my own fortune in my misery.
Perhaps you have learned it without book.	Perhaps you’ve learned from life and not from books.
But I pray, can you read anything you see?	But please tell me, can you read anything you see?
Ay, if I know the letters and the language.	Yes, if I know the language and the letters.
Ye say honestly.	I see.
Stay, fellow.	Well, that’s an  Stay, fellow.
I can read.	I can read.
Seigneur Martino and his wife and daughters; County Anselme and his beauteous sisters; The lady widow of Vitruvio; Seigneur Placentio and his lovely nieces; Mercutio and his brother Valentine; Mine uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters; My fair niece Rosaline and Livia;	Signor Martino and his wife and daughters, Count Anselme and his beautiful sisters, Vitruvio’s widow, Signor Placentio and his lovely nieces, Mercutio and his brother Valentine, My uncle Capulet and his wife and daughters, My fair niece Rosaline and Livia,
Seigneur Valentio and his cousin Tybalt; Lucio and the lively Helena.” A fair assembly.	Signor Valentio and his cousin Tybalt, Lucio and the lively Helena.” That’s a nice group of people.
Whither should they come?	Where are they supposed to come?
Up.	Up.
Whither?	Where?
To supper?	To supper?
To our house.	To our house.
Whose house?	Whose house?
My master’s.	My master’s house.
Indeed, I should have asked thee that before.	Indeed, I should have asked you before who he was.
Now I’ll tell you without asking.	Now I’ll tell you so you don’t have to ask.
