Rest you merry!	Have a nice day!
At this same ancient feast of Capulet’s Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so loves With all the admired beauties of Verona.	The beautiful Rosaline whom you love so much will be at Capulet’s traditional feast, along with every beautiful woman in Verona.
Go thither, and with unattainted eye Compare her face with some that I shall show, And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.	Go there and compare her objectively to some other girls I’ll show you.
One fairer than my love?	A woman more beautiful than the one I love?
The all-seeing sun Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun.	The sun itself has never seen anyone as beautiful since the world began.
I’ll go along, no such sight to be shown, But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.	I’ll go with you.
Nurse, where’s my daughter?	Nurse, where’s my daughter?
Call her forth to me.	Tell her to come to me.
Now, by my maidenhead at twelve year old I bade her come.	I swear to you by my virginity at age twelve, I already told her to come.
What, lamb!	Come on!
How now, who calls?	Who’s calling me?
Your mother.	Your mother.
Madam, I am here.	Madam, I’m here.
What is your will?	What do you want?
Thou know’st my daughter’s of a pretty age.	You know how young my daughter is.
Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.	Yes, I know her age down to the hour.
She’s not fourteen.	She’s not even fourteen.
I’ll lay fourteen of my teeth—and yet, to my teen be it spoken, I have but four—she is not fourteen.	I’d bet fourteen of my own teeth—but, I’m sorry to say, I only have four teeth—she’s not fourteen.
Even or odd, of all days in the year, Come Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen.	Whether it’s even or odd, of all the days in the year, on the night of Lammas Eve, she’ll be fourteen.
Susan and she—God rest all Christian souls!— Were of an age.	She and Susan—God rest her and all Christian souls—were born on the same day.
Well, Susan is with God.	Well, Susan died and is with God.
She was too good for me.	She was too good for me.
But, as I said, On Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen.	But like I said, on the night of Lammas Eve, she will be fourteen.
That shall she.	Yes, she will.
Marry, I remember it well.	Indeed, I remember it well.
Tis since the earthquake now eleven years, And she was weaned—I never shall forget it— Of all the days of the year, upon that day.	It’s been eleven years since the earthquake.
For I had then laid wormwood to my dug, Sitting in the sun under the dovehouse wall.	I had put bitter wormwood on my breast as I was sitting in the sun, under the wall of the dovehouse.
My lord and you were then at Mantua.— Nay, I do bear a brain.—But, as I said, When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool, To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug!	But like I said, when she tasted the bitter wormwood on my nipple, the pretty little babe got irritated and started to quarrel with my breast.
Shake!” quoth the dovehouse.	Then the dovehouse shook with the earthquake.
Twas no need, I trow, To bid me trudge.	There was no need to tell me to get out of there.
Yea,” quoth he, “Dost thou fall upon thy face?	Oh,” he said, “Did you fall on your face?
And, pretty fool, it stinted and said “ay.” Enough of this.	You’ll  Enough of this.
I pray thee, hold thy peace.	Please be quiet.
Yes, madam.	Yes ,madam.
Yet I cannot choose but laugh To think it should leave crying and say “ay.” And yet, I warrant, it had upon its brow A bump as big as a young cockerel’s stone, A perilous knock, and it cried bitterly.	But I can’t help laughing to think that the baby stopped crying and said, “Yes.” I swear, she had a bump on her forehead as big as a rooster’s testicle.
Yea,” quoth my husband, “Fall’st upon thy face?	It was a painful bruise, and she was crying bitterly.
Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age.	Yes,” said my husband, “Did you fall on your face?
Wilt thou not, Jule?” It stinted and said “ay.” And stint thou too, I pray thee, Nurse, say I.	You’ll fall backward when you grow up, won’t you, Jule?” And she stopped crying and said, “Yes.” Now you stop too, Nurse, please.
God mark thee to his grace!	May God choose you to receive his grace.
Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed.	You were the prettiest baby I ever nursed.
An I might live to see thee married once, I have my wish.	If I live to see you get married someday, all my wishes will come true.
Tell me, daughter Juliet, How stands your disposition to be married?	Tell me, my daughter Juliet, what is your attitude about getting married?
It is an honor that I dream not of.	It is an honor that I do not dream of.
Well, think of marriage now.	Well, start thinking about marriage now.
Younger than you Here in Verona, ladies of esteem Are made already mothers.	Here in Verona there are girls younger than you—girls from noble families—who have already become mothers.
By my count, I was your mother much upon these years That you are now a maid.	By my count, I was already your mother at just about your age, while you remain a virgin.
Thus then in brief: The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.	Well then, I’ll say this quickly: the valiant Paris wants you as his bride.
A man, young lady!	What a man, young lady.
Verona’s summer hath not such a flower.	Summertime in Verona has no flower as fine as him.
What say you?	Lose nothing?
I’ll look to like if looking liking move.	I’ll look at him and try to like him, at least if what I see is likable.
But no more deep will I endart mine eye Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.	But I won’t let myself fall for him any more than your permission allows.
I must hence to wait.	Everything’s out of control.
I beseech you, follow straight.	Please, follow straight after me.
We follow thee.—Juliet, the county stays.	We’ll follow you.
Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days.	Go, girl, look for a man who’ll give you happy nights at the end of happy days.
What, shall this speech be spoke for our excuse?	What will we say is our excuse for being here?
Or shall we on without apology?	Or should we enter without apologizing?
The date is out of such prolixity.	It’s out of fashion to give lengthy explanations like that.
But let them measure us by what they will.	Let them judge us however they please.
Give me a torch.	Give me a torch.
I am not for this ambling.	I don’t want to dance.
Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.	No, noble Romeo, you’ve got to dance.
Not I, believe me.	Not me, believe me.
You have dancing shoes With nimble soles.	You’re wearing dancing shoes with nimble soles.
I have a soul of lead So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.	My soul is made out of lead, and it’s so heavy it keeps me stuck on the ground so I can’t move.
You are a lover.	You’re a lover.
Borrow Cupid’s wings And soar with them above a common bound.	Take Cupid’s wings and fly higher than the average man.
I am too sore enpiercèd with his shaft To soar with his light feathers, and so bound, I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe.	His arrow has pierced me too deeply, so I can’t fly high with his cheerful feathers.
Under love’s heavy burden do I sink.	I sink under the heavy weight of love.
I mean, an we be in choler, we’ll draw.	We won’t take their garbage.
I strike quickly, being moved.	I hit hard when I’m angry.
But thou art not quickly moved to strike.	Angry enough to run away.
To move is to stir, and to be valiant is to stand.	You won’t stand and fight.
A dog of that house shall move me to stand.	A dog from that house will make me angry enough to take a stand.
And to sink in it, should you burthen love— Too great oppression for a tender thing.	If you sink, you’re dragging love down.
Is love a tender thing?	Is love really tender?
It is too rough, Too rude, too boisterous, and it pricks like thorn.	I think it’s too rough, too rude, too rowdy, and it pricks like a thorn.
If love be rough with you, be rough with love.	If love plays rough with you, play rough with  Come on, let’s knock and go in.
Let wantons light of heart Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels.	Let playful people with light hearts dance.
Come, we burn daylight, ho!	Come on, we’re wasting precious daylight.
Nay, that’s not so.	Let’s go!
We waste our lights in vain, like lights by day.	No we’re not—it’s night.
And we mean well in going to this mask, But ’tis no wit to go.	We mean well by going to this masquerade ball, but it’s not smart of us to go.
Why, may one ask?	Why, may I ask?
I dreamt a dream tonight.	I had a dream last night.
And so did I.	So did I.
Well, what was yours?	Well, what was your dream?
That dreamers often lie.	My dream told me that dreamers often lie.
In bed asleep while they do dream things true.	They lie in bed while they dream about the truth.
Oh, then, I see Queen Mab hath been with you.	Oh, then I see you’ve been with  Who’s Queen Mab?
Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier’s nose, And then dreams he of smelling out a suit.	Sometimes she rides over a courtier’s lips, and he dreams of making money off of someone.
And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig’s tail Tickling a parson’s nose as he lies asleep, Then he dreams of another benefice.	Sometimes she tickles a priest’s nose with a  Enough, enough!
This is she—    Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!	Mercutio, be quiet.
This wind you talk of, blows us from ourselves.	The wind you’re talking about is blowing us off our course.
Supper is done, and we shall come too late.	Dinner is over, and we’re going to get there too late.
On, lusty gentlemen.	Onward, lover boys!
Strike, drum.	Beat the drum.
Where’s Potpan, that he helps not to take away?	Where’s Potpan?
When good manners shall lie all in one or two men’s hands, and they unwashed too, ’tis a foul thing.	When only one or two men have all the good manners, and even they are dirty, things are bad.
Away with the joint-stools, remove the court-cupboard, look to the plate.	Take away the stools, the sideboards, and the plates.

Ay, boy, ready.	Yes, boy, I’m ready.
You are looked for and called for, asked for and sought for, in the great chamber.	They’re looking for you in the great chamber.
We cannot be here and there too.	We can’t be in two places at once, both here and there!
Cheerly, boys.	Cheers, boys.
Be brisk 0awhile, and the longer liver take all.	Be quick for a while and let the one who lives the longest take everything.
Welcome, gentlemen!	Welcome, gentlemen.
She that makes dainty, She, I’ll swear, hath corns.	Whichever of you acts shy, I’ll swear she has corns.

By'r Lady, thirty years.	I swear, it must be thirty years.
Tis more, ’tis more.	It’s been longer, it’s been longer.
His son is elder, sir.	Lucentio’s son is older than that, sir.
His son is thirty.	He’s thirty years old.
Will you tell me that?	Are you really going to tell me that?
His son was but a ward two years ago.	His son was a minor only two years ago.
I know not, sir.	I don’t know, sir.

For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.	My eyes were liars, then, because I never saw true beauty before tonight.
This, by his voice, should be a Montague.—   What, dares the slave Come hither, covered with an antic face, To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?	I can tell by his voice that this man is a Montague.
Wherefore storm you so?	Why are you acting so angry?
Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe, A villain that is hither come in spite To scorn at our solemnity this night.	Uncle, this man is a Montague—our enemy.
Young Romeo is it?	Is it young Romeo?
Tis he, that villain Romeo.	That’s him, that villain Romeo.
Content thee, gentle coz.	Calm down, gentle cousin.
Let him alone.	Leave him alone.
He bears him like a portly gentleman, And, to say truth, Verona brags of him To be a virtuous and well-governed youth.	He carries himself like a dignified gentleman, and, to tell you the truth, he has a reputation throughout Verona as a virtuous and well-behaved young man.
I would not for the wealth of all the town Here in my house do him disparagement.	I wouldn’t insult him in my own house for all the wealth in this town.
Therefore be patient.	So calm down.
Take no note of him.	Just ignore him.
You’ll not endure him!	I won’t tolerate him.

You are a saucy boy.	You’re an insolent little boy.
Is ’t so, indeed?	Is that how it is, really?
This trick may chance to scathe you, I know what.	I know what I’ll do.
You must contrary me.	You have to contradict me, do you?
I’ll make you quiet.—What, cheerly, my hearts!	I’ll teach you a lesson.
Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?	Don’t saints and pilgrims have lips too?
Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.	Yes, pilgrim—they have lips that they’re supposed to pray with.
O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do.	Well then, saint, let lips do what hands do.
They pray; grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.	Please grant my prayer so my faith doesn’t turn to despair.
Saints do not move, though grant for prayers' sake.	Saints don’t move, even when they grant prayers.
Then move not, while my prayer’s effect I take.	Then don’t move while I act out my prayer.
Thus from my lips, by thine, my sin is purged.	Now my sin has been taken from my lips by yours.
Then have my lips the sin that they have took.	Then do my lips now have the sin they took from yours?
Sin from thy lips?	Sin from my lips?
Give me my sin again.	Give me my sin back.
You kiss by th' book.	You kiss like you’ve studied how.
Madam, your mother craves a word with you.	Madam, your mother wants to talk to you.
What is her mother?	Who is her mother?
I nursed her daughter that you talked withal.	I nursed her daughter, whom you were just talking to.
I tell you, he that can lay hold of her Shall have the chinks.	Let me tell you, the man who marries her will become very wealthy.
Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone.	No gentlemen, don’t get ready to go now.
We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.— Is it e'en so?	We have a little dessert coming up.
I’ll to my rest.	You’re right.
The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.	The fight is between our masters, and we men who work for them.
Tis all one.	It’s all the same.
I will show myself a tyrant.	I’ll be a harsh master to them.
The heads of the maids?	Cut off their heads?

They must take it in sense that feel it.	The women you rape are the ones who’ll have to “sense” it.
Me they shall feel while I am able to stand, and ’tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.	Everybody knows I’m a nice piece of flesh.

Now Romeo is beloved and loves again, Alike bewitchèd by the charm of looks, But to his foe supposed he must complain, And she steal love’s sweet bait from fearful hooks.	But he has to make his speeches of love to a woman who’s supposed to be his enemy.
And she as much in love, her means much less To meet her new beloved anywhere.	And Juliet’s just as much in love as he, but she has even less opportunity to meet her lover.
But passion lends them power, time means, to meet, Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.	But love gives them power, and time gives them the chance to meet, sweetening the extreme danger with intense pleasure.
Can I go forward when my heart is here?	Can I go away while my heart stays here?
He is wise, And, on my life, hath stol'n him home to bed.	I bet he slipped away and went home to bed.
He ran this way and leapt this orchard wall.	He ran this way and jumped over this orchard wall.
Call, good Mercutio.	Call to him, Mercutio.

Romeo!	Romeo!
Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh!	Show yourself in the form of a sigh.
Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied.	Speak one rhyme, and I’ll be satisfied.
Cry but “Ay me!” Pronounce but “love” and “dove.” Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word, One nickname for her purblind son and heir, Young Abraham Cupid, he that shot so true When King Cophetua loved the beggar maid.— He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not. An if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.	If he hears you, you’ll make him angry.
This cannot anger him.	What I’m saying can’t anger him.
My invocation Is fair and honest.	The things I’m saying are fair and honest.
Blind is his love and best befits the dark.	His love is blind, so it belongs in the dark.
If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.	If love is blind, it can’t hit the target.

Go, then, for ’tis in vain To seek him here that means not to be found.	There’s no point in looking for him if he doesn’t want to be found.
It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.	It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.
Her vestal livery is but sick and green, And none but fools do wear it.	Virginity makes her look sick and green.
Cast it off!	Let it go.
It is my lady.	Oh, there’s my lady!
Oh, it is my love.	Oh, it is my love.
Oh, that she knew she were!	Oh, I wish she knew how much I love her.
She speaks, yet she says nothing.	She’s talking, but she’s not saying anything.
What of that?	So what?
Her eye discourses.	Her eyes are saying something.
Tis not to me she speaks.	She’s not talking to me.
Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven, Having some business, do entreat her eyes To twinkle in their spheres till they return.	Two of the brightest stars in the whole sky had to go away on business, and they’re asking her eyes to twinkle in their places until they return.
Her eye in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night.	If her eyes were in the night sky, they would shine so brightly through space that birds would start singing, thinking her light was the light of day.
See how she leans her cheek upon her hand.	Look how she leans her hand on her cheek.
Oh, that I were a glove upon that hand That I might touch that cheek!	Oh, I wish I was the glove on that hand so that I could touch that cheek.
O Romeo, Romeo!	Oh, my!
Wherefore art thou Romeo?	Who are you?
Tis but thy name that is my enemy.	I hate my name, dear saint, because my name is your enemy.
Henceforth I never will be Romeo.	Aren’t you Romeo?
What man art thou that, thus bescreened in night, So stumblest on my counsel?	And aren’t you a Montague?
By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am.	Tell me, how did you get in here?
Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague?	And why did you come?
The orchard walls are high and hard to climb, And the place death, considering who thou art, If any of my kinsmen find thee here.	If any of my relatives find you here they’ll kill you because of who you are.
Therefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me.	Therefore your relatives are no obstacle.
If they do see thee they will murder thee.	If they see you, they’ll murder you.
Look thou but sweet, And I am proof against their enmity.	Just look at me kindly, and I’m invincible against their hatred.
I would not for the world they saw thee here.	I’d give anything to keep them from seeing you here.
My life were better ended by their hate Than death proroguèd, wanting of thy love.	I’d rather they killed me than have to live without your love.
Thou know’st the mask of night is on my face, Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek For that which thou hast heard me speak tonight.	Otherwise, you’d see me blushing about the things you’ve heard me say tonight.
Dost thou love me?	Do you love me?
I know thou wilt say “ay,” And I will take thy word.	I know you’ll say “yes,” and I’ll believe you.
What shall I swear by?	What should I swear by?
Do not swear at all.	Don’t swear at all.
Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self, Which is the god of my idolatry, And I’ll believe thee.	But if you have to swear, swear by your wonderful self, which is the god I worship like an idol, and then I’ll believe you.
If my heart’s dear love— Well, do not swear.	If my heart’s dear love— Well, don’t swear.
Although I joy in thee, I have no joy of this contract tonight.	Although you bring me joy, I can’t take joy in this exchange of promises tonight.
This bud of love, by summer’s ripening breath, May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.	Our love, which right now is like a flower bud in the summer air, may turn out to be a beautiful flower by the next time we meet.
As sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast.	I hope you enjoy the same sweet peace and rest I feel in my heart.
O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?	Oh, are you going to leave me so unsatisfied?
What satisfaction canst thou have tonight?	What satisfaction could you possibly have tonight?
Th' exchange of thy love’s faithful vow for mine.	I pledged my love to you before you asked me to.
I gave thee mine before thou didst request it, And yet I would it were to give again.	Yet I wish I could take that promise back, so I had it to give again.
Wouldst thou withdraw it?	You would take it back?
For what purpose, love?	Why would you do that, my love?
But to be frank, and give it thee again.	Only to be generous and give it to you once more.
And yet I wish but for the thing I have.	But I’m wishing for something I already have.
My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep.	My generosity to you is as limitless as the sea, and my love is as deep.
I hear some noise within.	I hear a noise inside.
Dear love, adieu.— Anon, good Nurse!—Sweet Montague, be true.	Sweet Montague, be true.
Stay but a little.	Stay here for a moment.
I will come again.	I’ll come back.
O blessèd, blessèd night!	Oh, blessed, blessed night!
I am afeard, Being in night, all this is but a dream, Too flattering sweet to be substantial.	Because it’s dark out, I’m afraid all this is just a dream, too sweet to be real.
Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.	Three words, dear Romeo, and then it’s good night for real.
Fear me not.	Don’t worry about me.
Let us take the law of our sides.	I  Let’s not break the law by starting a fight.
Let them begin.	Let them start something.
I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as they list.	I’ll frown at them as they pass by, and they can react however they want.
Nay, as they dare.	You mean however they dare.
I will bite my thumb at them, which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.	I’ll bite my thumb at them.
Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?	Hey, are you biting your thumb at us?
I do bite my thumb, sir.	I’m biting my thumb.
Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?	Are you biting your thumb at us?
Do you quarrel, sir?	Are you trying to start a fight?
Quarrel, sir?	Start a fight?
No, sir.	No, sir.
Tomorrow will I send.	Tomorrow I’ll send the messenger.
So thrive my soul— A thousand times good night!	My soul depends on it— A thousand times good night.
A thousand times the worse to want thy light.	Leaving you is a thousand times worse than being near you.
Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud, Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies, And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine, With repetition of “My Romeo!” It is my soul that calls upon my name.	Oh, I wish I could make a  My soul is calling out my name.
How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night, Like softest music to attending ears!	The sound of lovers calling each others names through the night is silver-sweet.
Romeo!	Romeo!
My nyas?	My baby hawk?
What o'clock tomorrow Shall I send to thee?	What time tomorrow should I send a messenger to you?
By the hour of nine.	By nine o'clock.
I will not fail.	I won’t fail.
Tis twenty year till then.	From now until then seems like twenty years.
I have forgot why I did call thee back.	I have forgotten why I called you back.
Let me stand here till thou remember it.	Let me stand here until you remember your reason.
And I’ll still stay, to have thee still forget, Forgetting any other home but this.	I’ll forget that I have any home besides this spot right here.
Tis almost morning.	It’s almost morning.
And yet no further than a wanton’s bird, That lets it hop a little from his hand Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves, And with a silken thread plucks it back again, So loving-jealous of his liberty.	He lets the bird hop a little from his hand and then yanks him back by a string.
I would I were thy bird.	I wish I was your bird.
Sweet, so would I.	My sweet, so do I.
Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.	But I would kill you by petting you too much.
Good night, good night!	Good night, good night.
Parting is such sweet sorrow That I shall say good night till it be morrow.	Parting is such sweet sorrow that I’ll say good night until tonight becomes tomorrow.
Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast.	I hope you sleep peacefully.
Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest.	I wish I were Sleep and Peace, so I could spend the night with you.
Hence will I to my ghostly friar’s close cell, His help to crave and my dear hap to tell.	Now I’ll go see my priest, to ask for his help and tell him about my good luck.
The gray-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night, Checkering the eastern clouds with streaks of light, And fleckled darkness like a drunkard reels From forth day’s path and Titan’s fiery wheels.	Darkness is stumbling out of the sun’s path like a drunk man.
Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye, The day to cheer and night’s dank dew to dry, I must upfill this osier cage of ours With baleful weeds and precious-juicèd flowers.	Now, before the sun comes up and burns away the dew, I have to fill this basket of mine with poisonous weeds and medicinal flowers.
The earth, that’s nature’s mother, is her tomb.	The Earth is nature’s mother and also nature’s tomb.
And from her womb children of divers kind We sucking on her natural bosom find, Many for many virtues excellent, None but for some and yet all different.	From the Earth’s womb, many different sorts of plants and animals come forth, and the Earth provides her children with many excellent forms of nourishment.
Oh, mickle is the powerful grace that lies In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities.	Herbs, plants, and stones possess great power.
For naught so vile that on the earth doth live But to the earth some special good doth give.	There is nothing on Earth that is so evil that it does not provide the earth with some special quality.
Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied, And vice sometime by action dignified.	Virtue turns to vice if it’s misused.
Within the infant rind of this small flower Poison hath residence and medicine power.	Inside the little rind of this weak flower, there is both poison and powerful medicine.
Two such opposèd kings encamp them still, In man as well as herbs—grace and rude will.	There are two opposite elements in everything, in men as well as in herbs—good and evil.
And where the worser is predominant, Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.	When evil is dominant, death soon kills the body like cancer.
Good morrow, Father.	Good morning, father.
Benedicite.	God bless you.
What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?	Who greets me so early in the morning?
Young son, it argues a distempered head So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed.	Young man, something’s wrong if you’re getting out of bed this early.
Care keeps his watch in every old man’s eye, And where care lodges, sleep will never lie.	Every old man has worries, and worried men never get any sleep, but young men shouldn’t have a care in the world.
But where unbruisèd youth with unstuffed brain Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign.	They should get to bed early and get plenty of sleep.
Therefore thy earliness doth me assure Thou art uproused by some distemperature.	Therefore, the fact that you’re awake this early tells me you’ve been upset with some anxiety.
Or if not so, then here I hit it right: Our Romeo hath not been in bed tonight.	If that’s not the case, then this must be the answer: You, Romeo, have not been to bed tonight.
That last is true.	Your last guess is right.
The sweeter rest was mine.	I enjoyed a sweeter rest than sleep.
With Rosaline, my ghostly Father?	With Rosaline, father?
That’s my good son.	That’s good, my boy.
But where hast thou been, then?	But where have you been?
I’ll tell thee ere thou ask it me again.	I’ll tell you before you have to ask me again.
Both our remedies Within thy help and holy physic lies.	You have the sacred power to cure both of us.
I bear no hatred, blessèd man, for, lo, My intercession likewise steads my foe.	I carry no hatred, holy man, because my request will benefit my enemy.
Here comes your father.	Here comes your father.
Never make denial.	Don’t even think about refusing.

How but well, sir?	Beautifully, sir, beautifully!

In your dumps?	Are you down in the dumps?
Call you me daughter?	You have the nerve to call me daughter?

Nay, then, good night our part.	So much for our plan.
Be patient, gentlemen.	Relax, gentlemen.
I choose her for myself.	I’ve made my choice.
If she and I be pleased, what’s that to you?	If she and I are happy, what’s it to you?

Tis a match.	Call it a match!
Amen, say we.	Amen to that!

Sunday comes apace.	Sunday is just around the corner.
We will be married o' Sunday.	We’re to be married on Sunday.
Was ever match clapped up so suddenly?	Was there ever a match put together so quickly?
Twill bring you gain or perish on the seas.	I’ve made a risky investment.
The gain I seek is quiet in the match.	The only profit I seek is a peaceful match.
No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch.	There’s no doubt that Petruchio’s got quite a catch.
But now, Baptista, to your younger daughter.	Now, Baptista, let’s turn to your younger daughter.
Now is the day we long have lookèd for.	We’ve been waiting a long time for this day.

Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.   Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.	Callow youth, you don’t yet know how to love!
But thine doth fry.	And you’re all sizzle.
Skipper, stand back.	Stand back, boy.
Tis age that nourisheth.	Age is the thing that nourishes.
Content you, gentlemen.	Enough, gentlemen.
I will compound this strife.	I will settle this matter.
First, as you know, my house within the city Is richly furnishèd with plate and gold, Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands; My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry, In ivory coffers I have stuffed my crowns, In cypress chests my arras counterpoints, Costly apparel, tents, and canopies, Fine linen, Turkey cushions bossed with pearl, Valance of Venice gold in needlework, Pewter and brass, and all things that belong To house or housekeeping.	First of all, my house in the city, as you know, is filled with expensive furniture and household articles, china and gold, basins and pitchers for her to wash her dainty hands in.
Then, at my farm I have a hundred milch-kine to the pail, Six score fat oxen standing in my stalls, And all things answerable to this portion.	Then, at my farm I have a hundred milk cows, a hundred and twenty fat oxen in my stables, and all the equipment necessary to maintain them.
Two thousand ducats by the year of land!	Two thousand ducats a year from his land!
Nay, I have offered all, I have no more, And she can have no more than all I have.	I can’t offer her more than all I have.
I must confess your offer is the best, And, let your father make her the assurance, She is your own; else, you must pardon me.	I must admit your offer is the best.

And may not young men die as well as old?	Oh, and young men never die?

Now must the world point at poor Katherine And say, “Lo, there is mad Petruchio’s wife, If it would please him come and marry her!”   Upon my life, Petruchio means but well, Whatever fortune stays him from his word: Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise; Though he be merry, yet withal he’s honest.	So now everyone will point at me and say, “Look, there goes the wife of that comedian Petruchio—if he could be bothered to marry the pathetic thing!”
Would Katherine had never seen him, though!	Maybe, but I wish I’d never laid eyes on him.

Now, were not I a little pot and soon hot, my very lips might freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, my heart in my belly, ere I should come by a fire to thaw me. My falcon now is sharp and passing empty, And, till she stoop, she must not be full-gorged, For then she never looks upon her lure.	My falcon is now hungry and unfed and must not be given enough to eat until she comes to me, for if her hunger is satisfied, she’ll pay no attention to the bait.
Another way I have to man my haggard, To make her come and know her keeper’s call.	I have another plan to make my bird come to me and recognize her owner’s call is to keep her from sleeping—
That is, to watch her, as we watch these kites That bate and beat and will not be obedient.	the way trainers do with young hawks that flutter and flap and will not obey.
She ate no meat today, nor none shall eat.	She had no food today and will have none.
Last night she slept not, nor tonight she shall not.	Last night she got no sleep, and she won’t get any tonight.
As with the meat, some undeservèd fault I’ll find about the making of the bed, And here I’ll fling the pillow, there the bolster, This way the coverlet, another way the sheets.	Just as I did with the meat, I’ll make up some problem with the way the bed is made, and throw the pillow one way and the cushion the other, and the blanket over here and the sheets over there.
And, in conclusion, she shall watch all night, And if she chance to nod I’ll rail and brawl, And with the clamor keep her still awake.	And if she starts to drop off, I’ll rant and yell until I wake her up.
He that knows better how to tame a shrew, Now let him speak; ’tis charity to show.	If anyone here knows a better way to tame a shrew, speak up, please.
Is ’t possible, friend Litio, that mistress Bianca Doth fancy any other but Lucentio?	It would be much appreciated.
What, master, read you?	What are you reading, teacher?
First resolve me that.	Answer me that first.
And may you prove, sir, master of your art.	I hope you’re an expert in your field.
I tell thee, Litio, this is wonderful!	Let me come clean.
Mistake no more.	I’m not really Litio.
Know, sir, that I am called Hortensio.	My name is Hortensio, sir.
See how they kiss and court!	Look how they kiss and carry on!
Fie on her!	The hell with her!
See how beastly she doth court him!	Look how she carries on with him!
Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!	It’s revolting!
For me, that I may surely keep mine oath, I will be married to a wealthy widow, Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved me As I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.	Well, to be on the safe side—so I don’t go back on my promise—I plan to get myself married to a wealthy widow within the next three days.
And so farewell, Signior Lucentio.	Farewell, then, Signior Lucentio.
Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks, Shall win my love, and so I take my leave, In resolution as I swore before.	From now on, goodness in women, not superficial beauty, will win my heart.
What, would you make me mad?	What, are you trying to make me crazy?

Oh, this is it that makes your servants droop!	And this is why your servants hang their heads in sorrow!
O noble lord, bethink thee of thy birth, Call home thy ancient thoughts from banishment, And banish hence these abject lowly dreams.	Oh noble lord, consider your lineage.
Look how thy servants do attend on thee, Each in his office ready at thy beck.	Look how your servants wait on you, each one ready to do whatever you command.
Wilt thou have music?	Would you care to hear some music?
Hark!	Listen!
Apollo plays, And twenty cagèd nightingales do sing: Or wilt thou sleep?	Do you want to sleep?

Ay, and he’ll tame her.	Yeah, and he’s going to tame her.

For that goes hard.	That would be a little extreme!

But I, who never knew how to entreat, Nor never needed that I should entreat, Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep, With oaths kept waking and with brawling fed.	But I, who have never known how to beg and never had to beg, am starved for food, dizzy with lack of sleep, kept awake with curses and fed with brawling.
And that which spites me more than all these wants, He does it under name of perfect love, As who should say, if I should sleep or eat, 'Twere deadly sickness or else present death.	And what irks me more than all these things put together is that he does it under the pretense of love—as though for me to eat or sleep would bring on fatal illness or sudden death.

You bid me make it orderly and well, According to the fashion and the time.	You told me to make it well and properly and in keeping with the current style.
Marry, and did.	Certainly, I did.

Oh, he hath murdered his master!	Oh God, he’s murdered his master!
O my son, my son!	Oh, my son, my son!
Tell me, thou villain, where is my son Lucentio?	Tell me, you monster, where is my son Lucentio?
Carry this mad knave to the jail.—Father Baptista, I charge you see that he be forthcoming.	Take this mad wretch to jail.—Father-in-law Baptista, will you see that he’s available to appear in court?
Carry me to the jail?	Take me off to jail?
He shall not go to prison.	He mustn’t go to prison.
Talk not, Signior Gremio.	Be quiet, Signior Gremio.
I say he shall go to prison.	I say he shall go to prison.
Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be cony-catched in this business.	Be careful, Signior Baptista, lest you be made the dupe in this business.
I dare swear this is the right Vincentio.	I could swear this is the real Vincentio.
Nay, I dare not swear it.	Well, no, not literally.
Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.	No, I know that you’re Signior Lucentio.
Away with the dotard!	Away with the doddering fool!
To the jail with him!	Take him off to jail!
O!	We’re ruined!
We are spoiled and yonder he is!	There he is!
Pardon, sweet father.	Pardon, dear father.
Lives my sweet son?	Dear son, you’re alive!
Pardon, dear father.	Pardon us, dear father.
How hast thou offended?	What have you done?
Where is Lucentio?	Where is Lucentio?
Here’s Lucentio, right son to the right Vincentio, That have by marriage made thy daughter mine While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.	I have made your daughter mine by marriage while false impressions blinded your eyes.
Here’s packing, with a witness, to deceive us all!	We’ve all been duped.
Where is that damnèd villain, Tranio, That faced and braved me in this matter so?	Where is that damned wretch, Tranio, who defied me in such a disgraceful manner?
Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?	Say, isn’t this the Latin master Cambio?
Cambio is changed into Lucentio.	Cambio is transformed into Lucentio.
Love wrought these miracles.	It was love that performed these miracles.
Bianca’s love Made me exchange my state with Tranio, While he did bear my countenance in the town, And happily I have arrivèd at the last Unto the wishèd haven of my bliss.	Bianca’s love made me trade places with Tranio while he masqueraded as me around town.
What Tranio did, myself enforced him to.	What Tranio did, he did at my command.
Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.	So pardon him, dear father, for my sake.
I’ll slit the villain’s nose that would have sent me to the jail.	No, I’ll slit the nose of the villain who would have sent me to jail.
But do you hear, sir, have you married my daughter without asking my goodwill?	But sir, have you married my daughter without my consent?
Fear not, Baptista, we will content you.	Don’t worry, Baptista, you’ll be perfectly satisfied.
Go to.	You’ll see.
My cake is dough, but I’ll in among the rest, Out of hope of all but my share of the feast.	All I can hope for now is a share of the feast.
Husband, let’s follow to see the end of this ado.	Let’s follow them to see how this turns out.
First kiss me, Kate, and we will.	First kiss me, Kate, and then we will.

What, art thou ashamed of me?	Are you ashamed of me?
No, sir, God forbid, but ashamed to kiss.	But I’m ashamed to kiss, sir.
Why, then let’s home again.	All right then, back home we go.
Nay, I will give thee a kiss.	No, wait.
Is not this well?	I  Isn’t this good?

Better once than never, for never too late.	Better late than never—and it’s never too late to change.
Now Lord be thanked for my good amends!	Well, thank God I’m cured!
Amen.	Amen.
I thank thee.	I thank you all.
Thou shalt not lose by it.	You won’t regret this.

Marry, I fare well, For here is cheer enough.	This is all quite pleasant.

Here, noble lord.	Here, noble lord.
What is thy will with her?	What is your wish with regard to her?
Are you my wife and will not call me “husband”?	You call yourself my wife, yet you don’t call me “husband”?
My men should call me “lord.” I am your goodman.	It’s my men who should call me “lord.” I’m your man, your fellow.

My banquet is to close our stomachs up, After our great good cheer.	This last course here is for closing up the stomach after great feasting.
Pray you, sit down, For now we sit to chat as well as eat.	Now everyone be seated, as this is the part where we sit and chat as well as eat.
Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!	All we do is sit and sit and eat and eat.

He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.	He who is dizzy thinks the world is spinning.
Roundly replied.	A very candid reply.
Mistress, how mean you that?	What’s that supposed to mean?
Thus I conceive by him.	That’s what I conceive of him.
Very well mended.	Nice save!

He that is giddy thinks the world turns round”— I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.	He who is dizzy thinks the world is spinning”—please, tell me what you meant by that.
Your husband being troubled with a shrew Measures my husband’s sorrow by his woe.	Your husband, being saddled with a shrew, projects his own suffering onto my husband.

A very mean meaning.	A very nasty meaning.

A good swift simile, but something currish.	A witty if a cynical reply.

What a foolish duty call you this?	What kind of loyalty is this?

We will have no telling.	There will be no lecture.

Fie, fie!	Girls, girls!
Unknit that threat'ning unkind brow And dart not scornful glances from those eyes To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor.	This disrespectful stance toward the man who is your lord, your king, your governor tarnishes your beauty the way the frosts of winter blights the land.
Such duty as the subject owes the prince, Even such a woman oweth to her husband.	A woman owes her husband the same loyalty a subject owes his king.
And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour, And not obedient to his honest will, What is she but a foul contending rebel And graceless traitor to her loving lord?	And when she is peevish and perverse, sullen, sour, and disobedient to his honest wishes, what is she but a loathsome, warlike rebel and an ungrateful traitor to her loving lord?
I am ashamed that women are so simple To offer war where they should kneel for peace; Or seek for rule, supremacy and sway When they are bound to serve, love, and obey.	I am ashamed that women are so foolish as to declare war when they should plead on their knees for peace, that they seek authority, supremacy, and power when they are under an obligation to serve, love, and obey.
Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, Unapt to toil and trouble in the world, But that our soft conditions and our hearts Should well agree with our external parts?	Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, unfit for toil and trouble in the world, if not so that our soft qualities and our hearts should agree with our external parts?
Come, come, you froward and unable worms!	Come, come, you weak, ungovernable worms!
My mind hath been as big as one of yours, My heart as great, my reason haply more, To bandy word for word and frown for frown.	My spirit has been as proud as each of yours, my courage as great, and my reason perhaps even better suited to bandy words back and forth and exchange frown for frown.
But now I see our lances are but straws, Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare, That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.	But now I see our weapons are like straws, our strength like a straw’s weakness, and our weakness past comparison, so that we seem to be the thing we most are not.

Tis a good hearing when children are toward.	It’s nice to see children playing well together.

Ay, and the time seems thirty unto me, Being all this time abandoned from your bed.	Yes, and it seemed twice as long to me, having been kept from your bed that whole time.
Tis much.—Servants, leave me and her alone.	That’s too long.—Servants, leave her and me alone.

For your physicians have expressly charged, In peril to incur your former malady, That I should yet absent me from your bed.	Your doctors have expressly forbidden me to sleep with you, as there’s a risk that you might have a relapse.
I hope this reason stands for my excuse.	I hope this explanation will stand as my excuse.
Ay, it stands so that I may hardly tarry so long.	I’m not sure I can wait that long.
But I would be loath to fall into my dreams again.	Still, I’d hate to see my former dreams return.
Your Honor’s players, hearing your amendment, Are come to play a pleasant comedy, For so your doctors hold it very meet, Seeing too much sadness hath congealed your blood, And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy.	So I  Your Honor’s actors, hearing of your recovery, have come to perform a pleasing comedy for you—and your doctors approve wholeheartedly.
Therefore they thought it good you hear a play And frame your mind to mirth and merriment, Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life.	So they think it’s a good idea for you to watch a play and direct your thoughts toward laughter and merriment—two strong preventive medicines that foster long life.
Let them play it.	Okay, bring on the play.

Spake you not these words plain: “Sirrah, knock me here, rap me here, knock me well, and knock me soundly”?	Didn’t you clearly say “Knock,” “pound,” and “put your fists to work”?
And come you now with “knocking at the gate”?	Now you say it was “Knock at the gate”?
Petruchio, patience.	I’m warning you.
I am Grumio’s pledge.	Easy, Petruchio.
Why, this' a heavy chance ’twixt him and you, Your ancient, trusty, pleasant servant Grumio.	I’ll vouch for Grumio.
And tell me now, sweet friend, what happy gale Blows you to Padua here from old Verona?	Now, my dear friend, what lucky wind blows you in from Verona?
Such wind as scatters young men through the world To seek their fortunes farther than at home, Where small experience grows.	The wind that scatters young men throughout the world, encouraging them to seek their fortunes some place other than home, where there’s little to be found in the way of experience.
Crowns in my purse I have and goods at home, And so am come abroad to see the world.	I have money in my purse and property at home, so I’m off to see the world.
Thou’dst thank me but a little for my counsel; And yet I’ll promise thee she shall be rich, And very rich.	I doubt you’d thank me in the end, but she’s rich, all right, very rich.
But thou'rt too much my friend, And I’ll not wish thee to her.	But you’re too good a friend for me to wish her on you.
Signior Hortensio, ’twixt such friends as we Few words suffice.	Hortensio, good friends like us can get by on a few words.
I can, Petruchio, help thee to a wife With wealth enough, and young and beauteous, Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman.	I can help you find a wife who’s rich, young, beautiful, and reared in a manner fit for a gentlewoman.
Her only fault, and that is faults enough, Is that she is intolerable curst, And shrewd and froward, so beyond all measure That, were my state far worser than it is, I would not wed her for a mine of gold.	Her only flaw—and it’s a big one—is that she’s unbearable, a total witch, so much so that I wouldn’t think of marrying her myself, not even if I were in a worse fix than I am, not for a whole goldmine.
Hortensio, peace.	Hush, Hortensio.
Thou know’st not gold’s effect.	You don’t know what money can buy.
Her father is Baptista Minola, An affable and courteous gentleman.	Her father is Baptista Minola, a pleasant and courteous gentleman.
Her name is Katherina Minola, Renowned in Padua for her scolding tongue.	Her name is Katherina Minola, famous throughout Padua for her scolding tongue.
I know her father, though I know not her, And he knew my deceasèd father well.	I don’t know her, but I know her father and he knew mine well.

His youngest daughter, the beautiful Bianca, is the jewel of my life, and he keeps her hidden away from me and other rivals for her hand.
Katherine the curst!” A title for a maid of all titles the worst.	Katherine the shrew!” That’s the worst thing you can call a young woman.

Now my friend Petruchio will help me out, presenting me to old Baptista as a schoolmaster for Bianca well-versed in music.
Here’s no knavery!	I’ll disguise myself in somber robes.

Some kinds of baseness Are nobly undergone.	Some kinds of lowly activities are done for noble reasons.
And most poor matters Point to rich ends.	And you can do poor things that lead to rich results.
This my mean task Would be as heavy to me as odious, but The mistress which I serve quickens what’s dead And makes my labors pleasures.	This hard work would be boring and nasty to me, but I’m working for a mistress who makes me enjoy my labor.
Oh, she is Ten times more gentle than her father’s crabbed, And he’s composed of harshness.	Oh, she’s ten times nicer than her father is mean, and he’s the height of crabbiness.
I must remove Some thousands of these logs and pile them up, Upon a sore injunction.	I have thousands of logs to take away and pile up, on strict orders from him.
My sweet mistress Weeps when she sees me work, and says such baseness Had never like executor.	My sweet darling cries when she sees me work and tells me that such a wonderful man never performed such lowly tasks before.
I forget, But these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labors, Most busiest when I do it.	These sweet thoughts relieve me and refresh me, especially when I’m slaving away busily.
Alas now, pray you, Work not so hard.	Now, please, I beg you, don’t work so hard.
I would the lightning had Burnt up those logs that you are enjoined to pile!	I wish the lightning had burned up all those logs that you’ve been ordered to stack!
Pray, set it down and rest you.	Please put that log down and rest a while.
When this burns, 'Twill weep for having wearied you.	When this wood burns, it’ll weep for making you tired.
My father Is hard at study.	My father’s studying hard, so he won’t see you.
Pray now, rest yourself.	So please rest.
He’s safe for these three hours.	We’re safe from my father for at least three hours.
O most dear mistress, The sun will set before I shall discharge What I must strive to do.	Oh, my dear mistress, I won’t be able to finish this work until sunset at the earliest.
If you’ll sit down, I’ll bear your logs the while.	If you sit down, I’ll carry your logs a while.
Pray, give me that.	Please give me that.
I’ll carry it to the pile.	I’ll take it over to the pile.
It would become me As well as it does you, and I should do it With much more ease, for my good will is to it And yours it is against.	I’d be as right for the job as you are, and I’d do it more easily, since I’d have good will on my side.
You look wearily.	You look tired.
I do beseech you— Chiefly that I might set it in my prayers— What is your name?	I beg you to tell me your name so I can use it in my prayers.
Miranda.—O my father, I have broke your hest to say so!	Miranda.—Oh father, I’ve disobeyed you by telling him that!
Full many a lady I have eyed with best regard and many a time	I’ve looked at many ladies with pleasure, and been
For several virtues Have I liked several women.	But with you it’s different.
But you, O you, So perfect and so peerless, are created Of every creature’s best.	You’re perfect, without a rival in the world, made up of the best qualities of every creature.
I do not know One of my sex, no woman’s face remember— Save, from my glass, mine own.	I’ve never known any woman or seen a woman’s face—except my own in the mirror.
Nor have I seen More that I may call men than you, good friend, And my dear father.	And I’ve never met any men besides you and my father.
I am in my condition A prince, Miranda—I do think, a king; I would, not so!—and would no more endure This wooden slavery than to suffer The flesh-fly blow my mouth.	I’m a prince by birth, Miranda—maybe even a king now; though I wish I weren’t—and normally I wouldn’t put up with carrying these logs any more than I’d let flies breed in my mouth.
Hear my soul speak.	But I’ll tell you something from my soul.
The very instant that I saw you did My heart fly to your service, there resides To make me slave to it, and for your sake Am I this patient log-man.	The second I saw you, my heart rushed to serve you and be your slave, so here I am now, a patient log-man.
Do you love me?	Do you love me?
O heaven, O earth, bear witness to this sound And crown what I profess with kind event	Oh heaven, oh earth, witness what I’m about to say, and reward me if I tell the truth!
If I speak true!	If I’m lying, then
I Beyond all limit of what else i' th' world Do love, prize, honor you.	More than anything else in the world, I love you, value you, and honor you.
I am a fool To weep at what I am glad of.	Look at me crying—what a fool I am to cry at what makes me happy.
Wherefore weep you?	Why are you crying?
At mine unworthiness, that dare not offer What I desire to give, and much less take What I shall die to want.	I’m crying at how unworthy I am to give you what I want to give you and to take what I’m dying to have.
But this is trifling, And all the more it seeks to hide itself The bigger bulk it shows.	The more I try to hide what I’m feeling, the bigger it gets.
I am your wife if you will marry me.	I’ll be your wife if you’ll have me.
If not, I’ll die your maid.	Otherwise, I’ll die a virgin, devoted to you.
To be your fellow You may deny me, but I’ll be your servant Whether you will or no.	You can refuse to make me your spouse, but I’ll be your servant whether you want me to or not.
My mistress, dearest, and I thus humble ever.	You’ll be my wife, dearest, and I’ll serve you forever.
My husband, then?	Will you be my husband, then?
A thousand thousand!	A million goodbyes to you.
I’ll to my book, For yet ere supper-time must I perform Much business appertaining.	Now it’s time to get back to my studying, since I have a lot of serious business to take care of before dinner.
Tell not me.	Don’t tell me that.
When the butt is out, we will drink water.	When the barrel’s empty, we’ll drink water.

The folly of this island.	What a crazy island this is.
They say there’s but five upon this isle.	They say there are only five people on it.
We are three of them.	We’re three of them.

Her waspish-headed son has broke his arrows, Swears he will shoot no more, but play with sparrows And be a boy right out.	Venus went home again, and her little son broke all his arrows, swearing he’ll never shoot them again, but play with birds like other little boys.

I told you, sir, they were red-hot with drinking, So full of valor that they smote the air For breathing in their faces, beat the ground For kissing of their feet—yet always bending Towards their project.	I told you, sir, they were totally drunk, so puffed up with courage that they were getting angry at the air for blowing in their faces, and beating the ground for touching their feet—yet even when drunk, they kept their plan firmly in mind.
Then I beat my tabor, At which, like unbacked colts, they pricked their ears, Advanced their eyelids, lifted up their noses As they smelt music.	Then I beat my drum, at which point they pricked up their ears and opened their eyes, looking around for the source of my music.
So I charmed their ears That, calflike, they my lowing followed through Toothed briers, sharp furzes, pricking gorse, and thorns, Which entered their frail shins.	I enchanted them so thoroughly that they followed me through thorn bushes and prickly shrubs that tore up their shins.
At last I left them I' th' filthy-mantled pool beyond your cell, There dancing up to th' chins, that the foul lake O'erstunk their feet.	In the end I left them standing in the smelly pond behind your room, with the stinking water covering them up to their chins.
This was well done, my bird.	Good job, my little one.
Thy shape invisible retain thou still.	Stay invisible.
The trumpery in my house, go bring it hither For stale to catch these thieves.	Bring the fancy clothes out of my house, to use as bait to catch these thieves.
I go, I go.	I’m going, I’m going.
A devil, a born devil on whose nature Nurture can never stick, on whom my pains, Humanely taken, all, all lost, quite lost.	He’s a devil, a born devil, who can never be trained.
And as with age his body uglier grows, So his mind cankers.	As his body grows uglier with age, his mind rots away as well.
I will plague them all, Even to roaring.	I’ll torment them all till they roar with pain.
Come, hang them on this line.	Here, hang them on this clothesline.
Pray you, tread softly, that the blind mole may not hear a foot fall.	Please walk softly, so not even a mole hears us approach.
We now are near his cell.	We’re near his room now.
Monster, your fairy, which you say is a harmless fairy, has done little better than played the jack with us.	Hey monster, the spirit you’ve been talking about, the one you call harmless, has been playing tricks on us.
Monster, I do smell all horse piss, at which my nose is in great indignation.	Monster, I smell like horse piss, which is making my nose pretty upset.
So is mine.—Do you hear, monster?	Mine too.—Are you listening, monster?
If I should take a displeasure against you, look you—  Thou wert but a lost monster.	If I decide to get angry at you, just watch out— You’d be done for then, monster.
Good my lord, give me thy favor still.	My good lord, I still need you to like me.
Be patient, for the prize I’ll bring thee to Shall hoodwink this mischance.	Be patient, because the prize I’m leading you to will make you forget how smelly you are now.
Therefore speak softly.	So be quiet.
All’s hushed as midnight yet.	It’s as silent as a graveyard here.
That’s more to me than my wetting.	That upsets me much more than getting wet.
Yet this is your harmless fairy, monster.	And you called the fairy creature harmless, monster.

Seest thou here, This is the mouth o' th' cell.	Look here, this is the entrance to his room.
No noise, and enter.	Be silent and go in.

I do begin to have bloody thoughts.	I’m starting to feel murderous urges.
Let it alone, thou fool.	Leave it alone, you fool.
It is but trash.	It’s worthless.
Oh, ho, monster, we know what belongs to a frippery.—   Put off that gown, Trinculo.	Oh, monster, we know secondhand clothes when we see them.— Take off that gown, Trinculo.
By this hand, I’ll have that gown.	I swear that gown’s for me.
Thy grace shall have it.	You can have it then, your highness.
The dropsy drown this fool!	To hell with this idiot!
What do you mean To dote thus on such luggage?	Why are you going crazy over these trashy clothes?
Let’s alone, And do the murder first.	Leave them alone, and do the murder first.

Do, do.	Thank you kindly.

Wit shall not go unrewarded while I am king of this country.	As king of this country I like to reward wit when I hear it.
There’s another garment for ’t.	Here’s another jacket to say thanks.

I will have none on ’t.	I won’t have any of this.

Hark, they roar.	Listen they’re howling.

My charms crack not, my spirits obey, and time Goes upright with his carriage.	My spells are working well, my spirits are obeying me, and everything is right on schedule.

On the sixth hour, at which time, my lord, You said our work should cease.	It’s after six o'clock, my lord, when you said our work would be finished.
I did say so When first I raised the tempest.	That’s what I said when I first conjured the tempest.

Confined together In the same fashion as you gave in charge, Just as you left them, all prisoners, sir, In the line grove which weather-fends your cell.	All cooped up together, just as you ordered, all imprisoned in the grove of linden trees that protects your room from bad weather.
They cannot budge till your release.	They can’t move till you release them.
The king, His brother, and yours, abide all three distracted, And the remainder mourning over them, Brimful of sorrow and dismay.	The king, his brother, and your brother are all waiting there in a crazed state of mind, and the rest are grieving over them, sad and astonished.
But chiefly Him that you termed, sir, “the good old Lord Gonzalo,” His tears run down his beard like winter’s drops From eaves of reeds.	Good old lord Gonzalo,” as you call him, is saddest of all, with tears running down his beard.
Your charm so strongly works 'em That if you now beheld them, your affections Would become tender.	Your magic spell has such an effect on them that if you saw them now, you’d feel sorry for them.
Dost thou think so, spirit?	Do you think so, spirit?
Mine would, sir, were I human.	I’d feel sorry for them, if I were human.
And mine shall.	I will too.
The rarer action is In virtue than in vengeance.	It’s better to act virtuously rather than vengefully.
Go release them, Ariel.	Go release them, Ariel.
My charms I’ll break, their senses I’ll restore, And they shall be themselves.	I’ll break my spells and bring them back to their senses, and they’ll feel like themselves again.

With his own bolt;     the strong-based promontory Have I made shake, and by the spurs plucked up The pine and cedar; graves at my command Have waked their sleepers, oped, and let 'em forth By my so potent art.	With his own lightning bolts; I’ve shaken up the sturdy cliffs and uprooted pines and cedars; I’ve opened up graves and awakened the corpses sleeping in them, letting them out with my powerful magic.
But this rough magic I here abjure, and when I have required Some heavenly music, which even now I do, To work mine end upon their senses that This airy charm is for, I’ll break my staff, Bury it certain fathoms in the earth, And deeper than did ever plummet sound I’ll drown my book.	But I surrender all this magic now, when I’ve summoned some heavenly music to cast a spell, as I’m doing now, I’ll break my staff and bury it far underground, and throw my book of magic spells deeper into the sea than any anchor ever sank.
A solemn air and the best comforter To an unsettled fancy cure thy brains, Now useless, boiled within thy skull.—There stand, For you are spell-stopped.—   Mine eyes, ev'n sociable to the show of thine, Fall fellowly drops. You the like loss?	You suffered a loss like mine?
As great to me as late.	Yes, just as great and just as recent.

In this last tempest.	In this recent storm.
I perceive these lords At this encounter do so much admire That they devour their reason and scarce think Their eyes do offices of truth, their words Are natural breath.—But howsoev'r you have Been justled from your senses, know for certain That I am Prospero and that very duke Which was thrust forth of Milan, who most strangely Upon this shore where you were wracked, was landed, To be the lord on ’t.	These lords seem so astonished that they’ve lost their use of reason and can hardly believe what they see with their own eyes.—But whatever the reason for your losing your senses, you can know for sure that I’m Prospero, that same duke who was kicked out of Milan and landed on this same island where you landed, and became the lord of it.

he whom next thyself Of all the world I loved and to him put The manage of my state, as at that time Through all the signories it was the first, And Prospero the prime duke, being so reputed In dignity, and for the liberal arts Without a parallel.	My brother whom—aside from you—I loved more than anyone else in the world, I trusted to run my state, which at that time was the strongest in the land, and Prospero the number one duke, famous for my dignity and my education.
Those being all my study, The government I cast upon my brother And to my state grew stranger, being transported And rapt in secret studies. In one voyage Did Claribel her husband find at Tunis; And Ferdinand, her brother, found a wife Where he himself was lost; Prospero, his dukedom In a poor isle; and all of us, ourselves When no man was his own. I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated To closeness and the bettering of my mind With that which, but by being so retired, O'erprized all popular rate, in my false brother Awaked an evil nature.	As I neglected practical matters, being totally dedicated to solitude and to improving my mind with subjects more valuable than most people imagine, I was so shut away from the world that I unwittingly stirred up evil wishes in my disloyal brother.
And my trust, Like a good parent, did beget of him A falsehood in its contrary as great As my trust was, which had indeed no limit, A confidence sans bound.	My deep trust in him made him deeply untrustworthy, arousing in him a treachery as big as my trust was—my trust which had no limit, an infinite confidence.
Hence his ambition growing— Dost thou hear?	With his ambition growing like this—do you hear what I’m saying?

On their sustaining garments not a blemish, But fresher than before.	Even their clothes are unstained, and look fresher than before the storm.
And, as thou badest me, In troops I have dispersed them 'bout the isle.	I’ve separated them into groups around the island, just as you ordered.
The king’s son have I landed by himself, Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs In an odd angle of the isle, and sitting, His arms in this sad knot.	I sent the king’s son off by himself to a faraway nook on the island, where he’s sitting now sighing, with his arms crossed like this.
Of the king’s ship, The mariners, say how thou hast disposed, And all the rest o' th' fleet.	Tell me what you did with the king’s ship, the sailors, and the other ships.
The mariners all under hatches stowed, Who, with a charm joined to their suffered labor, I have left asleep.	The sailors are all below deck, sleeping both from their labor and from a magic spell I cast over them.
And for the rest o' th' fleet, Which I dispersed, they all have met again And are upon the Mediterranean float, Bound sadly home for Naples, Supposing that they saw the king’s ship wracked And his great person perish.	As for the rest of the ships, I scattered them, and they’ve gathered again in the Mediterranean, sailing sadly home to Naples, believing that they witnessed the shipwreck and death of their great king.
Ariel, thy charge Exactly is performed.	Ariel, you’ve done your work exactly as I ordered.
But there’s more work.	But there’s more work to be done.
What is the time o' th' day?	What time is it?
Past the mid season.	Past noon.
At least two glasses.	At least two hours past.
The time ’twixt six and now Must by us both be spent most preciously.	We can’t waste time between now and six o'clock.
Is there more toil?	Is there more work to do?
Since thou dost give me pains, Let me remember thee what thou hast promised, Which is not yet performed me.	Since you’re giving me new assignments, let me remind you what you promised me but haven’t come through with yet.
How now?	What?
Moody?	You’re in a bad mood?
What is ’t thou canst demand?	What could you possibly ask for?
My liberty.	My freedom.
Before the time be out?	Before your sentence has been completed?
No more!	Don’t say anything else.
I prithee, Remember I have done thee worthy service, Told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, served Without or grudge or grumblings.	I beg you, remember the good work I’ve done for you, and how I’ve never lied to you, never made mistakes, and never grumbled in my work.
Thou didst promise To bate me a full year.	You promised to take a full year off my sentence.
Dost thou forget From what a torment I did free thee?	Have you forgotten the torture I freed you from?
No.	No.
Thou dost, and think’st it much to tread the ooze Of the salt deep, To run upon the sharp wind of the north, To do me business in the veins o' th' earth When it is baked with frost.	You have forgotten, and you think it’s a burden when I ask you to walk through the ocean, or run on the north wind, or do business for me underground when the earth’s frozen solid.
I do not, sir.	No, I don’t, sir.
Thou liest, malignant thing!	You lie, you nasty, ungrateful thing!
Hast thou forgot The foul witch Sycorax, who with age and envy Was grown into a hoop?	Have you forgotten the horrid witch Sycorax, stooped over with old age and ill will?
Hast thou forgot her?	Have you forgotten her?
No, sir.	No, sir.
Thou hast.	You have.
Where was she born?	Where was she born?
Speak.	Speak.
Tell me.	Tell me.
Sir, in Argier.	In Algiers, sir.
Oh, was she so?	Oh, was she now?
I must Once in a month recount what thou hast been, Which thou forget’st.	I’ll have to tell the story again every month, since you seem to forget it.
This damned witch Sycorax, For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible To enter human hearing, from Argier, Thou know’st, was banished.	This damned witch Sycorax was kicked out of Algiers for various witching crimes too terrible for humans to hear about.
For one thing she did They would not take her life.	But for one reason they refused to execute her.
Is not this true?	Isn’t that true?
Ay, sir.	Yes, sir.
This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with child And here was left by th' sailors.	This sunken-eyed hag was brought here pregnant and left by the sailors.
Thou, my slave, As thou report’st thyself, wast then her servant.	You, my slave, were her servant at the time, as you admit yourself.
And, for thou wast a spirit too delicate To act her earthy and abhorred commands, Refusing her grand hests, she did confine thee, By help of her more potent ministers And in her most unmitigable rage, Into a cloven pine, within which rift Imprisoned thou didst painfully remain A dozen years; within which space she died And left thee there, where thou didst vent thy groans As fast as mill wheels strike.	In a fit of rage she locked you up in a hollow pine tree, with the help of her powerful assistants, and left you there for twelve years.
Dull thing, I say so.	That’s right, you stupid thing.
He, that Caliban Whom now I keep in service.	Caliban, who now serves me.
It was mine art, When I arrived and heard thee, that made gape The pine and let thee out.	It was my magic that saved you when I arrived on the island and heard you, making the pine tree open and let you out.
I thank thee, master.	Thank you, master.
If thou more murmur’st, I will rend an oak And peg thee in his knotty entrails till Thou hast howled away twelve winters.	If you complain any more, I’ll split an oak tree and lock you up in it till you’ve howled for twelve years.
Pardon, master.	Please forgive me, master.
I will be correspondent to command And do my spiriting gently.	I’ll be obedient and do all my tasks without complaining.
Do so, and after two days I will discharge thee.	Do that, and I’ll set you free in two days.
That’s my noble master!	That’s noble of you, master.
What shall I do?	What shall I do for you?
Say, what?	Just tell me.
What shall I do?	What shall I do?
Go make thyself like a nymph o' th' sea.	Go disguise yourself as a sea nymph.
Be subject To no sight but thine and mine, invisible To every eyeball else.	Be invisible to everyone except yourself and me.
Go take this shape And hither come in ’t.	Take this garment, put it on, and then come back here.
Go hence with diligence.	Hurry, go!
Shake it off.	Shake off your sleepiness.
Come on.	Come on.
We’ll visit Caliban, my slave who never Yields us kind answer.	We’ll go visit Caliban, my slave who always talks to us so nastily.
But as ’tis, We cannot miss him.	But even so, we can’t do without him.
He does make our fire, Fetch in our wood, and serves in offices That profit us.—What, ho!	He builds our fires, gets our firewood, and does all kinds of useful things for us.—Hey!
Slave!	Caliban!
Caliban!	Pile of dirt!
Speak.	Say something.
Come forth, I say!	Come out, I order you.
There’s other business for thee.	There’s other work for you to do.
Come, thou tortoise!	Come on, you turtle!
Fine apparition!	What a fine sight!
My quaint Ariel, Hark in thine ear.	My dear clever Ariel, listen carefully.
My lord it shall be done.	My lord, I’ll do it right away.
As wicked dew as e'er my mother brushed With raven’s feather from unwholesome fen Drop on you both!	I hope you both get drenched with a dew as evil as what my mother used to collect with a crow’s feather from the poison swamps.
A southwest blow on ye And blister you all o'er!	May a hot southwest wind blow on you and cover you with blisters all over.
For this, be sure, tonight thou shalt have cramps, Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up.	I’ll give you cramps for saying that—horrible pains in your sides that will keep you from breathing.
Urchins Shall, forth at vast of night that they may work, All exercise on thee.	I’ll send goblins out at night to work their nasty deeds on you.
Thou shalt be pinched As thick as honeycomb, each pinch more stinging Than bees that made 'em.	You’ll be pricked all over, and it’ll sting like bees.
I must eat my dinner.	I have to eat my dinner now.
This island’s mine, by Sycorax my mother, Which thou takest from me.	This island belongs to me because Sycorax, my mother, left it to me.
Cursed be I that did so!	I curse myself for doing that!
Thou most lying slave, Whom stripes may move, not kindness!	You liar, you respond better to the whip than to kindness!
I have used thee, Filth as thou art, with human care, and lodged thee In mine own cell till thou didst seek to violate The honor of my child.	I took good care of you—piece of filth that you are—and let you stay in my own hut until you tried to rape my daughter.
Oh ho, oh ho!	Oh ho, oh ho!
Would ’t had been done!	I wish I had!
Thou didst prevent me.	You stopped me.
Abhorrèd slave, Which any print of goodness wilt not take, Being capable of all ill!	You horrid slave, you can’t be trained to be good, and you’re capable of anything evil!
I pitied thee, Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hour One thing or other.	I pitied you, worked hard to teach you to speak, and taught you some new thing practically every hour.
But thy vile race, Though thou didst learn, had that in ’t which good natures Could not abide to be with.	But you had bad blood in you, no matter how much you learned, and good people couldn’t stand to be near you.
Therefore wast thou Deservedly confined into this rock, Who hadst deserved more than a prison.	So you got what you deserved, and were locked up in this cave, which is more fitting for the likes of you than a prison would be.
You taught me language, and my profit on ’t Is I know how to curse.	You taught me language, and all I can do with it is curse.
The red plague rid you For learning me your language!	Damn you for teaching me your language!
No, pray thee.	No, please.
So, slave, hence!	Go then, slave.
The watchdogs bark.	The watchdogs bark.
Hark, hark!	Listen, listen!
I hear The strain of strutting chanticleer Cry “Cock-a-diddle-dow.” Where should this music be?	Where’s that music coming from?
I' th' air or th' earth?	From the earth, or the air?
It sounds no more, and sure, it waits upon Some god o' th' island.	It’s stopped now—it must be played for some local god of the island.
Sitting on a bank, Weeping again the king my father’s wrack, This music crept by me upon the waters, Allaying both their fury and my passion With its sweet air.	As I sat on the shore crying over my father’s shipwreck, I heard the music creep over the wild waves, calming their fury and soothing my own grief with its sweet melodies.
Thence I have followed it, Or it hath drawn me rather.	I followed it here, or I should say it dragged me here.
But ’tis gone.	But now it’s stopped.
No, it begins again.	No, there it is again.
Hark, now I hear them.	Listen, I hear them.
The ditty does remember my drowned father.	This song’s about my dead father.
I hear it now above me.	I hear it now overhead.
What is ’t?	What is it?
A spirit?	A spirit?
Lord, how it looks about!	Lord, it’s glancing every which way!

But ’tis a spirit.	It must be a spirit.
No, wench!	No, girl!
It eats and sleeps and hath such senses As we have, such.	It eats and sleeps and has the same five senses we do.

Hence!	Now get out of here!
To cabin, silence!	Go to your cabins and be quiet!
Trouble us not.	Don’t bother us up here.
Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.	Just remember who you’ve got on board with you, good man.
None that I more love than myself.	Nobody I care about more than myself.
You are a councilor.	You’re a king’s advisor.
Use your authority.	Go ahead, use your authority.
If you cannot, give thanks you have lived so long and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap.—Cheerly, good hearts!—Out of our way, I say.	If you can’t do it, be grateful you’ve lived this long and go wait to die in your cabin, if it comes to that.—Harder, men!—Now get out of our way, I’m telling you.
I have great comfort from this fellow.	I feel a lot better after talking to this guy.
I might call him A thing divine, for nothing natural I ever saw so noble.	I could imagine he’s divine, since I never saw anything so noble-looking on earth before.
No wonder, sir, But certainly a maid.	I’m not marvelous, sir, but I’m certainly a maiden.
My language!	She speaks my language!

How?	What’s that?
The best?	The highest-ranking?
What wert thou if the King of Naples heard thee?	What would the King of Naples do if he heard you say that?
A single thing, as I am now, that wonders To hear thee speak of Naples.	He would just see me for what I am, a person amazed to hear you talking about Naples.
He does hear me, And that he does I weep.	He does hear me, and that makes me cry.
Myself am Naples, Who with mine eyes, never since at ebb, beheld The king my father wracked.	I myself am the King of Naples, since I saw with my own eyes—these eyes that haven’t been dry since—my father killed in a shipwreck.
Alack, for mercy!	Ah, how pitiful!
Yes, faith, and all his lords, the Duke of Milan And his brave son being twain.	Yes, indeed, and all the King’s men, the Duke of Milan and his fine son too.
Soft, sir!	Hang on, sir!

If the ill spirit have so fair a house, Good things will strive to dwell with ’t.	If the devil had such a beautiful house as his body, then good things would fight to live in it.
What, I say?	What’s that?

Hence!	Let go of me!

What, An advocate for an imposter?	You’re defending an impostor?

My affections Are then most humble.	Then my love is humble.
I have no ambition To see a goodlier man.	I don’t feel any urge to see a more handsome man than this one.
So they are.	That’s true, they are.
My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.	My strength is all gone, as if in a dream.

The death of my father, my physical weakness, the loss of all my friends, the threats of this man who’s taken me prisoner—all that would be easy for me to take, if only I could look through my prison windows once a day and see this girl.
Space enough Have I in such a prison.	A prison like that would give me enough liberty.

A dollar.	What a pain.

Done.	You’re on.

Though this island seem to be desert—	Though this island may appear desolate—

The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.	There’s always a breath of fresh air here.
Or as ’twere perfumed by a fen.	Stinking like a swamp.
Here is everything advantageous to life.	This island contains everything beneficial to life.
True.	True.
Save means to live.	Everything except something to live on.

He misses not much.	He doesn’t miss a thing.

Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report.	Or stuff what he says into their pockets.

Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.	It was a lovely wedding, and we’re doing really well on our trip home.

His word is more than the miraculous harp.	Gonzalo is a miracle-worker.

Ay.	Yes indeed.

Very well.	All right, I’ll stop.
And most chirurgeonly.	Like a good doctor.

Very foul.	Yes, very bad.

And were the king on ’t, what would I do?	And if I were king of it, you know what I’d do?
